text:
Sections

The Indigenous and Islamic Traditions and Transformations
The Hispanic Traditions and Transformations
The American Tradition and Transformations
The Period of the Republics
Epilogue

 

Geographically, the Philippines belongs to the East, but it has absorbed considerable cultural influences from the West due primarily to 333 years of Spanish rule and 45 years of American domination. Its ancient Asian roots are still seen in highland and in lowland out-of-the-way barangays where indigenous cultures have thrived, despite Western influences that have seeped through the country’s borders via technology and the people who constantly move between local and global spaces. In the urban areas, Hispanic, American, and other transnational influences are highly evident in the social, economic, and political aspects of life. Shaped by cross-cultural contacts with Western and non-Western traditions, Philippine music of today consists of several streams: indigenous, Hispanic-influenced, and the American- or transnational-influenced.

 

 

The Indigenous and Islamic Traditions and Transformations

 

The so-called indigenous and Islamic-influenced traditions are practiced by about 14-17% of the total population of 100 million Filipinos, based on the 2014 Philippine Census. Around 33% of this group is represented by ethnolinguistic groups living in the mountains of northern Luzon, and 61% is in the islands of Mindanao and Sulu in southern Philippines. The rest live in Palawan and in the highlands of Mindoro in western Philippines. Indigenous peoples of the Philippines include the Aeta groups called Ita, Abyan, Agta, Ati, Dumagat, Batak, and Mamanua, among other names; the northern groups like the Isneg, Tinguian, Kalinga, Bontok, Ifugao, Kankanaey, Ibaloy, Bugkalot (Ilongot), Itawes, Isinay, and Gaddang; the southern non-Muslim groups of Mindanao like the Manobo, Bagobo, Subanon, Tiruray, Tboli, Mandaya, Mansaka, and Blaan; the Palawan and Tagbanwa of Palawan; and the Mangyan groups of Mindoro. The other six percent of these minority groups are the Muslims from Mindanao and Sulu, comprised of the Maguindanao and Maranao of Mindanao, the Yakan of Basilan, and the Tausug, Sama, Sama Dilaut, and Jama Mapun of the Sulu area.

 

Among the indigenous musical traditions, some common instruments are found. They include the lip-valley flute, pipe, reed pipe, transverse flute, bamboo and shell trumpets, polychordal bamboo zither, parallel-stringed zither, bamboo mouth organ, mouth harp, and the cylindrical drum. Similar instruments are found throughout Southeast Asia. These instruments may be made of bamboo, shell, wood, skin, vine, hair, and other materials found in the tropics.

 

On the other hand, musical instruments peculiar only to the north are flat gongs, bamboo buzzers, clappers, quill-shaped percussion tubes, and brass mouth harps. The presence of these types of instruments associates this tradition with continental Southeast Asia. Instruments found only in the south are a variety of bossed gongs, ring flutes, plank drums, xylophones, single-stringed violins, and suspended beams, which indicate links with Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, and South China.

 

The Islamic music tradition in the south is part of the musical heritage of the pre-Islamic cultures of Mindanao. Thus, they share similar instruments as well as vocal forms. Instrumental music includes a gong ensemble consisting of a graduated set of 5 to 11 gongs laid in a row played with other larger gongs like the agung, gandingan, and percussion instruments like the drums or split bamboos. The combination of instruments in the ensemble varies among the different groups. Aside from these, there are suspended wide-rimmed bossed gongs, two-stringed lutes, mouth harp, percussion beams, and bamboo slit drums.

 

The vocal repertoire is performed either in responsorial or solo manner. The singing style found among the northern groups differs from that of the south. The northern style uses a marked and rhythmic enunciation of vowels to form syllables or slides, half-speech sounds, and frequent pauses. By contrast, the southern style uses melisma, long phrases, a narrow range, fluid singing, and tremolo. A newer Islamic style superimposed on this tradition has a distinct vocal delivery, with a high tessitura, a strained voice of various timbres, and a nasal enunciation.

 

An example of responsorial singing of the leader-chorus type is the Ibaloy ba-diw. It is used in ceremonies for the dead called du-udyeng or ta-tamiya, as well as on such occasions as weddings, peshit or anniversary feasts, and thanksgiving rituals. The leader-chorus singing is also employed by the Bontok during important feasts like the chuno, in celebration of a victory or kay-aya, or in a curing ritual like the siyenga. Among the Tagbanwa, one ceremony has a woman leader singing and dancing around jars of rice wine as she tries to communicate with the spirits. As she dances, a group of young girls follows her, and as she sings, the chorus repeats the last syllables of her lines. Another type of responsorial singing are song debates such as the Bukidnon sala, Kankanaey day-eng, and the Tagbanwa taval-tavalan. These debates, usually between a man and a woman, are about everyday topics, particularly love.

 

Epic songs may be chanted at weddings or in gatherings to entertain guests, or may be simply used as evening entertainment for the villagers themselves. Epics may last for one or more nights and are attended with keen interest. Common among ethnic groups in the Philippines, epics describe the lives of heroes and gods. Some of these are the Ata Tulalang, the Blaan Aflulok, the Bukidnon Olaginon and Agyu, the Ifugao Hudhud, the Ilonggo Hinilawod, the Maguindanao Raja Madaya, the Maranao Darangen, the Mandaya Daut, the Mangguagan Tad-um, the Manobo Ulahingan, Agyu, and Tuwaang, the Mansaka Manggob, the Subanon Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan and Keg Sumba neg Sandayo, the Tboli Tudbulol, the Tagbanwa Dumarakol, and the Tiruray Berinarew.

 

Solo songs are sung for all kinds of occasions. They may be accompanied by instruments and/or dancing. Generally, there is no generic term for song—only names of particular song genres. Among the Kalinga, the dango, ading, and oggayam song genres are traditional in important ceremonies like peace pacts, weddings, and community gatherings. They are used to express a declaration, greeting, or statement related to the occasion. The Maranao bayok is usually sung at weddings and festivities. The singers are specialists who become the center of attraction in social gatherings where, as protagonists, they vie with each other in extemporizing allusions and double meanings, much to the delight of their audience.

 

Songs in connection with life-cycle events abound among all groups. Most common are lullabies like the Tiruray ambay, the Sama ngindung, the Palawan linggayen pa iga, the Maranao bomboman, the Mansaka uyug-uyug, the Manobo buwa-buwa, the Maguindanao sengal, the Bugkalot (Ilongot) emaga, the Ibaloy tami, the Blaan yadadang, and the Aeta adiyadi. Some groups have special songs to accompany rituals for children such as the Kalinga dopdopit, sung on the first bath of the child outside the house. During the Subanon circumcision ritual khundit, the baylan (shaman) chants the manambay. The Kalinga sing the dinnayan, dawak, and paliwat during an egam ritual, which celebrates the rite of passage from boyhood to manhood.

 

Most numerous of the life cycle songs are those sung during courtship and marriage ceremonies. In Sagada, young Bontok boys sing the tigtigaddo when visiting girls in their sleeping house. The Ata Manobo maiden of Davao del Norte sings the uranda to her swain, and he in turn sings the kumapuy to his beloved. Manobo courtship songs called sangong-sangong are often accompanied by an instrument: the saluray, kugot, or kitara. Courting songs of the Zambales Ayta are called awara. In Negros Oriental, the Negrito love song is called balak. The Palawan kulilal is a love song accompanied by the pagang. Wedding feasts are celebrated with much music making. There are songs which form part of the ceremony such as the sapo and ayyeng of the Kankanaey. The Kalinga sing the sugsugna to express gratitude to the couple. In the south, the Manobo sing the pamada (introduction) at a wedding and the pamal-i kagum as a wedding ceremony speech.

 

Death is an occasion for extolling the departed through song. The Bontok have special songs for the dead. The didiyaw expresses grief and is a prayer for a good afterlife for a small child, while the fulayao recalls the good deeds of the newly departed. This genre is similar to the day-eng of the Kankanaey of Benguet, which eulogizes the dead. The Kalinga sing the dassar before the burial of a murdered person so that vengeance for the murderer will take place sooner. Manobo mourning songs are the dalinday, tud-um, and diaga. At the funeral, they sing the tamandag in the presence of a baylan so as not to attract evil spirits. On a death anniversary, the Subanon sing the bahay-bahay.

 

Occupational songs abound among the different groups. These are sung in connection with farming, fishing, or doing simple chores. Particularly numerous are songs connected with the rice planting and harvesting cycle. The Mandaya sing the indowan to call people to plant rice. While working in the field, the Bontok sing the ayoweng. To protect the field from pests, the Kankanaey sing the soswa. Harvest songs by the Manobo are the layad-layad and balutuking. In the north, the Ifugao and Kalinga sing the liwliwa and sugiyaw/owayat in thanksgiving for a bountiful harvest. The tiyasha is a Bontok rice-pounding song.

 

Special rituals with corresponding music are performed for various purposes. There are rituals for curing the sick such as the Subanon khundit where the manambay is chanted. The Bontok chant the kapya; the Ibaloy, the angba; the Ifugao, the mangolhod; and the Bugkalot (Ilongot), the bariling to ask the spirits to cure illnesses. Among the Agusanon Manobo, the voice emitted from the ritual specialist medium called babaylan in a curing ritual called hinang is perceived to be that of the guardian spirit. The chant is called tud-om. Rituals are also performed for thanksgiving such as the Aeta diniwata or the Batak didayu; for weddings, such as the Blaan andaray and bansula; for blessing a new house, as in the Bontok sabosab; for victory, like the Ibaloy bindayan; for war, as in the Ifugao chajang; for the datu (chieftain), like the Manobo dumalongdong; or for seeking special favors, as in the Subanon somodiot.

 

In the Muslim tradition, the celebration of important feasts such as the visits of dignitaries or the inauguration of new officials are lavish affairs which include the participation of epic singers invited from different parts of the province, several instrumental ensembles, and dancers. Parts of the Quran are sung, and gongs are played during weddings. On the other hand, no instrumental music is played during the religious celebrations of Ramadan, the birth of Muhammad, or the Friday noon service.

 

 

 

The Hispanic Traditions and Transformations

 

In 1521 the travel of Ferdinand Magellan, who reached the Philippines by chance while in search of an alternative trade route, marked an important watershed in the Westernization of the world, which has resulted in what is known today as globalization. This eventually led to the Spanish colonization and Christianization of the country, and it planted the seeds of European harmonic music, which was totally unknown to Asia at that time. In over 300 years, from 1565 to 1898, these seeds took shape and produced religious music both connected to and outside the liturgy of the Catholic Church; secular music from Europe and even a European type of music that was developed by Filipinos; folk songs; and music of string and brass ensembles. These forms and types of music took hold of every segment of the society, from the rural villages to the urban centers of the rich.

 

In the early Spanish missionary contacts, the importance placed by the religious orders on music sprang from the belief that music was a most powerful means to win the spirit of a people and make them understand Christian ways and beliefs. The friars were given special musical training in Spain before coming to the Philippines. Among the friars who taught music from late 16th to 18th centuries were the Franciscans San Pedro Bautista, who was assigned to Lumban, Laguna in 1586; Juan de Santa Marta, who arrived in 1606; Geronimo Aguilar, who arrived in 1582; and arriving two centuries after, Jose de la Virgen, who composed a treatise on plain chant in the Bikol language in 1727 which is now lost. From the 18th to 19th centuries, the Augustinians had musician-priests like Lorenzo Castello, Juan Bolivar, and Manuel de Arostegui.

 

The Augustinian church in Intramuros produced noted Filipino musicians like Marcelo de San Agustin in the 17th century, who is the first indigeno (native) named in historical sources to have composed music in the Western idiom (Irving 2010, 172-3). From mid-18th century, the Dominican santuario San Juan del Monte produced a set of devotional hymns in villancico form, one of which had a text in Tagalog. This manuscript is doubly significant; not only is it the first extant evidence of local compositional production in the country, but also the mixing of Western melody and vernacular text as seen in the manuscript is inaugural. From that period up to the early 19th century, choir books of cowhide parchment containing collections of liturgical music had been preserved in a number of churches around the country, a good example of which was that from Baclayon, Bohol. By late 19th century, noted church music composers were Marcelo Adonay, Jose Canseco, and Pedro Navarro, with the latter two also active as maestros of military bands.

 

Throughout the islands, the Church and its clergy had a commanding impact on the musical life of Christianized Filipinos. The clergy’s sociopolitical influence, backed by the colonial policy of unity between Church and State, extended to the secular sphere. Many secular priests founded town bands and had the power to decide on how a fiesta, both a sacred and profane event, was to be celebrated. There was even a native priest named Fr Jose Zamora, who translated a fundamental music theory tutor book in Tagalog in 1888. The first and only book of its kind in Philippine history, it could be understood as an intervention made by a civic-minded clergy who felt that the islands lacked musically literate citizens and musicians.

 

New forms of Latin-influenced extraliturgical and secular folk music emerged from the cross-cultural encounters between Hispanic and local Philippine cultures. These became part of Philippine lowland music culture, particularly outside of towns and cities. Today, these folk traditions and practices in Catholic rituals and celebrations are still vigorously practiced.

 

At the start of the liturgical year, during advent, carolers roam the town streets, serenading households in the tradition called pastores in Bicol, tambora in Cuyo, and daigon in the Visayas. An elaborate outdoor folk drama variously called panunuluyan, pananawagan, and pananapatan in the Tagalog areas, and kagharong in Bicol reenacts, in sung dialogue and on the streets, Mary and Joseph’s search for a lodging in Bethlehem on Christmas Eve. The Lenten season is the occasion for the pabasa or the chanting of the pasyon, the versified story of the life and passion of Jesus Christ. In May, the flores de Mayo, a procession in honor of the Blessed Virgin, is held and adults and children sing popular songs and hymns. Before the procession, while flowers are offered at the foot of the Virgin’s altar, the salve, loa, saludo, and despedida in the 19th-century romantic idiom are sung. Also in May, the santacruzan features songs during the procession for the Santa Cruz. In Siquijor in southern Philippines, the sinulog is a dance ritual that recalls the fight between Christians and Moors, with the Christians emerging victorious through the intercession of Santiago. In the Bicol region, the kristianong turog is sung during the aurora—dawn processions celebrating a good harvest or a thanksgiving.

 

An important school in the mid-18th century was the Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral where many future Filipino musicians received their training in solfeggio, vocalization, and playing of instruments. By the last half of the 19th century, the school had adopted a curriculum patterned after that of the Conservatory of Madrid. Some of the Catedral’s teachers that time were well-known Spanish composers like Apolonio and Remigio Calahorra. Products of this school included Antonio Garcia, Simplicio Solis, Salvador Piñon, Hipolito Rivera, Fulgencio Tolentino, Jose Muezo, Antonio Escamilla, and Bernabe Solis.

 

Further and systematic instruction in Western secular music was given in schools for the children of the native elite. In boys’ colleges in the 19th century, music was taught as part of a number of subjects that included philosophy, physics, and metaphysics. At the Universidad de Santo Tomas, Colegio de San Jose, and the Ateneo de Manila, students had the opportunity to take up advanced studies in European arts and sciences. Similarly, young girls, especially after the educational reforms in basic education in 1863, were taught instrumental music, particularly the piano, especially in the girls’ colleges like Colegio de Santa Rosa, Colegio de Santa Isabel, Colegio de la Concordia, and Colegio de Santa Catalina. In addition, other Filipinos got a Western music education beginning in the 1890s from a number of private music academies that were often staffed by successful local or visiting foreign musicians who also gave private lessons in solfége, singing, piano, and violoncello. Notable among them were Spanish musician Oscar Camps y Soler and singers Enrico Capozzi, Santino Coppa, Ciro Cavalieri, and Vincenzo Gambardella. The products of such an education became the admirers of European music as performed by Filipino and visiting European artists. Europeanized in taste and manners, the elite group organized art societies, patronized concerts and operas, or played host to tertulias (soirees) in their homes where poetry and music formed part of the evening fare.

 

The circulation of printed sheet music, thanks to the lithographic print production technology like that introduced in Manila in the middle of the 19th century, could not have generated interest without these educational institutions that ensured the formation of urbane Hispanic colonial subjects who understood and were capable of producing the Western forms and styles of music. Printed sheet music, either for piano solo or for melody with piano accompaniment, was therefore principally marketed to this educated sector in Philippine society. They were the consumers who bought sheet music and other instrumental music collections from stores on Escolta like La Lira Almacen de Musica and La Estrella del Norte.

 

An important music publication of the last half of 19th century was Diego Perez’s piano medley Recuerdos de Filipinas y Sus Cantares (Memories of the Philippines and Its Songs) (1886), which paraphrased Philippine folk songs and dances. By the 1890s, a local print music industry had already produced notable publications such as Julio Nakpil’s piano music in various styles and the ever-popular kundiman “Jocelynang Baliwag” (Jocelyna of Baliwag), which is believed to have circulated in this form in 1896 among the Filipino revolutionaries.

 

Numerous instrumental groups performed actively, particularly in the second half of the 19th century. These included orchestras, bands, comparza, and rondalla. Orchestras in Manila included the San Juan del Monte Orchestra, Oriental Orchestra, Marikina Orchestra, Rizal Orchestra, and Molina Orchestra, and they often had the same members but different conductors. As early as 1885, a musicians’ union, Union Artistica Musical, was already in place, indicating the burgeoning cultural life of Manila. It had in its mandate the code of conduct that stipulated regularized fees for their engagements. Filipino musicians skilled in western idioms found themselves in great demand. Some musicians were contracted in the 1880s to augment the size of the Shanghai Municipal Band. By the end of 19th century, a number were performing in Singapore. Back home, these musicians were members of orchestras that played for solemn masses during church feasts in both Intramuros and the churches in the arrabales (outlying districts) like Quiapo, Santa Cruz, Binondo, San Sebastian, San Miguel, Pandacan, and San Juan del Monte. The orchestras also assisted visiting opera and zarzuela companies, performing the overtures and the intermezzi.

 

From mid-19th century to around the 1930s, a music concert would have presented a mixed program such as the one performed at the Teatro Español de Sibacon in the mid-19th century, which consisted of a sinfonia arranged by Frances Doce Uno; a dance intermission by the best students of Maestro Appiani; a comic skit by Don Ramon Valladores y Saavedra; and two songs in Spanish by a Señora Ojeda. Other program favorites were popular arias by Rossini, Thomas, Auber, and Waldteufel. The performance of a complete symphony or the concept of modern concert programming where large-scale works were presented did not occur until the American period, notably when the Manila Symphony Orchestra began giving concerts in 1926 under the Viennese-trained conductor Alexander Lippay.

 

In the 19th century, Western music was also played by the prestigious regimental bands. Their performances of band music at the Luneta were received with great enthusiasm by the public and praised even by European visitors. As mentioned, almost every town had a brass band outside Manila, with some towns having two or more. The bands participated in town fiesta celebrations, which lasted for three or more days. They started playing in the early morning, marching through all the streets. A major function was to play in processions in which religious images of saints in elaborately decorated carriages were paraded through the major streets of the town.

 

A popular ensemble was the rondalla, a group of plucked or picked stringed instruments made up of a bandurria, piccolo bandurria, laud, octavina, bandola, guitar, and bass. This ensemble was most likely inspired by similar popular music ensembles in Spain from the mid-19th century, though the bandurria itself may have predated this, having reached Philippine shores during the time of the galleon trade with Mexico (1565-1815). Though not as widespread as the brass bands, the rondalla nevertheless enjoyed a certain following. Today, there is a resurgence of interest in the rondalla, and many elementary and high schools have their own groups.

 

A favorite solo instrument from the mid-19th century onwards was the piano. In Manila, pianos by Pleyel Wolff, Steinway and Sons, M.F. Rachals, Grotian Steinway, and Winklemann adorned the spacious living rooms of the rich. Many upright pianos found their way into the smaller towns in Luzon and the Visayas. Visitors to the Philippines in the first half of the 19th century wrote that the piano and the harp were the most common instruments encountered in homes. Almost all young ladies were taught the piano or harp, which they were asked to play to entertain visitors at home.

 

Manila audiences were strongly attracted to opera presentations, particularly those presented by visiting European companies. Eventually, arias from famous operas like Aida, Tosca, La Traviata, Rigoletto, and Lucia di Lammermoor were heard in Philippine households where they were sung, played on the piano, or whistled by both young and old, masters and servants alike. In 1902, the first Filipino opera, Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), was composed by Ladislao Bonus, with libretto in Spanish by Pedro Paterno translated to Tagalog by Roman Reyes. It was followed by two more, Magdapio and Ang Gayuma (Love Potion), with music by Alejo Carluen.

 

The same audience that graced the opera also attended the zarzuela, which were plays with music and dance. The Spanish zarzuela was introduced to the Philippines through the performance of Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire) by the troupe of Dario Cespedes at the Teatro de Novedades in Arroceros, Manila in 1879. Alejandro Cubero, who came to the Philippines in 1880, is credited for having trained native artists such as Jose Carvajal, Venancia Suzara, Patrocinio Tagaroma, and Praxedes Julia Fernandez in the Spanish zarzuela. Eventually, Filipino playwrights wrote the native sarsuwela. Vernacular sarsuwela, the first documented of which was the Tagalog Budhing Nagpahamak (Tragic Conscience), ca 1890, appeared in Pampanga, Cebu, Bicol, Pangasinan, Ilocos, and the Tagalog provinces in the early 1900s.

 

In rural areas, folk dramas which had music flourished even before the advent of the zarzuela and opera. These included the komedya, the sinakulo, and the karilyo. The komedya, a drama in verse which depicted the conflict between Christians and Moors, had entrances, exits, duels, and fight scenes accompanied by music that was made up of stock pieces or music that was popular or in vogue. First performed in open spaces, these stylized dramas eventually made their way to the stages of more formal theaters. In Manila, several theaters specialized in the presentation of the komedya: the Teatro Comico, Teatro Lirico de Tondo, and Teatro de Binondo.

 

The sinakulo, a passion play staged during Holy Week, was performed in town plazas or church patios, attracting an audience that traveled by cart or on foot from outlying barrios. The traditional sinakulo found in Tagalog, Pampango, and Bicol provinces had chanted dialogue and marches performed by local bands. The carillo was introduced to Manila in the latter part of the 19th century by Navarro de Peralta. It was a shadow play using cardboard figures whose shadows were projected by a lamp on a white screen. Deriving its themes from European medieval tales and legends, the carillo was also performed to occasional music.

 

Aside from stage plays, other native musical forms, songs, and dances utilizing European idioms emerged. Some of these forms were the jota, habanera, mazurka, polka, kumintang, balitaw, balse, danza menor, pandanggo, and basultu. The music of these songs and dances were in major and minor tonalities, with simple harmonic progressions and usually in binary form. Triple meter appeared to have been favored over duple and quadruple beat patterns.

 

During the Philippine Revolution of 1896, the marcha and kundiman were used to express the strong patriotic sentiments of the revolutionaries. Of the kundiman, the so-called “Kundiman ng Himagsikan” (Kundiman of the Revolution) or “Jocelynang Baliwag” was the most popular. The steady but stimulating rhythm of marches invigorated the fighting temper of the revolutionaries, while the melancholic funeral marches written for fallen heroes kindled their deep-seated yearning for freedom. The most popular march played during the revolution was “Alerta Katipunan” (Katipunan, Alert), which was originally a Spanish march adapted by the Katipunero for their own use. Moving funeral marches composed by Julio Nakpil were “Pahimakas” (Last Farewell), written for Jose Rizal, and “Sueño Eterno” (Eternal Sleep), a eulogy for Antonio Luna. But Nakpil is most remembered for “Marangal na Dalit ng Katagalugan” (Noble Hymn of the Tagalog Region) which was written upon request of Andres Bonifacio who wanted a national anthem. However, after Bonifacio’s defeat by Emilio Aguinaldo’s cohorts, it was Julian Felipe’s “Marcha Nacional” that eventually became the national anthem.

 

 

 

The American Tradition and Transformations

 

The three centuries of Hispanic musical influence gave way to the colonial ideologies and norms introduced by the Americans from 1901 to 1946. Through the new system of public education established in early 1900s, American teachers introduced the singing of Philippine songs in Western style as well as other hymns and simple tunes from Europe and America—all in English. These songs became known to children all over the archipelago, including areas not reached by the Spanish-period teachers such as the Cordilleras in the north and the Muslim provinces in the south.

 

On the tertiary level, a number of music schools, variously referred to as conservatories or departments of music in colleges, were formally organized such as those of St Scholastica’s College founded in 1906; Centro Escolar de Señoritas, 1907; Silliman University, 1912; Philippine Women’s University, 1925; and Santa Isabel College, which re-opened in 1930. The most comprehensive music institution, however, was the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, which opened in 1916. The proposal for this conservatory was made in 1914 by Senator Joaquin Luna, the brother of the violinist and conductor Manuel Luna, and the scientist and soldier Gen Antonio Luna. Patterned after European conservatories, its curriculum included special studies in piano, music theory, harmony, counterpoint, orchestration, and composition. Gradually, studies in other instruments such as the violin, viola, cello, woodwinds, and brasses were added.

 

These schools produced singers and instrumentalists, some of whom extended their operatic and concert careers to principal cities of Europe and the United States. Among these schools, though, the UP Conservatory of Music produced the most number of composers, many of whom also became leading figures in Philippine music: Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Juan de Sahagun Hernandez, Antonio J. Molina, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonino Buenaventura, Hilarion Rubio, Felipe Padilla de Leon Sr, Lucio San Pedro, and Lucino Sacramento. Comprising the first generation of UP-trained Filipino composers, they wrote music in Western classical forms and idioms. Most of their instrumental works were inspired and influenced by the European romantic literature of Liszt, Schumann, Tchaikovsky, Saint-Saëns, and the works of the nationalist schools in Russia, Bohemia, and Scandinavia. Late 19th-century European music provided models of works with distinctive thematic materials and programmatic character—two elements that served as vehicles for the expression of nationalism.

 

From the 1920s, these UP composers wrote large-scale Western music genres like concertos, sonatas, tone poems, overtures, and symphonies, though the first Filipino to have written a complete symphony in 1928, titled Filipinas, was Jose A. Estella, who belonged to the generation before Abelardo and Santiago. All of them took musical materials from Filipino folk and popular music genres so that their works could all be construed as embodiments of nationalism, the ideology that was dominant at that time, especially among intellectuals of the period in the UP Conservatory of Music. Examples of compositions in classical forms were Abelardo’s Concerto in B-flat Minor, 1923; Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s Sonata for Violin and Piano, 1932; Jose Estella’s Ultimo Adios Symphonic Poem, 1927; Antonino Buenaventura’s Concert Overture, 1930; and Francisco Santiago’s Taga-ilog Symphony, 1938. Even Alexander Lippay, the Viennese-trained director of the said institution between 1925 and 1930, appropriated local materials in his symphonic variations in the late 1920s that were performed by the Manila Symphony Orchestra. But most significant during this period was the elevation of local genres into an art form, as exemplified by the kundiman. Familiar with both the art music of Europe and the folk music of the Philippines, Abelardo and Santiago carefully wedded music and words, in effect creating a refined music composition that qualified as an artistic expression known as the art song kundiman. Performed by such artists as Jovita Fuentes, a soprano whose career in the 1920s caught the attention of major European opera composers, these works became part of the national repertoire.

 

In the field of research, nationalism compelled historicism and motivated Raymundo Bañas and scholar Alfredo Roa to document Philippine music history, while Norberto Romualdez published his important book on organology and the classification of vocal music, Filipino Musical Instruments and Airs of Long Ago. During the school summer breaks of the early 1930s, field research documentations of Philippine folk dances were undertaken by Francisca Reyes-Tolentino, Antonino Buenaventura, and Ramon Tolentino. The materials were later published and circulated as textbooks for use in physical education classes in the schools. Reyes-Tolentino’s books of dances, including the accompanying music recorded in the field by Buenaventura as well as his own compositions for some dances became canonic in the ensuing decades.

 

Outside the academe, the American colonial period was mainly characterized by the rapid ascendance of popular culture, which, it must be emphasized, had already been on the rise during the last quarter of the 19th century as a result of increasing world trade. As has already been noted, the popularization of Philippine folk music was made possible by the lithographic technology begun in late 1850s, catering to the few colonialists and literate criollos and mestizos living in urban areas. The production of sheet music continued in the American period and accelerated when a new generation of American-educated Filipino composers such as Nicanor S. Abelardo and Francisco Santiago published their kundiman and danza. Another printed kundiman, Constancio de Guzman’s “Bayan Ko” (My Country), has become the most famous Filipino song of all time after the national anthem. Popularized by sarsuwela star Atang de la Rama, the song has been sung at rallies by workers and peasants. Aside from sheet music, the mechanical reproduction technology that produced audio recordings helped popularize Philippine music during the American period. Business enterprises with investments from French company Pathe, then American Victor and Columbia, and later German Odeon, recorded then sold Philippine music, whether folk songs, art songs, or songs from the sarsuwela, as commodities.

 

During the American colonial period, the semiclassical traditions consisted of music for theater, particularly from the sarsuwela, together with folk songs, rondalla music, and band music. Composers appropriated western music conventions to write for genres that were unique to the Philippines. Fulgencio Tolentino and Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1902; Jose Estella and Severino Reyes’s Filipinas para los Filipinos (The Philippines for the Filipinos), 1905; and Leon Ignacio and Hermogenes Ilagan’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919, represent the popularity of sarsuwela in the first decade of the 1900s. With the screening of the first Filipino sound film in 1933, the establishment of the major film studios from 1933 onwards, and the rise of bodabil in the 1920s, the sarsuwela began to lose its audience in the theaters. Coopting the form, Filipino film producers now either adapted the existing popular sarsuwela to film (i.e., filmed sarsuwela) in productions such as Jose Nepomuceno’s Dalagang Bukid or commissioned sarsuwela originally created for film (i.e., sarsuwela films) such as Carlos Vander Tolosa’s Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939, with music by Juan Silos Jr and Ariston Avelino.

 

At this time, the research and popularization of traditional folk songs in the native languages was in vogue. Norberto Romualdez reprinted folk songs such as “Comintang de la Conquista” (Comintang of the Conquest) and “Cachucha” in the Progressive Music Series anthology used in most schools. The proliferation of rondalla groups prompted the creation of many adaptations of folk songs such as “Lawiswis Kawayan” (Sounds of Bamboo) and “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly). Band music came in many forms such as overtures and marches. Examples of works for band were Pedro Navarro’s “Olimpia,” 1925, and Antonio Escamilla’s “Philippine Airs,” 1927.

 

With the sales of another American consumer item— the radio—in the 1930s, American jazz and Tin Pan Alley songs were heard alongside local Filipino music which refused to surrender to American cultural domination. This American popular music eventually shaped the production and broadcast of Filipino popular music, which later became the preferred music of the Filipino masses. Early radio hits included “Singing in the Rain,” “It’s Magic,” and “Boulevard of Broken Dreams.” Much of the aired music consisted of recordings of Filipino singers such as Katy de la Cruz and Bimbo Danao singing American-style pop music and the songs were sometimes performed live in the studio, accompanied by radio orchestras such as the Lux Orchestra. Some of these orchestras were organized for radio stations like KZEG, KZIB, and KZRM.

 

Meanwhile, live entertainment bodabil, the local rendering of vaudeville—a variety show that included American or American-inspired pop songs, dances, comedy skits, and even circus acts—offered an alternative to sarsuwela and formal concerts of classical music. Bodabil was performed in theaters like the Manila Grand Opera and later, the Metropolitan Theater. In 1921, the first bodabil company was established by “Borromeo Lou” (Luis Borromeo), an entertainer who had seen such groups in the United States. Bodabil competed with dance halls like cabarets, where bigger live orchestras directed by highly skilled Filipino musicians found work. It featured dances in styles such as the fox-trot, swing, charleston, cakewalk, and tango. Foreign and local songs were also presented in productions and skits with titles like “April Showers,” “Blue Hawaii,” and “Magandang Juaning” (Beautiful Juaning). Juan Silos Jr continued to propagate Filipino rondalla music, with his daughters (aka the SSS Trio) singing arranged folk songs, while Katy de la Cruz sang bodabil songs like “Balut” (Duck Egg). Light classical composers like Manuel Velez and Santiago Suarez composed their balitaw and danza for this theatrical form.

 

In a brief yet sudden reversal of fate, American domination would be drastically erased in favor of an anti-Western rhetoric from 1942 to 1945—a four-year period known popularly as the “Japanese Occupation.” Propagandistic songs commissioned by the Japanese military government, such as “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Filipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines) by Felipe Padilla de Leon Jr, were composed and performed in public, alongside Japanese nationalistic hymns such as “Nippon Zyunkyosya no Uta” (Hymn of Japanese Martyrdom) and “Umi Yukada” (Yukada Sea). Public entertainment was censored, and only shows that did not carry associations with American culture were allowed. Despite the enforced Japanese cultural, political, and economic agendas, Japanese occupation in the country did not leave a lasting effect on Filipino culture, for after the country was “liberated” from the Asian aggressors, the Filipinos returned to their preferred music.

 

 

 

The Period of the Republics

 

After World War II, the third Philippine republic witnessed a period of national and cultural reconstruction. The capitalist political economic structure specially favoring the country’s colonial master, the United States, and the usual rule of the few were reestablished. It was the resumption of the social clout of the few property-owning ruling class that was contested by the underground peasant movement, which believed in a socialist vision of property relations, and this set the stage for the burgeoning of protest songs in the 1950s. There was a resurgence in the singing of these as well as newer protest songs in the 1970s and 1980s with the student activist movement and the reestablishment of the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) in 1968.

 

The middle and upper classes who were allied to the United States upheld the status quo both politically and culturally. In the realm of classical music, many composers of the period continued to compose and perform western-type forms. The audiences for concertos, symphonic poems, and suites thrived in the 1950s. Classical music stood firm as a symbol of stability and marked the return to the old system of social hierarchy. In this decade, active concertizing was done by the Manila Symphony Orchestra under the Jewish-American conductor Herbert Zipper, and by middle class Filipino conductors like Ramon Tapales, Luis Valencia, and Redentor Romero, the last two of whom would perform well into the 1980s. Noted classical musicians of the period were pianists Nena del Rosario, Regalado Jose, Benjamin Tupas, and Reynaldo Reyes; singers Fides Cuyugan, Aurelio Estanislao, Irma Potenciano, and Luisa “Isang” Tapales; and instrumentalists such as Sergio Esmilla, Oscar Yatco, Carmencita Lozada, and Basilio Manalo.

 

In 1955, four important national music organizations were put up. These were the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines, a grant-giving government agency in support of artists headed by Jovita Fuentes; the Philippine Music Educators Group with Eliseo Pajaro as chair; the National Band Association led by Felipe de Leon Sr; and the League of Filipino Composers. The last organization underscored the importance of developing a Filipino classical repertoire.

 

Some representative works of composers during this period were Rosalina Abejo’s Pagtubos (Redemption), oratorio, and Thanatopsis, symphony; Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Itim Asu (The Black She-wolf), music for ballet, and Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), opera; Antonino Buenaventura’s By the Hillside, tone poem, and Woodwind Quintet; Rodolfo Cornejo’s Piano Concerto with Orchestra and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), music for ballet; Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s Toccata for Percussion and Winds and Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot); Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Manila Sketches for Orchestra, and the operas Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion); Antonio J. Molina’s songs and choral cycles Missa Antonina and Bontok Rhapsody for String Quartet; Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom), opera, and Mir-i-nisa, music for ballet; Hilarion F. Rubio’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), overture, and To the Filipino Youth, cantata; Lucino T. Sacramento’s Philippine Vistas for Orchestra and Violin Concerto in E minor; Lucio D. San Pedro’s Violin Concerto in D Minor and Transfiguration of Christ, symphonic poem; Rosendo Santos’s Lakeside Suite for Orchestra and Mass for Saint Paul; and Ramon Tapales’s Ave Liberator for chorus, and Messa in Stile Antico, mass. A number of these compositions won the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, which was then the main form of recognizing Filipino creativity in the field of music from the 1950s to the 1960s.

 

Idiomatically, these compositions were written in the tonal language of the late 19th-century European classical music, in different degrees of sophistication. Modern methods of composition, however, were also formally adopted in the works of those who studied abroad in the 1950s and 1960s, many of them under American government scholarships. American neoclassicism strongly influenced the music of Eliseo M. Pajaro and Lucrecia R. Kasilag, while the French avant-garde movement provided Jose Maceda structural models by which to realize new concepts derived from non-Western musical traditions.

 

Jose Maceda, who was a concert pianist before World War II, turned maverick in the 1950s to begin his career as an ethnomusicologist. He published his analysis of Sagada songs, collaborated with eminent American anthropologist Harold Conklin from Yale University in studying Hanunuo Mangyan music, and ended up doing fieldwork on a dissertation on Maguindanaon music in 1963. Maceda is considered the “Father of Musicology” in the Philippines, for the kind of empirical knowledge he produced on Philippine music was unprecedented at the national level as he explored both indigenous and acculturated Philippine music. An offshoot of his research was the institutionalization of courses on indigenous music at the Department of Asian Music, with Maguindanaon kulintang artist Aga Mayo Butocan teaching kulintang music at UP, later followed by Ben Pangosban, a Kalinga. The next generation of Filipino composers like Ramon P. Santos and Francisco F. Feliciano were heavily influenced by Maceda’s vision and philosophy of music education.

 

In 1958, the Bayanihan Folkloric Dance Company, with Kasilag as music consultant and director, began the very successful world tours that so impressed audiences worldwide and started the trend for “staged” folkloric dance and music among foreigners and diasporic Filipinos. Bayanihan’s achievement paralleled that of the University of the Philippines Madrigal Singers (PMS), founded by Andrea Veneracion in the early 1960s, whose impact in the quality of choral music performance among non-church based choirs in the country was unprecedented. PMS was known for its imaginative arrangements of Philippine folk, art, and pop songs.

 

The 1966 Music Education Law, which required the teaching of music in public schools, contributed to the popularization and institutionalization of many folk and art songs. Semi-classical music also got a boost with the establishment of the most important music recording company in the 1950s and 1960s: the Mabuhay Recording Company (MARECO), later renamed Villar Records. This company played a most important role in disseminating Philippine music nationwide. Not only did it record kundiman, balitaw, and danza genres that were already well circulated pre-World War II, but it also showcased local singers such as Sylvia La Torre, Cely Bautista, the Tres Rosas trio, and Ruben Tagalog. These singers recorded and popularized many important songs from earlier composers like Jose Estella’s “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow), Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “Bituing Marikit” (Beautiful Star) and “Nasaan Ka, Irog?” (Where are You, My Love?), Francisco Santiago’s “Pakiusap” (Plea) and “Madaling Araw” (Dawn), Santiago Suarez’s “Bakya Mo, Neneng” (Your Wooden Shoes, Neneng), and Constancio de Guzman’s “Maalaala Mo Kaya?” (Will You Remember?) and “Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig” (My Only Love) for the younger generation.

 

Semiclassical works which cover music written for bands, rondallas, and other instrumental groupings highlighted the folk song genre as a symbol of nationalism in the third Philippine Republic. Many marches for bands were written such as Felipe de Leon’s “Martsa ng Republika ng Pilipinas” (March of the Republic of the Philippines), 1948; and Lucio San Pedro’s “Festival March,” 1969. Other band music such as concert overtures, tone poems, and symphonies also abound, such as Eduardo Parungao’s Suite for Band, 1960, and Hilarion Rubio’s Three Kings Overture, 1970. Juan Silos’s rondalla propagated the arrangement, performance, and recording of folk songs and dances such as Eliseo Pajaro’s Himig Pilipino No. 1, 1956, and Philippine Medley, 1959. These were widely disseminated throughout the archipelago and used by public schools in their Physical Education classes. Leopoldo Silos and his orchestra played light classical arrangements, which resonated with the style of movie music of the period.

 

Original Filipino ballads in semiclassical style—aka middle-of-the-road songs—written by composers such as Miguel Velarde, Josefino Cenizal, Manuel Velez, Minggoy Lopez, and Antonio Maiquez were sung by singers such as Diomedes Maturan, Pilita Corrales, Ric Manrique, and the Mabuhay Singers. A few of the songs written in this style are “A Million Thanks to You,” “Eternally Yours,” and “Dedicated to You.” Some of the singers were discovered in amateur singing contests that were so popular in the late 1950s like Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). Nora Aunor, who hailed from Bicol, gained entry into the world of urban glamour through this song contest.

 

Owing to its roots in romantic Filipino music theater and film, the sound of Filipino semiclassical and popular music from the 1950s to 1960s was generally lyrical, tender, and suave. But some had begun to be influenced by Latin music of the 1950s that had spicy African rhythms like rhumba, mambo, and cha-cha, introduced through records, radio, film, or television. Groups called cumbancheros played Latin music in the 1950s using improvised instruments made out of gasoline, cooking oil, and biscuit tin cans referred to as combos by the time of The Beatles. Later in the 1960s, the same media targeted youth cultures around the world, and this time, rock ‘n’ roll was the hip thing that drew young people to buy into the images of industry’s stars.

 

Through radio, television, cinema, and the recording industry, Filipinos were inundated with the latest songs and dances from the United States in the 1950s and 1960s. It was also during this time that foreign music was sung by Filipino performers who excelled in mimicry. The proclivity of the Filipinos to imitate and assimilate foreign music was more pronounced in the field of popular entertainment music, prompting cultural theorist Arjun Appadurai to comment that Filipino music mimicries even surpassed their originals. Filipino counterparts of singing idols Nat King Cole, Perry Como, Elvis Presley, Johnny Mathis, Connie Francis, Doris Day, Timi Yuro, and Tom Jones proliferated and were commercially promoted on the airwaves and on TV. Plakang-plaka or the ability to duplicate a foreign singer’s voice, enunciation, and general singing style became a compliment for such singers. Some musicians who had very good ears for imitating found their way into jazz bands and combos of the hotels and nightclubs in Manila and other Asian cities like Tokyo, Taipei, Singapore, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Bangkok, and Jakarta, and later, in the Middle East and Europe.

 

This period also saw the proliferation of American-influenced Filipino pop music as heard in “Waray-Waray” (a person from Samar or Leyte), which had blues chords; “Hahabol-habol” (Chasing After), which was in rock ‘n’ roll style; and “Pitong Gatang” (a street in the notorious Tondo district of Manila), which was in country and Western style. At the same time, foreign band music invaded and inundated the country with groups such as The Ventures, The Beatles, and the Rolling Stones. During this period, the American electric guitar, British amplifier, and trap drum set were the favored instruments. The repertoire of musicians and amateur groups in the provinces were mostly cover versions of anything that was fashionable, but notable was the rise of Filipino rock bands doing both foreign and local music, such as RJ and the Riots and the Juan de La Cruz Band.

 

The declaration of martial law by Ferdinand E. Marcos ushered in the fourth Philippine Republic, which lasted from 1972 to 1986. The main thrust of Marcos’s New Society was to nationalize Philippine industries, including music. This thrust was reflected in the centralization of music cultural production via the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), which was built in 1969. Through President Marcos’s wife, Imelda, CCP acquired unsurpassed glamor and glory, albeit at the expense of silencing the majority of artists from the grassroots cultures. Support for certain arts and artists was lavish and could only be described as “Imeldific.” Imelda was criticized for spending a lot of money on the American pianist Clifford van Cliburn and ballet dancer Margot Fonteyn. A few resident companies in dance, music, and theater were instituted and were favored with grants and the use of the new CCP venues. The undemocratic process discouraged local artists from participation and drew criticism, especially among the intellectuals and artists from UP, many of whom were tortured and incarcerated by the regime.

 

Classical works that came out during this period include compositions specifically written for the Marcoses such as Lucino Sacramento’s two concertos for piano and orchestra Ang Maharlika (The Nobility), 1973, and Ang Bituin (The Star), 1974, obviously dedicated to Ferdinand and Imelda; and Rodolfo de Leon’s musical setting of the regime’s slogan, “Isang Bansa, Isang Diwa” (One Country, One Spirit), 1974. Other composers continued to write in the classical tradition, dramatically influenced by new compositional techniques developed in the West. Ramon Santos’s Suite for Flute, Clarinet, Viola, Cello, and Piano and Four Movements for chamber orchestra, and Francisco Feliciano’s Fragments and Die Verklärung Christi (Transfiguration) for large orchestra were written in atonal language. Experimentations were also prominent, as seen in Chino Toledo’s Ugnay (Link) and Kulambo: Isang Kayumangging Puntod (Mosquito Net: A Brown Grave), and Verne de la Peña’s N(y)uma for 36 Voices and Asian Instruments.

 

Focused as it were on “highbrow” music, CCP did not sufficiently nurture semiclassical music such as the music of the rondalla and the band, the former only finding a new source of material in modern compositions by Bayani Mendoza de Leon and Jerry Dadap, and the latter finding a performance venue in the weekly concerts at Luneta. Concerts at the Park and later concerts in heritage sites like Puerta Real in Intramuros and Paco Park received funding from the government to broadcast over national TV. A look into the content of these aired broadcasts would reveal that classical music lorded it over semiclassical music, again reflecting the elitist priorities of the Marcos administration.

 

The few musical productions for theater, rondalla, and band music during the Marcos administration included the restaging of old sarsuwela such as Walang Sugat and Ana Maria, and the staging of new ones such as Reynaldo Paguio’s Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow), 1976, and Miss Philippines, 1980. Others wrote sarsuwela that were mainly anti-martial law and anti-Marcos such as Amelia Lapeña-Bonfacio and Fabian Obispo who penned Ang Bundok (The Mountain), 1977, and Nicanor Tiongson, Lutgardo Labad, Louie Pascasio, and Lucien Letaba with their Pilipinas Circa 1907, 1982. Foreign musicals were also frequently presented in the capital such as Jesus Christ Superstar and Godspell. New music for rondalla and band were anthems and marches labeled as New Society songs such as “Bagong Lipunan” (Hymn of the New Society), “Bagong Pagsilang” (March of the New Society), and “Magtanim, Magtanim” (Plant).

 

Critical thinkers and artists from the academe, many of whom were influenced by the ideology of the democratic Left, strongly reacted against Marcos’s authoritarian rule and the abuses of the military. There was an abundance of protest songs coming from Heber Bartolome and Banyuhay, Jess Santiago, Inang Laya, and Patatag who expressed their sentiments through songs such as “Sino Ang Manggagawa” (Who are the Workers) by Rody Vera of Patatag and “Butil ng Palay” (Grain of Rice) by Jess Santiago and Inang Laya. Similarly, theater productions of the Philippine Educational Theater (PETA), like the rock musical Nukleyar I and II, 1981 and 1985, respectively, and Macli-ing, 1988, were a condemnation of military rule.

 

The music industry also underwent Filipinization in the 1970s and 1980s. The association of broadcasters, Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP), adopted the policy passed by the Broadcast Media Council (BMC) of airing Filipino pop music every hour, while annual pop music competitions like the Metro Manila Pop Music Festival led to more new songs being written by Filipino songwriters. Filipinization of popular music was realized first through the vernacularization of the texts and the use of soft rock accompaniment in what was labeled as Manila Sound, and later in the production of original compositions that were to be subsumed under the umbrella term OPM (Original Pilipino Music). The styles generally remained faithful to or were somehow influenced by their foreign models—i.e., country western, Broadway rock, punk rock, heavy metal, folk, and rap. Particularly influential was the American music industry’s Top 40 chart, which popularized the music of Elvis Presley, Bob Dylan, the Bee Gees, the Village People, and Karen Carpenter, among others. A long string of names that topped the charts in Filipino pop music included Ryan Cayabyab, Willy Cruz, Hotdog, Apo Hiking Society, Heber Bartolome, Freddie Aguilar, Maria Cafra, Mike Hanopol, and Yoyoy Villame, with songs such as “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You are the Miss Universe of my Life) “Sana’y Wala nang Wakas” (May It Never End), “Laki sa Layaw” (Spoiled Brat), “Ngayon at Kailanman” (Now and Forever), and the biggest hit of all, “Anak” (Child).

 

In Aug 1983, the murder of exiled senator Benigno Aquino Jr on the airport tarmac at the hands of the military presaged the end of the decades-old dictatorship of the Marcoses. Discontent with the government escalated and culminated in the botched national election that then brought about the bloodless EDSA Revolt in Feb 1986. This peaceful revolt led Jim Paredes, a member of the APO Hiking Society, to write the song “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo” (Filipino Offering to the World), inspiring people around the world to overthrow monolithic governments through non-violent means.

 

When the wife of Sen Aquino, Cory Aquino, took office as the President of the fifth Philippine Republic, Filipino artists representing different art forms came together to craft new policies in culture that would be more democratic. The result of this was the creation of the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts, 1987, which became the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) in 1992. The commission’s establishment ushered in a new era in the management and promotion of Philippine music and arts in which non-governmental art agencies were encouraged to participate. The NCCA, which became the coordinating organization for all affiliated government cultural agencies, implemented its grants assistance program for the development, protection, preservation, and dissemination of Philippine culture and arts.

 

With the new leadership, the CCP reoriented its thrusts and programs. The five new directions of the post-Marcos CCP were Filipinization, democratization, decentralization, promotion of artistic excellence, and reorientation of international exchanges. An important component of the Filipinization goal of the CCP was to present outstanding Filipino musicians through the Filipino Artists Series launched in 1987 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino (formerly Little Theater), and to give grants to different music groups. To push for democratization, the CCP outreach program brought Manila artists such as Inang Laya and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra to the regions and regional artists such as Sining Kambayoka and Joey Ayala to Manila and to other provinces as well. In support of decentralization, the CCP organized artists in regional centers such as Cebu, Iloilo, Bacolod, and Davao so that they could contribute to the creation of original works from their region and thus enrich the national culture from the grassroots. To promote artistic excellence, the CCP emphasized the highest standards of excellence and encouraged artists to be rooted in their traditions but at the same time be open to the best of world cultures.

 

It is significant that during this period, patronage of the arts was no longer the exclusive purview of CCP as in the Marcos period, but was extended to corporations who built venues in Makati and Alabang, among other places, and supported symphonic organizations as part of their corporate responsibility. San Miguel Corporation’s sponsorship of an orchestra (now defunct), directed by Ryan Cayabyab is the best example. Without San Miguel, Cayabyab could not have composed his cheerful orchestrations of folk songs that sounded Bernstein-like and yet Filipino at the same time. Meanwhile, the Manila Symphony Orchestra was revived under Basilio Manalo’s leadership. Throughout its history, this orchestra was supported by well-endowed citizens like the Legarda family. Other orchestras of this period are the Metro Manila Community Orchestra (now renamed Metro Manila Concert Orchestra) led by Josefino “Chino” Toledo and Manila Philharmonic Orchestra, led by Rodel Colmenar, which is organized like a musician’s union and run independently by musicians themselves. Some orchestras, like the ABS-CBN Orchestra, directed by Gerard Salonga, is a pop orchestra, specializing in light Philippine orchestra music and at the same time supplying works for the multinational media conglomerate.

 

Composers during this period continued to write in the classical Western tradition, with strong inclination toward experimentation marking the contemporariness and social relevance of their creations. On the traditional side were Antonino Buenaventura’s Concerto for French Horn and Orchestra, 1987; and Lucrecia Kasilag’s Violin Concerto No. 2, 1994. Examples of the dominant style focusing on experimental sonic combinations include Ramon Santos’s Time Space, for two orchestras, 1990; Jose Maceda’s Music for a Chamber Orchestra, 1997; Jonas Baes’s Patangis-Buwaya (Cry of the Crocodile), 2003; and Chino Toledo’s Hoy! (Hey!), 2004.

 

Music for dance theater showcased ballets such as Joey Ayala’s Encantada as choreographed by Agnes Locsin, who introduced neo-ethnic dance movements which lent a unique Philippine flavor to contemporary ballet. Another collaborative work of Locsin and Ayala was Sayaw LikhANG KIUKOK, Atbp. Meanwhile, Fabian Obispo did the music for Denisa Reyes’s For the Gods, 1988, and Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1988.

 

Theatrical productions have also experienced enormous growth as new and old theater companies present newly composed operas, sarsuwelas, and musicals. Examples of these productions are Ryan Cayabyab and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio’s opera Spoliarium, 2003; and Chino Toledo and Virgilio Almario’s Andres B, 2014. New sarsuwelas created during the Philippine centennial celebrations of 1998-99 included Mario O’Hara and Minda Azarcon’s Palasyo ni Valentin (Palace of Valentin), Bienvenido Lumbera and Lucien Letaba’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plaint and Rebellion of Victoria Laktaw and Others), George de Jesus III and Jesse Lucas’s Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom), and Melba Maggay and Lucio San Pedro’s Bayan Ko, Isang Paa na Lang (My Country, Just One Step More).

 

New musicals are exemplified by Ryan Cayabyab’s Katy! The Musical, 1988, with Jose Javier Reyes; Nick Joaquin’s Larawan (Portrait), 1997, with Rolando Tinio; and Alikabok (Dust), 1995, with Noel Balmaceda. Vincent de Jesus composed the music for Walang Himala (No Miracle), 2003, with a libretto by Ricardo Lee; Skin Deep, 2008, which he also wrote; and Care Divas, 2011, with a libretto by Liza Magtoto. Floy Quintos’s ...And St Louis Loves Dem Filipinos became a musical in 2005, with music by Antonio Paterno Africa. In 2013, Nick Pichay adapted the film Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros) into Maxie: The Musicale, with music by William Manzano, JJ Pimpinio, and Janine Santos. In 2013, Carol Bello composed the music for Rody Vera’s Ibalong. In 2014, the music of Aegis was used for Liza Magtoto’s libretto of Rak of Aegis, which is now one of the longest running musicals in the country. In 2015, Jed Balsamo composed the music for Nicanor Tiongson’s Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior) and Jomar Fleras’s Kanser@35 (Cancer@35).

 

Brass bands continue to thrive with the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas, Inc. (PASAMBAP, Inc.) leading the herd. The compositions of Lucio San Pedro have been among the staple repertoire of brass bands in Rizal, Pandacan, and Cavite, and these include Victory on Parade March and Festival March. Similarly, the proliferation of rondalla groups has been attributable to the efforts of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and Musicological Society of the Philippines’ Kuwerdas ng Pagkakaisa: International Rondalla Festival under the leadership of Ramon P. Santos. Among the new musical works written for rondalla are Ma. Christine Muyco’s PagpiPiko (Playing Hopscotch), Christi-Anne Castro’s Gabi ng mga Aswang (Night of the Evil Spirits), and Nelson Espejo’s Minsan sa Isang Taon (Once A Year).

 

Popular music comes in a variety of forms—ballads, novelty songs, folk songs, rock, jazz fusion, rap, and alternative music. The establishment of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM) in the late 1980s contributed to the development of the pop music industry. Many of the songs which became popular were also winning compositions in pop music festivals, examples of which are “Sometimes You Just Know” by Danny Tan, Makko Pals, and Edith Gallardo, “Shine” by Trina Belamide, and “Malayo Man, Malapit Din” (Even if it’s Far, It’s Also Near) by Bayang Barrios. Competitions abroad also contributed to the popularity of winning songs such as Danny Tan’s “Easy to Love You,” and Ryan Cayabyab’s “Paraiso” (Paradise). Novelty songs celebrating the humorous side of Filipino character provided a marketable variation of popular music, examples of which are “Spaghetti” by the Sex Bomb Girls, “Papa Cologne” (Father Cologne) by Parokya ni Edgar, and “Otso Otso” (Move Like Number Eight) by Bayani Agbayani.

 

The success of commercial music is evidenced by the rise of alternative rock from the 1980s to the present. The Dawn, Eraserheads, Parokya ni Edgar, and later Gloc-9, whose works are as much local as they are global, continued the legacy of the first wave of local rock in the 1970s. A few of the rock hits have been the Eraserheads’s “Ang Huling El Bimbo” (The Last El Bimbo), Kamikazee’s “Narda,” and Aegis’s “Halik” (Kiss). Pinoy rap also became a commercial success. “Mga Kababayan Ko” (My Countrymen) by Francis M. is perhaps the most popular Filipino rap song of all time. Andrew E.’s hits include “Humanap Ka ng Pangit” (Look for an Ugly One), and “Huwag Kang Gamol” (Don’t be an Ass). Present-day original Filipino rap music conveys a tenderness characteristic of Filipinos, which departs from the more edgy and confrontational rap of the youth crews in New York.

 

Popular music continues to enjoy mass appreciation and support especially with the advent of new distribution technologies. In the late 1980s, the distribution mechanism was primarily through television, radio, and film. As the technological revolution of the last years of the 20th century reached the Philippines, the dissemination of pop music accelerated and intensified and now, the flow of media and information via interactive telecommunications technology has inspired more independence in the creation of original works, and this is also manifest in art forms like film and literature. In the field of music, the rise of sound art is a perfect example of how international influences reach local shores—via on-off telepresencing in social media and not through the usual channels of formal music education. The use of contemporary music technology is being done in schools like the College of St Benilde of La Salle that has been specializing in digital music media production.

 

Epilogue

 

In contemporary Philippines, three kinds of music—old aboriginal Asian music, religious and secular music patterned after Hispanic and European forms, and American/European-inspired classical, semiclassical, and popular music—stand side by side, offering Filipino artists a wealth of options and possibilities. Given all these contexts and the many musical forms and styles that continue to be unearthed by researchers, the musical artists of today continue to discover many alternative concepts, values, and perspectives as they endeavor to create music that will express the history and way of life of the Filipino and display an unmistakable national character.  Written by Jose M. Maceda, Corazon C. Dioquino, and Ramon P. Santos, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo and Arwin Q. Tan, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson
