text:
Sections

Background
The Musical Instruments
The Vocal Genres
Styles, Concepts, and Structures
Epilogue

Sources

 

 

Although a majority of Philippine music traditions has been largely shaped by Western concepts and beliefs introduced since the Spanish colonial period, musical practices linking the country to pre-European Southeast Asian cultures remain alive. Today, indigenous vocal and instrumental music and dances are perpetuated by linguistic groups that comprise some 14-17% of the total population of 100 million Filipinos (National Statistics Office 2014).

 

Background

 

Philippine musical traditions are diverse. Although they have common instruments and life cycle functions, these vary considerably in form and structure, performance media, style, aesthetics, and theories such as tuning temperaments, scales, modes, and terminologies. Such cultural pluralism is the result of prehistorical periods of human interaction and exchanges in the region. Currently accepted Austronesian dispersal theories propose sequential migrations from Taiwan to the Philippines beginning ca 4,500 to 4,000 years ago (Bellwood 1997). There is archeological evidence that point to “considerable maritime interaction” in Island Southeast Asia even before the appearance of Austronesian languages (Donohue and Denham 2010, 223). Subsequent migrations within the larger Southeast Asian region gave rise to many separate regional settlements and extended family communities, with their own laws and customs, animist religious beliefs and practices, and distinct artistic expressions (Patanne 1977, 85-9).

 

By the 10th century, there was dynamic trade between the people of Ma-i (now Mindoro) and Chinese, Malay, Indonesian, and Arab merchants. They exchanged not only goods but also religious and social ideas. Hinduism and other elements of Indian culture, for example, reached the Philippines via Indonesia and other Southeast Asian countries, leaving strong imprints on religious concepts, patterns of social behavior, manner of dressing, and artifacts, and a Sanskrit-influenced system of writing (Churchill 1977; Nicolas 2007).

 

In the 14th century and perhaps even earlier, Islam was introduced in the southernmost island of Sulu. The new religion was adopted by various communities at different times and under different conditions and levels of assimilation. Thus, pre-Islamic practices were retained by the native converts while Islamic art forms enriched the indigenous arts.

 

Spain ruled the Philippines from 1565 to 1898, conquering the islands primarily by converting inhabitants to Christianity, especially those who belonged to the eight biggest lowland ethnolinguistic groups. The friars taught the people not only how to recite the Christian prayers and speak a new language, but also how to read music, sing European songs, and play European instruments. Just the same, even the Spanish conquest could not eradicate indigenous musical traditions and instruments, which survived and even assimilated Christian elements.

 

The long history of cultural assimilation shaped the highly varied Philippine cultural profile. The numerous ethnic and language groups with orally transmitted cultural practices may be categorized into six clusters based on history, geography, topography, kinship of artistic forms, material culture, and social structures: the Cordillera highland cultures and outlying communities, consisting of the ethnolinguistic groups of the Apayao or Isneg, Applay, Bago, Bontok, Balangao Gaddang, Ibaloy, Ifugao, Bugkalot (Ilongot), Kalinga, Kankanaey, and Tinguian; the central west highland cultures of the Alangan, Batak, Buhid, Hanunuo, Iraya, Palawan, Tagbanwa, Magahat, and Sulod; the Mindanao highland cultures of the Bagobo, Blaan, Kalagan, Mandaya, Mansaka, Manobo, Matigsalug, Subanon, and Tboli; the Aeta communities represented by groups like the Ati, Agta, Abyan, Dumagat, and Kabihug; the Islamic communities of the Sama Dilaut, Ilanun, Jama Mapun, Maguindanao, Maranao, Sama, Sangil, Tausug, and Yakan; and the rural Christian communities, including the Ilocano, Ibanag, Pangasinan, Pampango, Tagalog, Bikol, Cuyunon, Aklanon, Kinaray-a, Ilonggo, Cebuano, and Waray.

 

Many communities in the fifth group were converted to Islam. Although the last few groups are more integrated into the lowland political and economic mainstream, some of their indigenous musical traditions are still widely practiced, especially those that have found areas of accommodation with dominant religious and social norms. Practices of animist provenance still exist, although not as widely as before (Hislop 1971, 144-55). Music marks rites of passage and life cycle events such as birth, initiation, courtship, wedding, death; seasonal events such as planting, harvest; religious-cycle events; and other special occasions such as thanksgiving, war, peace pacts, and anniversaries. Music that accompanied extinct practices such as tribal wars and headhunting have either disappeared or are performed now but in new contexts.

 

In lowland community celebrations, group instrumental playing is common, as are dancing, welcome chants, panegyrics, laments, epics, ballads, allegorical songs, and extemporized poetry. Solo instrumental playing is done at intimate, informal gatherings, for courting or for self-amusement while the player watches over the fields, for example.

 

The Islamic cultures are mostly found in the coastal and lowland areas of western Mindanao. Their musical traditions are generally pre-Islamic, integrating folk culture and court music dating back to the 10th century or earlier. Despite the fundamental Islamic view that frowns on music, the musical practices of these communities remain an important element in their social life and one of the chief sources of their ethnic identities. Moreover, the musical traditions of earlier Islamic peoples, such as Arabs and Persians, and the modes of rendition of religious literature, have enriched the musical life of Filipino Muslims.

 

The distance of rural Christian communities from cities was significant in their cultural development. Western ideas did not come in a constant stream but were filtered and modified. Although many communal activities were replaced by Christian-oriented or Christian-derived forms of social practice, particularly those related to the Christian liturgical calendar, aspects of pre-Christian culture remained. Varying degrees of acculturation and a syncretic blend of Western and non-Western ideas are still evident in their musical practices.

 

 

Indigenous music of Asiatic provenance may be classified into three categories in relation to social context. First is the function-specific music performed only on specific occasions such as the Kalinga dopdopit for the first bathing of a child outside the house, the Yakan kwintangan kayu for the growth of rice seedlings, and the Ifugao bangibang for revenge for a person’s untimely death. The pasyon for the Lenten pabasa also falls under this category. Second is music that may be performed on similar occasions, usually identified by melody or rhythm or both, such as the Maguindanao tagunggo, a rhythmic mode played only for solemn activities, or the Ibaloy ba-diw and Maranao bayok, both sung with extemporized texts modified to fit the event (Figure 1). The third category is music that may be performed anytime for any occasion, consisting of folk songs, epics, narrative and allegorical ballads, and musical theater.

 

 

 

Traditional music activities relate to the social status, age, and gender of the performers. Rituals are usually reserved for priests and shamans. Elders and community leaders sing greeting songs and songs of wisdom and advice such as as the Ibaloy ba-diw and the Ilocano dallot. Some instruments are usually played by women, such as the Maranao kulintang and Bagobo saluray, and those played by men are the Maguindanao kudyapi, Ibaloy sulibao, and Kalinga gangsa pattung. Individual artistry and creative skill are admired in performers of such difficult forms as epics and extemporized poetic genres like the Kalinga ading.

 

 

 

The Musical Instruments

 

Most pre-Hispanic instruments are related to those in Southeast Asia, South China, and Oceania such as gongs, bamboo aerophones (blown instruments), drums, zithers, two-stringed lutes, bamboo xylophones, and other wooden and metal idiophones. Unlike the harp, guitar, transverse flutes, and violin-type instruments, which were adopted from the West, Philippine indigenous instruments have a highly relative tuning system partly due to the lack of standard sizes and a great variety of material sources. Western-adopted instruments are tuned diatonically based on the Western equal temperament.

 

There are representative instruments and instrument types according to area, according to Dioquino (1988). In the Cordillera highlands are found the flat gongs (Kalinga gangsa, Ifugao gangha, Ibaloy kalsa and pinsak); polychordal zither (Bontok kolitong, Kalinga kulibit); lip-valley flute (Kalinga paldong, Ibaloy taladi); fipple flute (Kalinga olimong, Bontok teptepew); pipe flutes in ensemble (Kalinga saggeypo); single-reed pipe (Ifugao hupip, Kalinga pattotot); nose flute (Isneg baliing, Bontok kaleleng, Ifugao ungiyung, Kalinga tungali); metal mouth harp (Bontok awedeng, Ibaloy koding, Kalinga giwong); conical drum (Ifugao libbit, Ibaloy kimbal and sulibao); bamboo and board zither (Ifugao ayudding and tadcheng, Ibaloy kaltsang); half-tube zither (Itneg patanggu, Kalinga patang-ug); stamping tubes (Kalinga tongatong, Isneg tungtung); bamboo buzzer (Bontok avakkao, Isneg bungkaka, Kalinga ubbeng); yoke-beam (Ifugao bangibang); xylophone blades (Kalinga patatag, Isneg talonggating); and violin (Kalinga gologod, Isneg nabil).

 

Instruments found in the central west highlands are the bossed gong (Palawan and Tagbanwa babandil); wide-rimmed bossed gong (Palawan agung); mouth harp (Palawan and Tagbanwa aroding, Hanunuo kinaban); ring flute (Palawan beberek); transverse flute (Hanunuo lantuy, Cuyunon and Tagbanwa tipanu); double-headed drum (Tagbanwa and Cuyunon gimbal, tambor); two-stringed lute (Palawan kusyapi); three-stringed fiddle (Buhid gitgit); bean-pod rattle (Hanunuo buray dipay); digging pole (Cuyunon palakupakan); shell trumpet (Hanunuo budyong, Cuyunon taburi); percussion beams (Tagbanwa sabagan); and percussion sticks (Hanunuo kalutang).

 

In the Mindanao highlands, the instruments used are the small bossed gongs laid in a row (Tboli klintang, Blaan and Subanon kulintang); small hanging bossed gongs (Manobo kulintang); small narrow-rimmed bossed gong (Tiruray agung); suspended bossed gong (Mansaka bubundi); several hanging bossed gongs (Bagobo lumming tagunggua); wide-rimmed bossed gong (Blaan, Subanon, Tboli, Kalagan, Bagobo and Manobo agung, Blaan salmagi); mouth harp (Tiruray kubing, Bagobo kumbing, Blaan lideng); lip-valley flute (Mandaya bunabon, Blaan palundag, Subanon tanggab and tulali); ring flute (Subanon glantuy, Bukidnon kinsi, Agusanon-Manobo saguysuy, Blaan and Tiruray suling); one-stringed fiddle (Blaan aduwagay, Agusanon-Manobo kugot, Tboli duwagey); two-stringed lute (Mansaka binarig, Blaan faglong, Tboli hagelong, Mansaka and Manobo kudlung); polychordal zither (Bagobo saluroy); digging pole (Subanon buhahay and taha-taha); shell trumpet (Mandaya lungga); plank drum (Blaan amdel, Kalagan and Tagakaolo edel, Bagobo odol); percussion beams (Tboli kalutang, Tiruray lontang, Manobo lutang); and bamboo slit drum (Mansaka koratong, Agusanon-Manobo kagii).

 

Among the Aeta groups are found the flat gong (Aeta Magbukun palay); bamboo mouth harp (Aeta and Dumagat kulibaw); lip-valley flute (Aeta Magbukun banghi, Ata tiwali); ring flute (Ata lantuy); musical bow (Aeta Magkunana bayi, Agta and Dumagat palat); two-stringed musical bow (Agta surimbao, Kabihug curimbao); one-stringed fiddle (Ata kagot); parallel-stringed tube zither (Aeta Magkunana tabebeng); digging pole (Aeta Magkunana talibengan).

 

Islamized groups used the small bossed gongs laid in a row (Maguindanao, Maranao, Sama and Jama Mapun kulintang, Yakan kwintangan); suspended bossed gong (Maguindanao and Maranao babandir); narrow-rimmed, suspended bossed gongs (Maguindanao gandingan); wide-rimmed bossed gong (Maranao, Maguindanao, Sama Dilaut, and Jama Mapun agung, Jama Mapun, Sama and Tausug buwa, tunggalan, and pulakan); bamboo mouth harp (Maranao and Sama kobing, Tausug and Yakan kulaing, Maguindanao kubing); lip-valley flute (Maguindanao palendag); ring flute (Maguindanao, Sama, Tausug, and Yakan suling); two-stringed lute (Maguindanao and Maranao kutyapi); European-type violin (Sama, Tausug, and Sama Dilaut biyula); bamboo slit drum (Maranao bentong agong, Maguindanao tamlang agong, Yakan tagutok); bamboo scraper (Maguindanao kagul, Maranao garakot); goblet-shaped drum (Maguindanao and Maranao dabakan); double-headed cylindrical drum (Tausug, Sama, Sama Dilaut, Maranao and Maguindanao gandang and tambul), bamboo clapper (Yakan daluppal); percussion beams (Yakan kwintangan kayu, Maranao lumbang, Maguindanao luntang); log drum (Yakan, Tausug, Sama Dilaut tuntungan); and bamboo xylophone (Yakan agung gabbang, gabbang, and kwintangan batakan, Sama gambang).

 

Among rural Christian communities, the instruments are the goblet-shaped drum (Tagalog Batangas tugtugan); double-headed cylindrical drum (Cebuano bombo, Ilonggo tambor); percussion sticks (Tagalog Marinduque kalutang); bamboo clappers (Tagalog Batangas kalaste); bamboo tube drum (Tagalog Batangas kalatong); European-type violin (Ilongo and Cebuano biyulin); diatonic harp (Ilocano and Tagalog arpa); transverse flute (Waray plahuta, Ilongo and Cebuano flauta); bamboo mouth harp (Tagalog barimbaw); imitation of brass-band instruments (Tagalog musikong bumbong); and the plucked instrument ensemble (rondalla).

 

Some instruments are more widespread than others, and some are played only in certain areas. The bamboo mouth harp, for example, is found almost everywhere, while the musical bow is limited to the Aeta cultures. The lip-valley flute and the polychordal zithers are found in northern Luzon and the Mindanao highlands. Flat gongs predominate in northern Luzon, while the bossed gongs are widespread in Mindanao, Sulu, and Palawan. Other instruments, such as the half-tube zither (ayudding) of the Ifugao and the stopped-pipe ensemble (saggeypo) of the Kalinga, are specific to some ethnolinguistic groups.

 

The instruments are played either in ensemble or solo. In general, ensembles perform during community events such as feasts like cañao and peshit, weddings, and burials. In the Cordillera highlands and northern Luzon, ensembles consist of groupings of one type of instrument such as the Kalinga and Bontok gangsa ensemble, or the saggeypo and bangibang ensemble.

 

In Figure 2, the Kalinga panpipe ensemble consists of six pitches with number one being the longest, therefore lowest tone, and number six being the shortest. An obvious interlocking music texture results from the juxtaposition of the musical cells.

 

The six pitches are named, each metaphorically representing a sector of the music community as in Table 1 (Prior 2011, 87):

 

Degree of Scale

Name

Representation

1

balbal

elders

2

kadwa

fathers

3

katlo

mothers

4

kapat

5

opop (kalmia)

unmarried woman

6

lalat (kanom)

children

 

The sulibao ensemble of the Ibaloy, however, consists of two flat gongs (kalsa and pinsak), two conical drums (sulibao and kimbal), and a pair of metal bars (palas). There is a variety of combinations of instruments and instrumental timbres in the Mindanao ensembles. The Yakan tagunggo ensemble consists primarily of a brass kwintangan, gabbang, a set of three agung, and cracked bamboo slit drum (gandang). The Maguindanao kulintangan is composed of a kulintang, babandir, four gandingan, a pair of agung, and a dabakan.

 

Indigenous musical instruments are mostly metallophones and idiophones, as well as bamboo chordophones and aerophones. Some of these have been adapted to Western music aesthetic. There are, for example, Asian instruments tuned to Western temperament and are played in the imported idiom. These are the blown bamboo tubes (bumbong), angklung, and tipanu (Cuyunon flute). Conversely, borrowed Western instruments have been used to play non-Western music such as the Hanunuo gitgit, Tausug biyula, and Aeta biyulin.

 

The Vocal Genres

 

In most tribal communities that have no generic name for vocal music or music for that matter, each vocal genre bears a specific name, usually referring not only to the musical and textual contents but also to its social role. The vocal repertoire consists of a great variety of types, forms, styles, uses, and functions.

 

While instrumental music is generally performed on different occasions—except for the bangibang music of the Ifugao which is heard exclusively at the ritual and the Yakan kwintangan kayu or daluppal music played only for agricultural purposes—vocal music is function-specific. Songs refer to particular occasions or activities and express individual feelings and emotions. Many songs are as specific as the Bugkalot (Ilongot) dinaweg, sung when trapping a wild pig, and the amamet, sung when hunting a pig with bow and arrow, and the Manobo sinda-ay, a wedding chant sung before inviting the groom’s party to enter the bride’s house. Among the Manobos of Agusan Valley, their most important song genre called tud-om is sung during face-to-face meetings as a ritualized gesture to formally recognize the co-presencing of self and other (Buenconsejo 2002).

 

Song genres are named differently depending on their content. The Kalinga lullaby is an owiwi when it tells of a child’s life or a dagdagqay when it foretells the baby’s future (Maceda 1972, 522). Some songs are general, such as the Kalinga salidummay, Tagalog awit, Mandaya bayok, Manobo limbay, and ballads such as the Ibaloy ta-miya.

 

Vocal genres may be classified according to their functions. The life cycle songs are lullabies, songs related to birth, courtship, wedding rites, and laments for the dead. Lullabies are as general as the langan bata-bata of the Tausug and bua of the Subanon, or as specific as the Kalinga oppiya which is sung while cradling a child on the singer’s lower leg, and the kawayanna which accompanies the wearing of a child’s first necklace (Maceda 1972, 518). Songs related to love, courtship, and marriage negotiations include song debates like the Kankanaey dai-eng, Batak inanen, Tagakaolo estijaro, Tboli setolu; incantations such as the Manobo kambong; and expressions of secret love like the Bontok chag-ay.

 

The different phases of the marriage rites have corresponding songs: the Manobo antang is a matchmaker’s song; the Pangasinan abuten is a duet of mother-in-law and daughter-in-law; the Tausug tarasul is a song of advice to the wedded couple; and the Ilocano dal-lot is a song debate between the couple’s parents. The Kalinga donop, which refers to the marriage proper, may be in the form of the tamuyong or appeal for spiritual blessing; dango or expression of gratitude; oggayam or greeting and advice to the newlyweds; and salidummay and dangdang-ay, which are love songs for entertainment.

 

Songs for the dead can be as specific as the Bontok didiyaw or the Matigsalug balow, which are sung for a dead husband. Some songs are sung during wakes: iring-iring of the Manobo, dirges such as the Ilocano dung-aw and the Isneg sangsangit, epic songs like the Manobo ulaging, and lamentations like the Ilonggo panaghoy. Among the Kankanaey of Benguet, mourners eulogize the dead by performing the day-eng­. Here, a singer extemporizes the text comprised of couplets A1 and B1 (Figure 3). Each couplet is then repeated by the entire group who perform the asbayat (response). Each singer is allowed as much time to sing as he or she wishes, although this commonly lasts anywhere from five to ten minutes.

 

Work songs accompany the different phases of the agricultural cycle, fishing, hunting, wine making, and gathering of firewood. Examples are the Aeta dururu, the general term for work song; the Subanon gagonapu, referring to hunting or fishing; the Ata panubad, a prayer before planting; the balatuking, harvest song of the Manobo; the sowe-ey, rice-pounding song of the Bontok; the Kalinga daku-yon, for hunting bats; the Bugkalot (Ilongot) dinaweg, for catching wild boar, and the dandannag and owayat, sung while gathering firewood; and the Batak didayu for wine making.

 

There is a vocal repertoire for the religious cycles of Islamic communities. Islamic rites include the Salathul Juma (Friday prayer), the Tarawe (prayer during the Ramadan), and the Maranao dekir or Maguindanao dikil (a dirge sung on the last night of the vigil). In indigenous animist cultures, the presence of spirits in the world is so real that they are always called upon or invoked in frequent life cycle and occupational activities and rituals. These are conducted or led by elders, medical specialists such as herbalists and bonesetters, and especially spirit-mediums when the occasion warrants their expertise in dealing with the spirit world.

 

Some vocal music among Christian groups clearly reveal Christian origins. An example is the chanted reading of the pasyon, the lengthy narrative of the passion of Christ set in versified form with five lines called pie (foot or stanza), each with eight syllables (Rivera Mirano 1984, 103). The text is read from published sources, the most popular version of which is titled Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat lpag-alab nang Puso nang Sino-mang Babasa (An Account of the Sacred Passion of Jesus Christ Our Lord Which Should Inflame the Heart of Anyone Who Reads It), also known as Pasyong Henesis (Genesis Passion), dating back to 1814. This text may be set to a number of melodies learned by rote and passed on through oral transmission. Each locality has its own set of melodies or punto, ranging from very old, extended and melismatic tunes sometimes known as sampay bakod (literally “to hang over a wall”) to perky tunes based on popular songs. In the town of Sariaya in Quezon province, tunes are ascribed to their places of origin such as sinariaya (from Sariaya, Figure 4), tinayabas (from Tayabas, Figure 5) and binatangan (from Batangas).

 

The use of indigenous instruments for Christian rituals is exemplified by the subli, which is performed in honor of the Holy Cross in Batangas. In the subli, the women devotees dance to the music of the indigenous drum tugtugan.

 

There are rituals in which vocal music plays a significant role: during curing ceremonies such as the Batak and Subanon diwata, Bontok kapya, Ibaloy angba, and Bugkalot (Ilongot) dawak; and during supplication rituals and offerings such as the Kankanaey alasan, Tagalog sanghiyang, Maguindanaon bpagipat, and Agusanon Manobo hinang. Normally, these are officiated by mediums who call upon their tutelary spirits who would demand that a pig or a chicken be sacrificed so that its meat is consecrated (bayaw) and eaten in a commensal feast. In the case of the Agusanon Manobo curing ritual, the animal sacrifice is termed saliling, which means “substitute,” and it is literally burnt after the killing as an act of dedication (sinugbahan)—a gift so to speak in order for a sick patient to live (Buenconsejo 2002). On these occasions, human sociability matters more than anything else. In effect, the dogmatic distinction between religious and secular expressions is undermined and rendered irrelevant. Other ritual genres are the Ibaloy bendiyan to celebrate victory in headhunting and the Kalinga kayuyugan and Manobo pamansag to celebrate victory in a tribal war; peace pacts, which are celebrated with the oggayam, ullalim, and dango; and thanksgiving rites like the Manobo pangangando.

 

There are children’s songs, songs for fun like the Subanon bongotat which is about old age and falling hair, drinking songs, greeting songs, and farewell songs. Philippine oral literature is also rich in extended narrative forms such as the folk epics and the metrical romances. The epics express not only the historical and literary aspects of a cultural tradition but also the people’s beliefs and entire system of social values. Some representative Philippine epics are the Blaan Aflulok, the Ifugao Hudhud, the Kalinga Gasumbi, Ilocano Lam-ang, the Sulod Hinilawod, the Palawan Kudaman, the Maguindanao Rajah Indarapatra, the Maranao Darangen, the Sama Silungan Baltapa, the Manobo Tuwaang, Agyu and Ulahingan, the Mansaka Manggob, the Subanon Gambatutu (Maceda 1972; Pfeiffer 1975, 204-48), and Tboli Tudbulol (Mora 2008). Some epics are shared by two or more cultural groups, such as the Rajah Indarapatra, known to both the Maguindanao and the Maranao.

 

In most Christian communities, indigenous epics have been replaced by metrical romances introduced by the Spanish colonizers and some may even consider the pabasa as an epic. The popularity of metrical romances peaked in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Although the stories were originally written, these have been orally transmitted through the years, assuming different versions in the process. The awit and korido, differing only in poetic structures and style of rendition, are tales of heroism populated by European knights, princes, and princesses, and based on Biblical stories and Greco-Roman literature (Eugenio 1987). Recited or intoned on preexisting melodic formulae such as the Tagalog awit, metrical romances are an established tradition among the Tagalog, Pampango, Ilocano, Cebuano, Bicol, and Ilongo. Philippine metrical romance literature includes both adapted works like Erastro, Floristo at Blanca Flor (Floristo and Blanca Flor), Adriana at Pantinople (Adriana and Pantinople), Mariang Alimango (Maria the Crab) which is an adaptation of the Cinderella story, and original works like Don Juan Tiñoso, Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird). The stories of the metrical romances have also provided material for the komedya, a popular theater form in the 19th century.

 

Based on field research in Batangas that is part of Southern Tagalog region, awit also means dance song, which is characterized by dodecasyllabic quatrains called plosa. These are chanted using melodic formulae, often with ornamentation and accompanied by rhythms on the guitar in pandanggo style. In the awit, one evidently sees the indigenous elements, such as chanting and dancing, being mixed with Western elements, such as the 12-syllable versification influenced by the literary metrical romances from Spain and use of guitar playing local version of fandango (Rivera Mirano 1984).

 

Styles, Concepts, and Structures

 

While affinities exist in instrumental inventories and social functions among music cultures, there are distinctions in the styles of performance, structural elements such as scales, tune formulae and rhythmic modes, and aesthetics.

 

Differences in performing styles can be very apparent even between related cultures. In the Cordillera highlands, the Kalinga play their gangsa (flat gongs) in groups of six or more, either in the pattong style (beaten with hard sticks) while dancing at the same time, or in the toppaya style (beaten with the palm, Figure 6) with gongs resting on the lap as the musicians half-kneel around the dance area, playing for dancing couples.

 

Among the Ibaloy, the kalsa and pinsak together with the palas players follow in step behind a dancing couple, while the two drums, sulibao and kimbal, are played by two seated musicians. The Ifugao play their gangha in a group of three, using both mallets and hands, remaining in position while accompanying the dancers. Benguet Kankanaey dancers on the other hand perform tayaw in public celebrations accompanied by two gongs (Figure 7), gangsa and pinsak, takik (iron bars) and solibaw (conical drum).

 

Among the inland Muslim peoples, kulintang music has greater musical autonomy, except when used in rituals such as the kapagipat curing ceremony of the Maguindanao, where the medium dances the sagayan to the accompaniment of the kulintang (Butocan 1987). During major celebrations, players exhibit virtuosity in highly competitive performances. They render improvisations on rhythmic modes classified into two types: an older style called a minuna and the new style known as a bagu. The latter, preferred by younger musicians, is much faster than the former (Table 2).

 

a minuna (old style)

a bagu (new style)

sirong

binalig

sinulog a minuna

sinulog a bagu

tidtu a minuna

tidtu a bagu

tagunggo

 

 

The Manobo, however, play the hanging kulintang while the body moves rhythmically with the music that eventually leads to dancing. The Maguindanao kutyapi is played in a sitting position, while players of the Manobo kuglong and the Tboli hagelong dance to their own music.

 

The styles of vocal rendition can be classified as solo singing, leader-chorus (solo and group alternating with each other), song debate (two singers, each alternating with sung verses), and group singing, with or without accompaniment. All of these have been observed in the diverse styles of reading the pasyon throughout the archipelago. Lullabies, songs for entertainment, laments, epics, and ritual chants are sung solo. The identity of solo songs with extemporized texts is based on tune formulae and social functions, as in the Kalinga gasumbi, oggayam, and Tagalog huluna. Song debates such as the Visayan balitaw and Ilocano dallot are usually performed in courtship and wedding rites, either by the two lovers or their parents.

 

The leader-chorus style, such as the Ibaloy ba-diw and Ifugao alim, is common among indigenous cultures. In the alim, two groups of singers reply to two male leaders. Group singing predominates in the music of lowland Christian communities. Folk songs are either sung in unison or in harmony. Members of folk religious sects in the provinces of Quezon, Laguna, Cavite, and Batangas, sing hymns in semi-extemporized harmonization (Santos 1975, 93-117). In indigenous cultures, work songs such as the Bontok chey-assa, a rice-pounding song, are sung in groups.

 

Accompanied solo songs are popular among highland communities of Mindanao and Palawan and Islamic coastal groups. Among the Mindanao highland peoples such as the Manobo, Bagobo, and Matigsalug, the singers play the two-stringed lute or the zither and dance to the music at the same time.

 

Among Christians, accompanied singing is the predominant style of vocal music, and the guitar is the most popular and readily available instrument. Improvised folk singing among rural Christian groups shows an integration of non-Western and Western musical elements such as the awit in San Juan, Batangas. The preexisting tunes are loosely cast in major and minor tonalities, while phrases are repeated in drone-like fashion over nonfunctional chordal accompaniment of the guitar or the local harp. The songs are based on certain metric patterns, which are not strictly complied with in actual performance.

 

The melodic structures vary from the most ornamented or melismatic to syllabic and speech-like renditions. Vocal techniques include trills, vibrato, slides, and glottal stops. In the sanghiyang ritual of the rural Tagalog, for example, the shamans start their dialogue in exaggerated speaking style and gradually modulate these to more musical or chant-like vocal undulations as they reach a state of trance. This music process is in contrast to the Agusanon Manobo ritual song tud-om, which starts with a section using dark constricted nonlexical vowels in a sound called ajenged. This is made up of minor seconds and microtones (Figure 8). This ends up with a burst in a bright tonal space using open lexical vowels in high register called te-ak. The dark-to-bright ajenged section is described by the Manobo as “weeping” and it alternates with sections that can be called “speech paragraphs.” These are made up of improvised textual couplets delivered in parlando speech style (not shown in transcription above). The Manobo call the ajenged section as the part of the song where habag (pity) is expressed.

 

Each cultural tradition has its own set of musical concepts and aesthetic values. In many cultures, music is not purely auditory or affective: the musical or sound component may be part of a larger artistic act. In most vocal repertoires, the text serves as the main artistic element more than the musical sound, and poetry and rhetoric determine the value of a song as a whole. The performer also composes by extemporaneously creating text in vocal music or by innovating and improvising on melodic motifs or rhythmic patterns in instrumental music.

 

Despite the use of five- or six-tone scales—sometimes even less than five tones in indigenous music—and the manufacture of more or less similar instruments, the tuning, sizes, scales, and modes are all relative to individual groups, families, or even individual artists. No kulintang is tuned exactly like another, and the lengths of flutes and overall size of other instruments are dependent on the preference of the performers who usually make the instruments themselves. Thus, musical excellence and aesthetic satisfaction are not determined by exact intonation and other quantitative factors deemed significant in Western music such as pitch range, amplitude, formal clarity, and compositional complexity. Rather, aesthetic pleasure is derived from individual timbres, tonal resonance, improvisation, poetic depth, and the relationship of the musical elements with other elements of the artistic activity.

 

Drone and melody are the underlying principles in the organization of the musical elements. Drone, a basic element in Asian music, reflects a concept of infinity and stability in the spiritual world. Musicologist Jose Maceda (1976) first described the different ways that cultures developed their musical languages according to the structural principles of drone and melody. First, drone and melody are an integrated structure of interlocking repeated individual parts (hocket) or patterns, such as in the music of Kalinga saggeypo and gangsa music, and Tiruray agung. Second, drone and melody are played as separate parts. Third, drone accompaniment alternates with song melody, as in the Palawan kulilal. Last, drone and melody are combined in one line, as in the Maguindanao kutyapi or Yakan solo gabbang.

 

The concept of tonal harmony hardly exists in orally transmitted musical idioms, except in the use of chord structures, usually the tonic and dominant, in rural Christian music. However, these chord structures provide drones rather than harmonic function relative to the European tonal system.

 

Philippine indigenous music is generally free rhythmically. While a basic pulse unifies a group performance, there is little synchronism or tyranny of the downbeat. Formal elements such as opening and closing formulae function only in instrumental ensemble music, without necessarily affecting the freedom to improvise with indefinite duration on the microstructural elements (i.e., motifs, phrases, rhythms) of the music or the body of the music itself.

 

The structural and stylistic elements of traditional musical practices represent different concepts of artistic expression, most of which are not confined to the purely sonic dimension but integrate sound, movement, space, and poetry, and fuse the performers’ creative and interpretative roles. Furthermore, improvisation and the absence of fixed systems in the formulation and formation of basic musical materials reflect not only individuality and specificity, but a concept of individual freedom of choice in the selection and organization of these materials. Improvisation and variation pervade even the seemingly closed and limited compositional system based on drone and melody.

 

Epilogue

 

The great variety of musical repertoires and styles in oral traditions reflects a highly pluralistic culture. There is no simple definition or description of the totality of Philippine music. Social changes—religious, economic, or political—affect musical practices, transforming them and giving rise to substitutes or causing their disappearance. Thus, the diversity in the archipelago’s music stems from highly dispersed ethnic origins as well as long periods of contact with outside traditions, both Asian and Western, and from the transformation of new impulses into integral parts of a Philippine cultural heritage. Written by Ramon P. Santos, updated by Verne de la Peña, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo
