Section:

 

Liturgical Music
Extraliturgical Music
Secular Music
Epilogue

 

In 1521, the first Spanish ships arrived in the Philippines. “God, Gold, and Glory” became the basis for Spain’s colonization of the country. The conquistadores had various motives for coming. Among these was the desire to gain control over the trade routes supplying the European market with spices and other exotic merchandise from Asia. To accomplish this, they needed to have control over the native rulers. At the same time, they had to compete with the growing influence of Islam and the Islamic leaders all over the islands.

 

Every Spanish expedition included a group of missionaries tasked to bring the Christian faith to the natives. Conversion involved not only embracing a new set of religious beliefs but also turning away from existing cultural practices. Thus, the Spanish colonial regime from 1565 to 1898 set out to reshape Philippine culture, including Philippine music. Songs on the exploits of epic heroes and the rhythms of the native drums and gongs gave way to the chants of the Christian church and the harmonized music of the organ, harp, and guitar.

 

Liturgical Music

 

The Spanish discovered that the Filipinos were a singing people. In 1604, Pedro Chirino noted how government and religion is “… founded on tradition … They preserve it in songs, which they know by heart and learn when children, by hearing these sung when they are sailing or tilling their fields, when they are rejoicing and holding feasts, and especially when they are mourning their dead. In these barbarous songs they relate the fabulous genealogies and vain deeds of their gods” (Blair and Robertson 1973, 263) .

The early dictionaries written by the missionaries to enable them to teach the Christian faith to new converts revealed an already long and varied list of native song types. Pedro de San Buenaventura’s 1613 Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala (Vocabulary of Tagalog Words) contained the following under the entry “cantar”:

 

auit (romance), hila (remeros), sambitan (llorando muertos), nananambitan (llorando difuecto), sambotanin (emborrachera), hilirao (emborrachera), diyona (de borrachera), oyayi (arrolando los niños), dayao (victoria), tagumpay (la victoria) [141]

 

 

The famous Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala by Juan de Noceda and Pedro de Sanlucar (1860) added “talindao … indolanin, dolayanin (en el calle)… soliranin, manigpasin (los remeros), holohorlo … (arrulos al niño), umbayi (triste), umiguing (suave) … dopayanin … balicongcong” (19) to Buenaventura’s list. Unfortunately for Philippine music, the sentiment prevailing among the clergy at the time of conquest was that such rich material was the province of the devil and therefore a barrier to the spread of the Christian faith. To clear the way for the latter, the sights and sounds of the old rituals had to be eradicated. As a whole, the performance and practice of what must have been a rich music culture was discouraged so that much of it virtually disappeared. Only a few genres survived, albeit in altered form.

 

As they suppressed native music, the missionaries doubled their efforts in teaching European religious music to the newly converted Christians who proved to be adept and enthusiastic in learning the plainsong, the flute, the harp, and the guitar. Thus, fifty years after the Spaniards’ arrival on Philippine shores, the Church was able to establish schools for teaching the indio (Christianized native) the music of the faith.

 

In monasteries and churches, the first sounds of the Christian church that the natives heard was the Gregorian chant or plainchant, an austere, unaccompanied monophony. This body of systematically codified and organized songs believed to have been put in order in the 6th century by Pope Gregory I represents one of the oldest surviving Western music traditions. Pope Gregory ensured the disciplined, uniform practice of the plainchant. His legacy lived on in the founding of the Schola Cantorum, a singing school for the training of church musicians in Rome in the 9th century. The schola became the center of training for all musicians within the church and an authoritative body that determined the character of church music and developed the musicians that would teach this practice all over the Christian world. Thus, the uniformity of style as well as practice, and the quality of music were ensured, which then convinced the Roman Catholic Church to include church musicians and music teachers among its missionaries to the Philippines. Notable among these were Juan Bolivar, Lorenzo Castelo, and Manuel Arostegui, all Augustinians; Pedro Bautista, Geronimo de Aguilar, and Jose de la Virgen, Franciscans; and Domingo Cera, Recollect. According to Church histories, these missionary musicians’ duties were to provide musical training for young boys, write books on music and music theory, compose music for liturgical purposes, provide music during masses, and, particularly in the case of Fr. Cera, train young musicians to manufacture musical instruments.

 

In 1601, the first church orchestra was organized by the Augustinians in Guadalupe. In 1606, the Franciscans, under the leadership of Juan de Garrovillas, founded a seminary in Lumban, Laguna where 400 boys were trained to sing, play, and manufacture musical instruments. The first director of the seminary was Juan de Santa Marta, who arrived in the Philippines in 1618 and who had been a singer at the Cathedral of Zaragosa. By 1609, there were already, according to de Morga (1890), fine choirs of chanters and musicians, especially around Manila. De Ribadeneira (1601) noted that the young boys in such schools play very well together and very softly; and as a whole are lovers of music. They serve Masses either by singing plainchant or playing the organ. Some are very good readers, such that to hear them sing an epistle and place accents, it seems they knew Latin. (67)

 

Decades later in Intramuros, the San Agustin church produced a lay brother, the great great grandson of Rajah Solaiman, Marcelo de San Agustin, who was the first named indio to have composed music in the Western idiom.

 

By 1742, a full-fledged conservatory of music, the Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral, was established in Manila. Solfeggio, vocalization, composition, organ, and strings were part of the basic curriculum. Subsequent graduates of the Colegio were Salvador Piñon, Simplicio Solis, Antonio Garcia, Maximo Nazario, Manuel Lopez, Antonio and Hipolito Rivera, FulgencioTolentino, Jose Muezo, Antonio Escamilla, Crispino Reyes, and Bernabe Solis. They were taught by noted Spanish peninsular composers like Remigio and Apolinar Calahorra; Hispanics Oscar Camps y Soler, Blas Echegoyen, and Luis Vicente Arche; and Filipino instrumentalists Ramon Valdez and Ignacio Morales.

 

 

 

 

Although the Colegio was the most important conservatory in the 19th century, other churches had their own boys’ choirs (e.g., Letran and Santo Domingo) which trained boys to become singers and sacristans as well. One outstanding product of the San Agustin Church choir in Intramuros was the composer of Filipino liturgical music MarceloAdonay (1848-1928) of Pakil, Laguna. He began to serve at the age of eight when he apprenticed as a sacristan. He later became a choirboy and would, during his off-hours, escape to the choir loft and learn to play the organ by himself. He also learned to play the piano and violin, and to compose in both the contrapuntal and harmonic styles. He was later named maestro de capilla and by 1870 was director of the church orchestra. He was praised by AntonioJ.Molina for keeping his religious music in “harmony with the severe regulations of the church liturgy,” while projecting the “vitality… religious fervor and … Christian faith, hope, love, and charity” that were often absent in the theatrical, showy music that was in vogue in his day (Manuel 1955, 38). Other 19th century composers who started out as boy sopranos at the San Agustin Church were Jose Canseco Jr and Pedro Navarro Jr. Both later became famous military band maestros. Navarro was Adonay’s pupil and the first Filipino conductor of the famed Philippine Constabulary Band in the early 20th century.

Native-born musicians were the backbone of music practice in the Philippines as they sang, played, and composed for the church. Prominent local artists active in church music in the 19th century were Cayetano Jacobe, violinist from Lumbang, Laguna; Pedro Castañeda from Santa Cruz; BalbinoCarrion, tenor; his son, Juan Carrion, singer and violinist; Andres Ciria Cruz, who also sang with visiting Italian opera companies; and NatalioMata, organist and teacher from Quiapo.

 

In this setting, religiousmusic flourished, varying in style, depending on the prevailing liturgical requirement and function. From the mid-18th to the early 19th century, church music consisted of canto llano (plainchant), canto llano figurado (chant with meter), and canto organo (polyphonic music). Extant large choirbooks called cantorales, handwritten on cowhide parchment and preserved at the San Agustin Church in Intramuros and in the parish church of Baclayon, Bohol, are reminders of the liturgical music from that early modern period. In the latter part of 19th century, the music celebrating a patron saint’s day was festive and symphonic, such as Beethoven’s “Missa Solemnis in D Major” which was performed at the San Agustin Church in the late 1870s. A partial listing of works composed by Fr Manuel Arostegui, who was referred to as “Augustino Filipino,” gives us an idea of the range of genres and repertoire that might have been familiar to a church musician of the 19th century: a grand mass for full orchestra, with organ or piano and four or eight voices; “O Salutaris Hostia” and “Motete al Santisimo,” for solo baritone, with violin and harmonium accompaniment; “Salve,” for three voices, with organ or piano accompaniment; “Flores de Maria,” for three voices, with organ or harmonium accompaniment; and “Ave Maria,” for tenor solo with piano or harmonium accompaniment. Marcelo Adonay’s Pequeña Misa Solemne Sobre Motivos de la Missa Regia del Canto Gregoriano (Short Solemn Mass using the Motives of the Missa Regia of Gregorian Chant), first sung during the feast day of San Augustin in Intramuros in 1904, was in the tradition of this grand mass.

 

The rest of church music was written for vocal and instrumental ensembles in various combinations. Instrumental ensembles usually included the violin and other strings, piano, harmonium, and the queen of church instruments, the pipe organ, which was usually imported from Spain, like the one from the old church of Santo Domingo in Intramuros which is supposed to have possessed a “fine double open diapason on the pedals, its longest pipe rising 18 ft above the floor” (Bañas 1969, 30). In time, some of the organs were manufactured locally. Pioneers in this effort were the Recollects who established a school for organ builders. In 1818, a native organ made of bamboo was constructed in Las Piñas under the direction of Fr. Diego Cera. Nine hundred pieces of bamboo were used, and great care was taken to ensure the proper treatment of the fragile material. The builders had to wait until the proper season to cut the bamboo pieces, which they then buried beside the sea for half a year to protect them from weevils and ensure their durability.

 

In all aspects of music practice, the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines brought in Western musical norms and ideals that, through the centuries, took firm root in fertile and receptive soil.

 

Extraliturgical Music

 

Because the Christian religion was such a powerful force during the Spanish colonial period, its influence extended outside the confines of the church liturgy and into the domain of daily life. Extraliturgical music was still tied, in varying degrees, to Christian belief. Some were initiated by the clergy themselves, a good example of which was the set of original devotional music in villancico form, which was composed for the cofradia of the santuario of San Juan del Monte in the 18th century. One piece in this collection was titled “Letra en Tagalo” (Lyrics in Tagalog) as it had a Tagalog text. This is the oldest extant Philippine music in Western notation.

 

Other types of extraliturgical music might originally have been church-sponsored but later on moved away from church supervision and lost much of their religious character. Those that developed outside church supervision still combined Christian and non-Christian elements and forms. Through time, Church authorities had mixed feelings about these practices, alternately encouraging them as expressions of simple piety and banning them as works of the devil.

These extraliturgical devotions abound in Philippine society until today. Some of these are practiced by all the major Christianized ethnolinguistic groups. Probably the most widespread of these practices are the Lenten pabasa; the Marian Flores de Mayo and the santacruzan, both held in May; the Easter salubong and bati; and the Christmas panunuluyan.

 

The pabasa is the public chanting of the pasyon, a long verse narrative on the life and death of Jesus Christ. Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s monumental Tagalog poem Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Cristong Panginoon Natin na Tola (Sacred Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse), first published in 1703, was the earliest of these verse narratives set in octosyllabic quintillas. Other pasyon in other Philippine languages were published later, many of them translations of the anonymous 1814 Tagalog poem Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (An Account of the Sacred Passion of our Lord Jesus Christ Which Should Inflame the Heart of Anyone Who Reads It). It is not known when the pasyon first came to be performed in public, but by 1827, when a parish priest complained in a letter about erroneous doctrinal ideas being spread by such performances, it could be assumed that the pabasa was already a well-entrenched custom.

 

Today, the pabasa thrives as a Lenten practice all over Catholic Philippines, performed during the entire season, from Ash Wednesday to Black Friday. The style of chanting varies not only from region to region but also from town to town. Some punto or basic melodies are sung in unison and resemble plainchant. Others are borrowed from current popular melodies and are sung in two or three-part Western harmony. Still others are accompanied by instruments in many different groupings. The vocal quality is tense with a raised upper palate. A much admired type of voice is called matinis—high-pitched and penetrating.

 

The punto, a term used in pabasa singing in Batangas, is an interesting feature of the form. It refers to the basic or skeletal melodies associated with the pabasa. Almost any melody, whether a traditional one from the early centuries of Spanish rule or one from the newest popular song, can form the basic punto. Thus, in the town of Balayan, there are punto based on “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), “Aloha Oe,” and even the Philippine National Anthem, alongside such venerable tunes as the tres caidas, kinalamyas, and biniyulin.

 

While a given punto is fixed and easily recognizable, it is also usually the practice to weave ornaments—slow tremolos, slides and mordent-like embellishments—into the punto. This practice, called pagduduyan in San Mateo, Rizal, adds to the beauty and grace of the melodic line. Such ornamentation also gives the individual singers a chance to add their individual stamp to the chanting. This elaborate use of ornaments, coupled with the unusual vocal quality, aside from giving the pabasa color and variety, suggests an earlier, pre-Spanish vocal style.

 

Despite the disparate melodies, textures, and performance practices, all pabasa are linked together by several characteristics. First, they are all communal performances of a long narrative poem on the life of Christ. Second, the pabasa is performed for a long period of time, usually lasting at least 12 hours. Finally, this communal effort is considered the fulfillment of a panata. The panata, an element found in many folk Christian practices that developed outside the Christian Church, is a vow made to God, the Virgin Mary, or to one’s favorite patron saints, in which a person promises to perform a difficult act or task in return for a favor bestowed by the deity such as deliverance from illness or misfortune, passing a government examination, or securing a good job. The task often takes the form of a long and elaborate ritual involving, among other things, singing or chanting praises to the patron (the aspect of God or the deity invoked).

 

Easter Sunday has its own set of extraliturgical celebrations. These commonly include the salubong, which begins with separate processions of the veiled Mater Dolorosa and the Risen Christ, sometimes accompanied by the choral singing of the “Stabat Mater” or a brass band. The processions wind up in the churchyard, where the meeting of the Virgin and Christ is dramatized. The Virgin’s black veil of mourning is lifted by a little girl dressed as an angel, while a chorus of girls and young women sing the “Regina Coeli, Laetare” (Queen of Heaven, Rejoice), with antiphonal alleluias. Sometimes, balse and mazurka are performed before and after the removal of the veil. Sometimes, the salubong also includes a special dance called bati, where performers wield flags and banners to the accompaniment of the drum. These songs and dances were most likely disseminated and encouraged by the church during the Spanish period.

 

A Maytime ritual is the santacruzan, a devotion to the Holy Cross that reenacts the finding of the true cross of Jesus Christ by Queen Helena, mother of the Roman emperor Constantine. The procession, accompanied by brass bands and choirs of singers, moves through the town’s main streets. The participants, dressed in elaborate costumes, personify characters from the story of the finding of the cross. Further secularization in the 20th century led to the festivity becoming the vehicle for a grand display of gowns and finery by the young elite members of the town.

 

Also dedicated to the Holy Cross is the subli of southwestern Batangas, a devotion-celebration with music, poetry, dance, and prayer. Its most famous version is found in the town of Bauan, Batangas where participants seek the favor of the Mahal na Poong Santa Cruz (Beloved Lord Holy Cross), a miraculous wooden cross that is the popularly accepted patron of the town. The ritual, which may last from six to eight hours, features uninterrupted dancing to the beating of drums and chanting in unison of mystic verses narrating the story of the Mahal na Poon. The major celebrations of the subli coincide with the Maytime santacruzan. At one point in the ritual, the distinction between the story of Queen Helena and the tale of the Mahal na Poon disappears as the two merge.

 

Performed in May, the Flores de Mayo, also known by the name alay, is a devotion to the Blessed Virgin Mary. Although each region and sometimes each town have a slightly different practice and a different set of songs for the occasion, the basic form remains the same. In the afternoons of May, processions of young women and girls carrying flowers wind their way through the town’s main street, singing songs in honor of the Virgin Mary. In the church, pairs of girls (or girls and boys) offer flowers to the statue of the Virgin as they sing in two-part tertial harmony, to the accompaniment of the guitar, organ, or a small orchestra. The Flores is climaxed by the big procession at the end of the month, which features the Virgin on a carroza (float), preceded by the zagala or young girls and ladies bearing symbols of the attributes of the Virgin Mary. As clerical control over these practices weakened, there was a tendency to combine the Flores with the Santacruzan, leading to some confusion over the nature and character of both celebrations.

 

During the period of hondras, the November festivals for the dead also known as undas or todos los santos, singing groups called mangangaluluwa surface. They represent the wandering spirits of the dead that carol from house to house, begging for alms and playing pranks on stingy house owners. The villancico, danza, habanera, and balse that form the bulk of their repertoire are based on popular Spanish or Mexican tunes and are unrelated to the music of the Catholic Church.

 

A good example of how a secular form separated itself from an originally church-sponsored practice is seen in the panunuluyan (seeking entry) and its related form, pamamasko (Christmas caroling). The former is a nativity pageant staged in various places around the town. Townsfolk dressed as characters in the Christmas story take part in this sung reenactment. A choir and orchestra performing Christmas carols accompany the actors in their journey through the town. This church-sponsored play might have been the origin of the practice of pamamasko, in which bands of young folk travel from house to house during Christmas time singing for alms. In the Leyte and Bicol regions, they are called pastores, usually composed of 12 girls and/or boys headed by a capitana (lady captain), all garbed in colorful costumes. Most of the tunes they sing are in the traditional Spanish villancico time of 6/8. In practice, however, folk musicians often change the rhythm and phrasing to balse or pasodoble or even irregular time, altering the character of the original songs to suit local tastes. An example of this is the Catalonian villancico “Pastores a Belen” (Shepherds at the Nativity) by the pastores of Camalig, Albay which has been transformed into a paso doble. The pamamasko, once part of the panunuluyan, has also become part of the secular side of the Christmas celebration. Divorced from the religious pageant, it has been transformed into a fund-raising event, and all proceeds raised by the young people are used to fund social dances or fiesta events for the next year.

 

Despite Spanish control, some extraliturgical music that was considered native ritual music persisted, because on the surface, they seemed to honor Christian icons. This is exemplified by the sanghiyang of Cavite which invokes the basic icons of the Christian pantheon such as the Virgin Mary and the Santo Niño. But the sanghiyang mediums are also possessed by numerous other spirits such as the hari ng kailaliman (king of the underworld) and San Juan Sambanog Tiwan-tiwan. In a trance state, they perform unmetered chants, half-spoken and half-sung. The entire ritual calls upon these deities to bestow health, good fortune, and prosperity upon the celebrating community with food offerings, chanted prayers, incense, and flames.

 

Secular Music

 

The more important type of secular music that evolved during the Spanish colonial period can be lumped together under the umbrella term folk music. Like the paraliturgical genres, this was an organic product of music acculturation or of the intercultural encounter between indigenous and Western cultures. This encounter spawned the bidirectional processes of music exchange, that is, syncretism or hybridity. One process pointed toward the Hispanization of indigenous pre-Hispanic genres like epic chanting and song debate. As Christianity spread, epic chanting was lost in lowland areas but was supplanted by the long hagiographic chant pabasa. Similarly, in the indigenous song debate, elements of European secular genres from Spain and/or Mexico were incorporated to the existing local expression, as in the use of harmonic tonality using the imported guitar that eventually replaced the native kudyapi and bamboo zither. In this process, mestizaje genres like kumintang, balitaw, and curacha emerged.

 

The other intercultural process was the reversal of the first, i.e., the Filipinization of imported genres like villancico, fandango, polka, jota, and most importantly, the danza. The villancico was the root of the Visayan pastores music and the Cebuano daygon. The fandango was so assimiliated by the indios that it spread to far-flung regions of the archipelago and may have been the source of the Tagalog kundiman because both kundiman and fandango were generally binary in form in the 19th century. These imported music genres were indigenized, later becoming the main body of folk songs known today among lowland Christians.

 

The berso golpeado of the Ibanag of Cagayan Valley, a joyous song for greeting guests in the northern Cordillera, is a traditional song in triple time accompanied by a cinco-cinco guitar which strums out chord progressions. The strumming at first appears to be simple attempts at simulating Western harmonies. Upon closer inspection, however, it expresses a different concept of sound in which two alternating clusters of tones are played repeatedly to create a continuous, unbroken sound over which a vocal melody may be built. This feature may be seen in song forms in other Christianized regions of the country.

 

Secular ballads narrating historical events, heroic deeds, or humorous anecdotes may still be heard in Hispanized areas, like Cuyo, Palawan or Panay. The composo is a ballad which is a vehicle for the spread of local news. At festive gatherings in Aklan such as after-work drinking parties, ordinary townsfolk compose and perform songs that retell the tales of the last devastating typhoon, the exploits of rebels or bandit leaders, and even the latest juicy gossip. Musically, its diatonic melodies and chordal accompaniment on the guitar show the influence of Western melody and harmonic progression.

 

Perhaps the most famous of all of these Hispanized hybrid music is the dance-song kumintang. In the 19th century, numerous writers referred to it as the national song, perhaps because it was indigenous to a particular place and people. Originating from Batangas, a province known in early times as “Kumintang,” it was actually a regional variant of the awit, a song in slow triple time. Cast in plosa verse or quatrains with 12-syllable lines, the text usually dealt with love and courtship, although it could also be about more general topics such as the hypocrisy and the folly of man.

 

The kumintang was first notated in a print by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay dating back to 1734. The first extant example of notation was the “Comintang de la Conquista” (Comintang of the Conquest) found in Jean Mallat’s travelogue Les Philippines, published in 1846. Epifanio de los Santos, writing in 1916, warned that portions of this transcription were not characteristic of the authentic kumintang. This was because Mallat’s publisher wrongly conflated the guitar accompaniment with a piano accompaniment whose harmony followed the learned classical style. The piano accompaniment was tacked on to the piece by a certain Henry Cohen who, in all likelihood, did not visit the Philippines. Indeed, if the piano accompaniment were eliminated and the guitar sounds alone accompanied the voice, this early transcription would bear striking structural similarities to the awit still performed in the mountains of Batangas today. The kinanluran (“of the west”) and sinilangan (“of the east”) awit styles, as well as the awit’s guitar-plucking technique, resemble not only the “Comintang de la Conquista” but also other 19th-century transcriptions, and provide a valuable link to an ancient tradition.

 

Secular music from Spain also made an impact in the form of light, popular songs and dances. The styles of these imported music were transmitted through spectacles in public spaces such as indoor theaters, outdoor plazas where events such as loa, komedya, serenata (open-air concert), and baile were held, and even inside the church whose religious music was heavily influenced by popular styles in 19th century. These were also transmitted via the Spanish school system which provided instruction in Western music to the children of the affluent criollos, mestizos, and native elites. This system also cultivated in them a taste for Italian operas such as Aida and Spanish zarzuela such as Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire) brought to the islands by troupes visiting from Europe, especially after the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869. In boys’ colleges in the 19th century, music was taught as part of a number of subjects, which included philosophy, physics, and metaphysics. Similarly, young girls, especially after the educational reforms in basic education in 1863, were taught instrumental music, particularly the piano, in the girls’ colleges. Familiarity with these European forms became a mark of gentility. Young women of good breeding were expected to play the waltz, the habanera, and mazurka on the piano or harp, and sing popular arias. Prominent families sponsored tertulias, informal parties where the main activity was the reading of Spanish poetry and the performance of light classical works by Italian composers such as Rossini and Verdi.

 

Philippine songs and dances modeled on these European forms developed and thus, Spanish music was Filipinized. By the 19th century, writers for the propaganda movement could point with pride to song and dance forms in the European style developed in the islands. The most famous of these was the kundiman.

 

The kundiman is a lyrical song in moderate triple time. From the early 1800s to about the 1840s, it was a folk dance-song as witnessed by observers like the Augustinian Martinez Zuñiga in 1800 and Gervasio Cironella and Jose Lozano in 1847. By about the 1860s to the 1890s, as evidenced in the music recorded in Karl Scherzer’s travelogue, 1861, and in the collection of popular music in the Philippines by Manuel Walls y Merino, 1892, it had lost its dance component. Unlike the kumintang, which has a strophic or a verse-and-refrain structure, the 19th century kundiman is divided into two separate sections, each with a different melody. Its binary sectioning makes it akin to other Filipino folk songs. By the 1920s, however, it developed into a “cultivated art” form, with an expanded second section to make three. Also, unlike the kumintang and the berso golpeado, where two chords or clusters of tones alternate repeatedly to produce a continuous, unchanging sound, the kundiman uses a clear harmonic progression in the Western sense and even modulation. While it is possible for the 19th century two-sectioned kundiman to be in a single key or tonality, it is more likely that each section is in a different mode.

 

The lyrics of the kundiman are about romantic love, although love of country and sorrow over the loss of a loved one are common themes as well. During the Philippine revolution against Spain, the kundiman became a metaphoric expression of love for the motherland. The most famous kundiman which fired the patriotic sentiments of revolucionarios (revolutionaries) from 1896 to 1898 in the struggle for liberation from colonial rule was “JocelynangBaliwag” (Jocelyna of Baliwag).

 

Other Western forms were adopted by Filipinos. The habanera, named after its place of origin of Havana, Cuba, and also known as danza or danza habanera, is in duple time, and is typified by “La Bella Filipina” by Massaguer. This piece is a landmark composition because it is one of the earliest sheet music prints that was produced in the colony. The polka, a lively Bohemian dance in fast duple meter, is exemplified by the popular “Pamulinawen” (Stone-hearted) of the Ilocos. The jota, originally a Spanish folk dance, has sections in duple and quadruple time, as seen in the jota moncadeña. The mazurka, which originated from Poland, is usually danced in 3/4 or 6/8 time by eight to 16 couples. The paso doble, a dance in duple meter slightly faster than the march, is exemplified by “No Te Vayas a Zamboanga” (Do Not Go to Zamboanga). The rigodon de honor, in duple meter, is based on the French court dance, and was once performed for official and formal functions. The marcha or march in duple time is exemplified by “Alerta Katipunan” (Alert, Katipunan) and Julian Felipe’s “Marcha Magdalo” (Magdalo March), which became the Philippine National Anthem. The most famous of all, the balse or waltz, is an Austrian dance in lilting triple time, an example of which is the famous waltz-song “AngMaya” (The Sparrow) composed in 1905 by the Filipino “Waltz King” JoseEstella.

 

The musical education and career of LadislaoBonus, the prominent 19th-century composer-conductor from Pandacan, gives us an idea of the range of experience of the Filipino secular musician. Outside of the church, the elite regimental band, and the colegios, no formal system for musical education existed. Bonus learned his skills by taking lessons from older musicians and by sitting in as assistant and apprentice player in the bands and orchestras that were often hired to accompany visiting zarzuela and opera troupes. In short, much of the music that Bonus learnt he absorbed in a community setting, as still happens in many parts of the country today. Eventually Bonus became a highly regarded contrabass player, versatile in other string instruments as well. E. Arsenio Manuel, in his Dictionary of Philippine Biography, noted that sometime in 1886 or 1887, an all-Filipino opera company was organized in Pandacan under Bonus’s directorship. Among the operas performed by the company were Lucrezia Borgia, Linda di Chamounix, Lucia di Lammermoor, La Traviata, and Fra Diavolo. Teodora San Luis was its prima donna. Other soloists included Josefa Tiongson, soprano; Victoria Medina, mezzo-soprano; Andres Ciria Cruz, Pedro Alcantara, and Alejo Natividad, tenors; Domingo Guanzon, baritone; and Eduardo Ciria Cruz and Jose Canseco (who doubled as stage director), basses.

 

Aside from the opera company, Bonus also directed the famous Orquesta Feminina de Pandacan, an all women’s ensemble immortalized in painting and lithograph by Simon Flores de la Rosa. Organized and managed by Raymundo Fermin, also known as “Maestrong Mundo” or “Mundong Bulag,” this unique group of singers and instrumentalists actively performed in Pandacan as well as in neighboring towns and provinces. Bonus was also known as a composer, his best-known work being the first full-length Filipino opera, SangdugongPanaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), which premiered in 1902, with libretto by PedroPaterno. Aside from Bonus, Julio Nakpil was another musical luminary, but unlike Bonus, Nakpil may have acquired his music knowledge and skills from the Matas who were organists at Quiapo Church.

 

Because there was no separation between church and state during the Spanish colonial period, the church and its clergy had direct control even of the secular musical culture of Filipinos. The parish curates approved what komedya was to play during fiestas where the popular songs of the day were played as incidental music for intermedios or intermissions. They also founded town musical organizations. Two famous examples of such curates were Fr Eliodoro Chico who produced the first generation of band musicians in Gapan, Nueva Ecija in the 1820s called Zabat Band, and Fr Cipriano Gonzales of Pandacan. Another priest named Jose Zamora even contributed to the advancement of the civic discourse in music by publishing a fundamental music theory tutor book in Tagalog, Breve Explicacion de los Principios Elementales de la Musica en Idioma Tagalog (Short Introduction to the Elementary Principles of Music in Tagalog), 1888, the only book of its kind in Philippine history. In the preface to the book, Fr Zamora justified the need for such a book, claiming that it was meant for the many musically illiterate indios in his midst, that is, Filipinos who played music oido or “by ear.” Music literacy in late 19th century quickly spread due to the rapid pace of urbanization in the colony and the rise in demand for band and orchestral music for social occasions. Musical skill became a form of cultural capital because there were so many bands and orchestras that needed performers capable of score and sight reading that such individuals found themselves in great demand.

 

As early as 1885, a musicians’ union—Union Artistica Musical—was in place. This was indicative of the already rich musical life of Philippine cities because the Union created a musicians’ code of ethics and regulated the amount of their salaries, a sign of the professionalization of the occupation. The reputation of the Filipino musician was so well-established that some of them had been contracted to augment the Shanghai Municipal Band earlier in the decade. Local orchestras did not only accompany visiting opera and zarzuela companies but also played in solemn masses during church feasts in both Intramuros and the churches in the arrabales such as Quiapo, Santa Cruz, Binondo, San Sebastian, San Miguel, Pandacan, and San Juan del Monte. In 1892, Albert Friedenthal noted that, “as musicians the inhabitants have won fame all over the Orient.” The district of Pandacan was known in the 19th century as “Little Italy” because of its many skilled musicians, musical troupes, and orchestras (Bañas 1969, 50).

 

The light classical 19th-century style spread into the far areas of Christian Philippines. European staples such as the balse, danza, and polka, as well as popular overtures like those from William Tell, El Anillo de Hierro (The Ring of Iron), and Poet and Peasant, were familiar to the rondalla and comparza, ensembles of string instruments. While the composition of these ensembles differed from place to place, they usually included the piccolo, bandurria, laud, octavina, guitar, bandola, and bajo de uñas.

 

Another ensemble that was to have considerable impact on the music of Spanish Philippines was the brass band. The first bands were organized to provide marching music for the military. In time, this music was also used for all the major civic parades and functions, religious festivals, and processions. As the band grew in popularity, civic organizations and even prominent families organized bands for their pleasure. At the serenata held on the eve of town fiestas, competing bands showed off their technical prowess and dexterity and their knowledge of band repertoire, which included marches and overtures from operas by famous Italian composers.

 

An indigenous offshoot of the brass band that deserves some mention is the musikongbumbong. According to local accounts, these groups were attempts by 19th-century nationalists and revolutionaries to create a uniquely Filipino sound. These attempts led to the creation of the all-bamboo ensembles organized along the lines of the marching band, playing music composed by Filipino composers. The members of the St Anthony Original Bamboo Band of Tonsuya, Malabon, Rizal are fourth-generation descendants of a band of Katipunero (Filipino revolutionary) musicians who organized a musikong bumbong ensemble in 1896. Their theme piece, Veteranos de la Revolucion (Veterans of the Revolution), attributed to an Amando Buencamino, was a typical example of the band music in vogue before the turn of the century.

 

The active careers of 19th-century Filipino musicians trained in Western classical music proved that at that time, the local music scene was already populated by individuals who were well-equipped to staff a musical establishment patterned after that of Spain and the rest of Europe. Aside from the instrumentalists, there was a growing number of skilled composers, increasingly well-versed in Western compositional techniques by the second half of the 19th century. This time though, not only did these composers write music for the church; they also wrote for the literary and musical publics comprised of the growing middle class whose members projected their status in society by buying compositions in the form of sheet music that they played on their pianos imported from Europe. By this time, pianos and violins became important instruments that marked social status. The proliferation of these instruments could be gleaned from the number of shops in Escolta and Quiapo that specialized in repairing the instruments. By the 1890s, Pio Trinidad had already fashioned the first Philippine piano, which was later exhibited in the 1904 St Louis Exposition.

 

During the last decades of the 19th century, there was a demand for sheet music from the urbanized population who cultivated their own knowledge of arts and culture as part of their urbanidad. The lithographic printer in Manila who printed the first sheet music in the country, the danza habanera “La Bella Filipina” mentioned in an earlier part of this essay, was the German businessman Oppel. In the 1870s, Fr Pedro Parra published a monumental four or five volume set of religious music, Manual Cantoral, for the liturgical and extraliturgical use of the Franciscans. A series of music compositions appeared in the La Lira Filipina magazine in the 1870s, although no copies have survived. The appearance of secular music in a literary periodical suggests the growing interest in music by subscribers living in a rapidly urbanizing Manila. By the 1870s, musical compositions for public consumption had become part of the local economy.

 

The most important music print from the last half of 19th century was Diego Perez’s 1886 piano medley, “Recuerdos de Filipinas” (Memories of the Philippines). Its importance lies in the fact that it paraphrased Philippine folk songs and dances—a proto-nationalistic attempt that was affected by the prevailing interest in folklore that journalists Jose Felipe Del Pan and Isabelo de los Reyes pursued in their own writing projects. This was followed by Julio Nakpil’s “Recuerdos de Capiz” (Memories of Capiz), which was so popular that it was reprinted five times by a French publisher. Dolores Paterno, a student of Perez, also printed “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) in 1878.

 

By the 1890s, the print music industry in Quiapo was already flourishing in the Philippines. Names like Chofre and Oliver y Trill became known. But there were other music publishing houses which were not named. “Jocelynang Baliuag” was believed to have been published in this manner and was circulated in 1896 in the form of sheet music. Aside from “Recuerdos de Capiz,” Nakpil composed “Salve Patria” (Save our Homeland), which was based on the Katipuneros’ anthem “MarangalnaDalitngKatagalugan“ (Noble Hymn of the Tagalog Region). The other prolific composer of print music was Jose Estella, who composed “La Tagala” (The Tagalog Woman), “Natalicio” (Birthday), and other popular works in cosmopolitan styles like the gavotte and the tanda de valses.

 

By the last quarter of the 19th century, the growing interest in local customs had kindled an interest in indigenous culture. Scholarly publications by European ethnologists and enthusiasts of Philippine culture such as Wenceslao Retana’s El Indio Batangueño (The Batangueño Indio) and Manuel Walls y Merino’s La Musica Popular de Filipinas (Popular Music of the Philippines) provided the first detailed picture of musical life in various parts of the archipelago. Later works by Philippine scholars included Pedro Paterno’s El Individuo Tagalo y Su Arte (The Tagalog People and Their Art) and Isabelo de los Reyes’s El Folklore Filipino (Filipino Folklore). Their combined efforts give us insights not only into the forms of Philippine music but the social practices that surrounded the performances of these indigenous forms. The pasyon, the kumintang, and the kundiman were among the most closely studied and described, but other dance songs such as the pandanggo and balitaw were also mentioned.

 

Efforts to incorporate local musical elements into original compositions continued well into the early 20th century, accelerating even more in production with the imposition of American capitalist rule. Utilizing local musical melodies, rhythms, and harmonies in an attempt to define and articulate a national music became a feature emulated by later scholars and composers. Fueled by such figures as Epifanio de los Santos and by the nationalist movement in the first half of the century, the preservation and documentation of the native music that had absorbed strong Spanish elements led to the writing of more and more art music based on these forms. In the 1920s and 1930s, composers such as NicanorS.Abelardo, FranciscoSantiago, FranciscoBuencamino, BonifacioAbdon, JuanS.Hernandez, and AntonioJ.Molina were to enshrine the kundiman and its related forms as the embodiment of Philippine music. “NasaanKa,Irog?” (Where Are You, My Love?) and “Pakiusap“ (Plea), both kundiman; “MutyangPasig“ (Muse of Pasig), a kumintang; and “Hatinggabi“ (Midnight), a danza habanera; and other so-called classics of the American period actually sprang from and were nurtured by an earlier time.

 

From the 1950s to the present, many Filipino composers of serious music have looked to lowland folk music for inspiration for their own compositions. Many of them built on the melodies of some famous songs such as Lucio D. San Pedro’s SuitePastorale, where the most famous piece, “SaUgoyngDuyan“ (As the Cradle Rocks), was inspired by an Angono lullaby; Bernardino Custodio’s “Pauli-uli” (Repetition), whose passacaglia was based on “BahayKubo” (Nipa Hut); Francisco Buencamino’s Mayon Concerto, whose principal theme was taken from “SarungBanggi “ (One Night); and Redentor Romero’s Philippine Portraits, which anthologized and interpreted several folk songs. Today, many of the regional folk songs have become popular beyond their places of origin. They have become part of the national song repertoire through choral renditions by vocal ensembles and choirs like the Mabuhay Singers and the Philippine Madrigal Singers; folk dance performances of the Bayanihan PhilippineDanceCompany and the RamonObusanFolkloricGroup which have incorporated songs into their dance suites; choral competitions where the usual repertoire includes Philippine ethnic and folksongs; radio and television programs which feature these songs in contests or as themes; and the physical education courses in the primary and secondary public schools where these songs are taught.

 

Epilogue

 

Nearly four centuries of Spanish rule brought irrevocable changes to Philippine music. European forms were introduced, taught, and imbedded in the Christianized Filipino’s consciousness and psyche. They did not remain simple transplants, for they were not only appropriated by the Filipinos and Filipinized but they were intricately woven into existing indigenous Asian sonic expressions that were organically forced to undergo the process of adaptation and Hispanization. These bidirectional intercultural strains have resulted in an exciting and dynamic soundscape that continues to flourish not only in the countryside that produced these hybrid folk musical forms, but also in the urban centers. These forms have become synonymous with the very identity of the contemporary Filipino who is heir to a rich colonial history.Written by Elena Rivera Mirano, u pdated by Jose S. Buenconsejo
