Section:

 

Historical Overview
Classical Music
Semiclassical Music
Popular Music

 

In 1898, Spain ceded its colonial sovereignty over the Philippine Islands to the United States by virtue of the Treaty of Paris. The American regime introduced a new form of government and economic supervision, established a system of public education, and developed a mass culture that promoted various forms of social entertainment.

 

In music, a new influence was introduced during the American colonial period from 1901 to 1946 that continues to be felt to the present. The American influence may be seen in the three types of music which evolved and gained adherence among various levels of Filipino audiences: 1) classical music, which includes both Western classical music and art music composed by Filipinos in the Western classical and modern idioms; 2) semiclassical music, which encompasses stylized folk songs, sarsuwela music, hymns and marches, and band and rondalla music; and 3) popular music, comprised mainly of music from the bodabil (Filipinized “vaudeville”) and the movies such as jazz, blues, and novelty songs, along with balitaw and kundiman, which were made accessible to the public through film, recording, print, and radio broadcasting. These categories of music are not entirely exclusive of one another, for even as they differ in form, style, and social function, they nevertheless share the same Western music language, musical contents, and composers. Thus, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Juan S. Hernandez, and Rodolfo S. Cornejo wrote concert pieces as well as music for the Filipino sarsuwela and dance halls.

 

Historical Overview

 

These Philippine musical forms evolved because of the conditions which provided the reason or context for musical creativity: the establishment of professional music schools which trained and produced musicians and artists of high caliber through formal programs of instruction; the introduction of formal music education in the public school system, which heightened the awareness for music as both artistic and social activity among the people; the proliferation of musical organizations and cultural institutions promoting musical activities and providing opportunities, incentives, and support to Filipino musicians in the fields of composition, performance, teaching, and research; the introduction of new musical idioms and the development of a taste for music related to American popular entertainment and mass culture; the crystallization of a nationalist ideology in music; the introduction of new perspectives and techniques in the study of indigenous musical cultures; and the intensification of printing which facilitated the dissemination of information on Philippine music and the spread of musical activities in Filipino homes.

 

Professional Music Schools. The professional training of Filipino musicians was given greater impetus with the institutionalization of the public educational system during the American colonial regime. The religious community still continued to dominate the operation of exclusive schools in the urban areas and centers of population. Except for the state-funded University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music opened in 1916, majority of the music schools were either part of sectarian colleges and universities or private academies. These include the School of Music of St Scholastica’s College which had its beginnings in 1906, the Academy of Music of Manila established in 1930, the Manila Conservatory of Music founded in 1934, and the Music Departments of the following colleges: Centro Escolar de Señoritas founded in 1907; Santa Isabel College which opened in 1930; Philippine Women’s University (PWU) organized in 1939, although music lessons were already being offered as early as 1925; Silliman University, established before World War II; St Paul College which opened in 1940; and the Philippine Conservatory of Music, an affiliate school of PWU, which operated only during the war years, 1943-4. Worth noting is the establishment of Escuela de Musica de Tabaco by Isidra Villanueva in Albay, 1910, and Academia Santa Cecilia by Lolita Heras in Manila, 1925. The last two signify the individual efforts of private citizens to propagate music education in the provinces in the early 20th century.

 

During the American colonial period, music training was no longer the exclusive purview of priests and nuns as it was during the Spanish period but was handled by outstanding Filipino musicians and professional European and American artists, not a few of whom stayed in the Philippines for extended periods of time. Some of the foreign pedagogues of the period were Wallace George, Guy Harrison, Robert Schofield, Alexander Lippay, Vladimir Elin, Wilma Hillberg, Vassily Prihodko, Edoardo Ferretto, Santino Coppa, Vincenzo Gambardella, Ciro Cavalieri, Josefina Gonzales Salvador, Sr Baptista Battig, OSB, Michael Wexler, Sergei Stupin, Carmen Kleinman, Henry Ore, Regina Feldman, Emma Moore, Julio Esteban Anguita, and Carmen Abella. Among the Filipino musicians who taught voice or instruments were Victorina Lobregat, Rosario Lopez, Jovita Fuentes, Rosita Sandejas, Antonino Buenaventura, Ernesto Vallejo, Rodolfo Cornejo, and Francisco Santiago.

 

Aside from instruction in vocal and instrumental performance, theory courses in harmony, counterpoint, and analysis were also emphasized in professional music schools. At the UP Conservatory of Music, these subjects were taught by both foreign and local personalities, including Guy Harrison, Carlyle Smith, Jeno von Takacs, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Juan S. Hernandez, and Antonino Buenaventura. Due to these developments, the Filipino-composed literature expanded from religious music, short instrumental pieces, kundiman, preludes, arias, and interludes for musical theaters, to such major forms as the opera, concerto, symphony, and sonata. A number of composers were able to study abroad to advance their creative skills such as Francisco Santiago, Nicanor S. Abelardo, and Rodolfo S. Cornejo.

 

 

 

Music Education in the Public Schools. The American colonial government made an effort to advance music literacy among the Filipinos by including the teaching of music in the curriculum of the public school system. Music was taught in relation to social values and the development of artistic consciousness and basic musical skills. In the early decades of the 20th century, music instruction was based mainly on the syllabus of the Progressive Music Series, with a special edition compiled by Norberto Romualdez and edited by Charles Griffith Jr intended for Philippine schools. The syllabus was in anthology form, containing songs and choruses from the folk song literature of various countries, classical works, and contributions by living American and Filipino composers. The songs were annotated and prescribed according to the needs of the different grade levels. The syllabus emphasized the development of skills in sight singing, and solo and choral singing, and aimed at the growth of the cognitive and affective faculties of the students.

 

Music Organizations and Institutions. Music societies and organizations with a variety of aims ranging from holding concerts and conferences to giving lessons in the different musical disciplines, as well as protecting the interests of music teachers, were known to have existed as early as the 1870s. Formed by professionally trained musicians, art patrons, and enthusiasts, the organizations multiplied and flourished during the American era, providing opportunities, incentives, and support for local musicians in the form of scholarships, competitions, concerts, and commissions.

 

 

Organizations founded before World War II include Centro Artistico, 1901; Centro de Bellas Artes, 1902; Monday Musical Club, 1902; Centro de Artistas, 1904; Philippine Musical Association, 1907; Club Euterpe, 1907; Artistico Literario, 1909; Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, 1907, 1919; Manila Chamber Music Society, 1921; Orfeon Filipino, 1921; Smiles Club, 1924; Philippine Philharmonic Association, 1925; Amihan Musical Society, 1927; Choral Art Association, 1930; Pro Arte Trio, 1933; National Federation of Music, 1933; the Philippine Cultural Concerts Society, 1935; Manila Music Lovers’ Society Inc., 1935; Philippine Society for Chamber Music, 1936; Philippine Society of Oriental Culture, 1940; Camia Musical Society, 1943; Peñaranda Music Lovers’ Society, 1946; Cabuyao Music Lovers’ Society, 1946; and Iloilo Musical Association. Except for the last three, all the groups were based in Manila. Many of these organizations sponsored and maintained specific musical groups such as orchestras, bands, and theater companies. The three groups considered to have contributed the most to Philippine musical arts in the 1930s were the Monday Musical Club, the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, and the Manila Chamber Music Society. Asociacion supported the Manila Symphony Orchestra from its founding by Alexander Lippay in 1926 until 1931, after which the orchestra was supported by the Manila Symphony Society.

 

The organizations also presented musical events that were mainly orchestral and choral concerts; piano, vocal, and chamber music recitals; and opera and other theatrical productions. These featured leading Filipino musicians, as well as renowned foreign artists and groups, mostly opera companies. The early years of the American occupation brought in visiting groups from the United States such as Charles Pollard’s American and English Comedy Company in 1908 and his Juvenile Comic Opera a few years before that. A number of opera companies from Europe, mainly from Italy and Spain, continued to present well-loved operas and they also introduced new works for the stage. From 1925-1930, the country welcomed various theater groups from Spain—Compania Viñas, Gonzales Opera Company, and Compania Iberia—and the Italian Opera Company from Italy. They staged operas, zarzuelas, and straight plays such as La Condeza de Montmartre (The Countess of Montmartre), Los Gavilanes (The Sparrowhawks), El Gato Montes (The Wild Cat), El Pajaro Azul (The Blue Bird), La Monteria (The Hunt), Venganza de Buena Ley (Revenge of the Good Act), El Pardon Municipal (Town’s Pardon), Exhumados Recuerdos (Exhumed Memories), and La Marcha de Cadiz (The March of Cadiz). Prominent instrumentalists and singers also performed in front of Filipino audiences in Manila, Iloilo, Cebu, and Silay. Among the celebrated foreign visitors were Australian soprano Pauline Bindley and her accompanist Ernest Empson in 1917; French-Canadian tenor Paul Dufault in 1917; organist Guy F. Harrison in 1918; American soprano Mary Jordan in 1925; Russian violinist Jascha Heifetz in 1927; violinist Cecilia Hassen and her husband-accompanist Boris Zahkaroff in 1928; soprano Galli Curci in 1929; Spanish tenor Miguel Fleta in 1929; Spanish guitarist Andres Segovia in 1929; French pianist Youra Guller in 1930; and violinist Michael Wexler in 1930. Harrison and Wexler eventually stayed in Manila for a few years to teach at the UP Conservatory of Music and the Academy of Music of Manila, respectively. A few choral groups also came over such as the Swiss Glee Club in 1927 and the Royal Russian Choir of Princess Slaviansky, which was organized in 1845 and embarked on their 77th annual tour of the world in 1928 by visiting the Philippines. A notable production was Manila Chamber Music Society’s staging of Aida by Verdi in the 1930s, with an all-Filipino cast and under the direction of Bonifacio Abdon, signaling the emancipation of Filipino productions from its dependence on foreign musicians.

 

The frequent venues for such performances were the Manila Grand Opera House, Colegio Medico Farmaceutico Building, Teatro Zorrilla, and the Casino Español. After its inauguration in 1931, the Metropolitan Theater on Plaza Lawton became the preferred venue for performances. However, the Met was severely damaged at the end of World War II.

 

 

Popular Entertainment. The most significant influence of American culture on Philippine musical life is reflected in the popular music movement, which catered to the growing need for entertainment and leisure of a mass audience. American institutions such as the dance hall (cabaret), vaudeville, radio, jukebox, cinema, and later on, the American Broadway theater and television, provided the mediums for disseminating jazz and various types of popular music which were mostly based on prevailing dance music styles and American theater-related songs. Filipinos readily accommodated the popular music culture not only by adopting the institutions and absorbing the American-made models but also by learning the performance practice then composing their own local versions of the different genres.

 

The kundiman, balitaw, danza, and other traditional forms continued to be popular since they were first noted by Manuel Walls in 1892. During the American occupation, these genres increasingly became mass-mediated and circulated through print, film, and radio. With the capitalist’s concern for profit, popular music truly became a commodity whose overall value was based not only on its artistic attributes but also on its potential to generate commercial and material profits.

 

 

 

Benefiting from the popularity of theater and its derivatives as the form of mass entertainment in the early years of the 20th century, American record producers such as William Anderson and Isaac Beck recorded well-loved kundiman and other song forms from the sarsuwela and bodabil. They established representative offices for US-based Victor Records and Columbia Records in the Philippines, and made the kundiman and other song forms available to the masses through recording. Eventually, these recordings were promoted through radio broadcasts from stations such as KZEG, KZIB, and KZRM. By the late 1930s, the movies overtook sarsuwela and bodabil in popularity, and soon after, songs from the movies became the repertoire for recording. Among the early Filipino recording artists were Maria Carpena, Victorino Carreon, Atang de la Rama, Katy de la Cruz, Vicente Ocampo, and Tinay Arellano. Odeon Records in Germany engaged famed Filipino opera singers who were in Europe taking advanced studies in voice in the late 1920s and early 1930s and pioneered the recording of Filipino folksongs in Europe. Jovita Fuentes recorded “Ay, Kalisud!” (Ah, Misery!) and Mercedes Matias recorded “Madaling Araw” (Dawn) and “Mutya ng Pasig” (Maiden of Pasig) for the Odeon label.

 

Nationalist Ideology in Music. The nationalist sentiment, which was nourished by the reform movement between 1882 and 1896 and the revolutionary movement from 1896 to 1901, resurfaced during the American regime. Philippine nationalism during this period manifested itself in two seemingly irreconcilable tendencies: the first, to affirm one’s unique identity as a people, and the second, to take pride in one’s ability to assimilate, master and replicate the forms imposed by the colonial regime. In music, Filipino composers continued to master the techniques of writing classical Western music even as they sought to assert their cultural identity and repudiate the symbols of colonial subservience.

 

During World War II, the Japanese exploited the issue of nationalism in Philippine music by promoting Filipino musicians and their works, and indoctrinating the public on the evils of Anglo-American music, more specifically American jazz and popular music. The most prominent Filipino composer during the Japanese occupation was Felipe Padilla de Leon, who was tasked by the Imperial Army to compose the music for the award-winning poem of Catalino S. Dionisio, “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Filipinas” (Song for the Creation of A New Philippines) in 1942. The music de Leon wrote, better known as “Tindig, Aking Inang Bayan” (Stand Up, My Mother Country), was regarded as the national song of the Philippines during the Japanese period. He was tasked to compose two more songs: “Day-atiw ng Kalibapi,” the official march of the Kapisanan sa Paglilingkod sa Bagong Filipinas (Organization for Serving the New Philippines), 1943, and “Awit ng Magdaragat” (Song of the Fisherman), 1944.

 

Realizing the importance of religion in the life of the Filipinos, the Japanese used it to advance their propaganda by forming the Catholic Unit of the Religious Section, a branch of the Japanese Propaganda Corps of the Imperial Japanese Army. A landmark religious occasion of this time was the celebration of a commemorative mass for the Venerable Lord Justus Ukon Takayama, a Japanese feudal lord who refused to renounce his Christian faith and who was consequently exiled to Manila in the 17th century where he died in 1615. The mass, which was held at the St Vincent de Paul Church on 20 Sep 1942, was aired on KZRH radio station to all the nations that comprised the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere to herald a new period of cooperation between the Imperial Army and American and Filipino church authorities. The commemorative mass was marked by the singing of two Japanese nationalistic hymns “Nippon Zyunkyosya No Uta” (Hymn of Japanese Martyrdom) and “Umi Yukada” (Yukada Sea) by the seminarians of San Carlos Seminary who were later joined by the entire congregation.

 

The Study of Indigenous Philippine Music. Scholarship in the field of culture and the arts was given due attention under the educational and literacy programs of the United States government. It is interesting to note that one of the associations formed during the American colonial regime was the Philippine Society of Oriental Culture. Founded in 1940, one of its aims was to “enrich our own music, painting, sculpture, and the body of our literary heritage from the past by studying our own and by drawing from other cultures” (Bañas 1975, 165). Initial efforts were made by foreign scholars, mostly anthropologists, who also showed great interest in the music cultures of the non-Christian Filipinos. Some of them were missionaries assigned to Christianize indigenous communities. Among them were Fay Cooper Cole, Albert E. Jenks, Otto Scheerer, James Alexander Robertson, Roy F. Barton, Dean Worcester, and Henry Otley Beyer. One of the first serious attempts at analyzing Philippine indigenous music was made by Frances Densmore who came to the conclusion that the music of the Philippine Aeta represents what could be the oldest forms of musical expression in the world. The study was made in connection with the St Louis Exposition of 1904, where native Filipinos were made to present various aspects of their indigenous music and other aspects of their cultural traditions. On the same occasion, the Philippine Constabulary Band wowed American audiences by displaying their musical versatility and a high standard of performance of Western classical music.

 

Two important compilations of extensive researches on the Philippines by American scholars were Emma Helen Blair and James A. Robertson’s 55-volume Philippine Islands, 1493-1898 published from 1903-9, and Wenceslao Emilio Retana’s three-volume Aparato Bibliografico de la Historia General de Filipinas (Bibliographic Apparatus of the General History of the Philippines) printed in 1906. Filipinos also undertook serious research on Philippine folklore and traditional music at the turn of the 20th century. Interest in the study of folklore and ethnologies among Filipinos began in the late 1880s with Pedro Paterno and Isabelo de los Reyes’s attempts to highlight the precolonial civilization of the Philippines in publications that came out during the propaganda movement led by the ilustrado (educated). The research works included Paterno’s La Antigua Civilizacion Tagalog (The Old Tagalog Civilization), 1887, and Los Itas (The Aeta), 1890; and de los Reyes’s Filipinas: Articulos Varios Sobre Etnografia, Historia y Costumbres del Pais (Philippines: Various Articles on the Ethnography, History and Traditions of the Country), 1887, and El Folk-Lore Filipino (Philippine Folklore), 1889. Initial studies such as these reverberated in the later examinations of traditional cultures and musical circumstances of their time by scholars such as Fernando Canon, Alfredo Roa, Epifanio de los Santos, Norberto Romualdez, Francisco Santiago, Antonio Molina, and Raymundo Bañas during the first half of the 20th century.

 

Fernando Canon published his article “Kuriapi” in Cultura Filipina Revista Mensua Artes I Ciencias in 1910, delivered a lecture titled “La Musica Filipina en Filipinas” in 1921, and printed his article “Philippine Music in the Philippines” in the 22 Jun 1921 issue of La Vanguardia (The Vanguard). Alfredo Roa wrote a three-article series featuring the biographies of Filipino musicians and composers of his time titled “De Nuestra Musica y Nuestros Musicos” (Of Our Music and Our Musicians), 1927. Epifanio de los Santos published “Literatura Tagala” (Tagalog Literature) in 1909, and “Folk-Lore Musical de Filipinas” after 1914. In 1931, Judge Norberto Romualdez presented his collection of Philippine indigenous instruments as well as transcriptions of some native songs in a public lecture at UP. Antonio J. Molina and Francisco Santiago, the first Filipino director of the UP Conservatory of Music, also contributed essays on folk music. Raymundo Bañas’ The Music and Theater of the Filipino People, 1924, presented the various facets of Philippine musical culture of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In the summers of 1934 to 1938, a research team composed of composer Antonino Buenaventura, dancer Francisca Reyes-Tolentino, and her husband photographer Ramon Tolentino recorded the folk music and dances from the different parts of the archipelago under a cultural committee organized and mandated by UP president Jorge Bocobo. The collected materials were later stylized in folk dance productions for the UP Folk Song and Dance Group by Buenaventura and Reyes-Tolentino according to existing norms of Western music and dance. The wealth of information on Philippine native music that was realized through these researches opened fresh musical perspectives and offered new possibilities in the modern Filipino’s search for a cultural identity in the interest of nationalism. The collected data did not only provide musical materials for use in new compositions but were also sources of musical thought that were rooted in the traditional Asiatic cultures of the Filipinos.

 

Printing and Dissemination of Philippine Music. The dissemination of Philippine music and music scholarship was accelerated through printing, particularly through the daily newspapers, periodic journals, pamphlets, and books. Newspaper articles on music included announcements of musical events, feature articles on musicians, new compositions, criticism, pictures, and serialized versions of long documents pertaining to music. Jose Felipe del Pan opened his Imprenta de la Oceania Española in the late 19th century, and Isabelo de los Reyes’s printing press published daily newspapers such as La Lectura Popular (The Popular Reading) and El Ilocano (The Ilokano). Their printing presses were active until the first decades of the 20th century. Other important newspapers during the American period were La Opinion, El Debate, La Vanguardia, El Renacimiento, El Pueblo, Taliba, Philippine Herald, The Tribune, and The Manila Times.

 

Many new music pieces were also printed during this time, bringing the works of Filipino composers into the homes of music enthusiasts. Printed pieces for piano solo, voice and piano, chamber music, and choral music proliferated and were distributed by music stores such as La Lira Almacen de Musica in Escolta, owned by Blas Echegoyen. Coupled with the popularity of the piano, guitar, and harp as household instruments, the availability of printed sheet music created an encouraging atmosphere for amateur music-making in Manila and contributed to the unprecedented advancement of music during the American period.

 

Classical Music

 

When the Americans took over the reins of the Philippine government, they found a vibrant cultural life that was characterized by a highly Westernized artistic environment. Filipino painters, writers, and musicians had already learned the techniques of producing worthy replicas of European art forms during the Spanish period. In music, Filipino performers—singers, instrumentalists, and conductors—were already active in the performances of Western zarzuela and operas being staged by visiting foreign companies, even as the Filipino sarsuwela were already being written, composed, and produced by Filipinos.

 

Western Classical Music. The influence of European classical music was made stronger by visits of individual foreign artists before and after the American occupation. The more notable visitors included violinists Agustin Rubio who was a pupil of Nicolo Paganini, Eduardo Remenyi, Mischa Elman, guitarist Andres Segovia, pianist-composer Rudolf Friml, and cellists Regina Feldman and Pierre Fournier. At the same time, a number of Filipino musicians that included Jovita Fuentes, Isang Tapales, Ramon Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, Conchita Gaston, Mercedes Matias, Federico Elizalde, and Luis Valencia achieved prominence abroad. Recitals and concerts featured mostly European music from the Baroque, Classical, and Romantic periods, while serious music theater leaned towards the operas of Giuseppe Verdi (Aida, Il Trovatore, La Traviata), Giacomo Puccini (Madame Butterfly, La Boheme), Gaetano Donizetti (Lucia di Lammermoor), Georges Bizet (Carmen), and Pietro Mascagni (Cavalleria Rusticana).

 

Filipino Works in Western Classical Idiom. At the beginning of the 20th century, Filipino composers took pride in having cultivated the ability to write operas, symphonies, and concertos—symbols of European high art in the field of music. A survey of the literature written in the first half of the 20th century shows that the treatment of the standard classical forms was basically programmatic or descriptive. The abstract aspects of Western music were hardly explored. Only a few symphonies in the traditional three- to four-movement formats were actually written. Among these are Jose Estella’s Filipinas Symphony, 1928; Francisco Santiago’s Taga-ilog Symphony (From the River Symphony), 1938; and Rodolfo Cornejo’s The Allies Symphony, 1943. Nicanor S. Abelardo wrote Sinfonniette in 1932 and left a symphony unfinished due to his untimely death in 1934. A few of the symphonic works in concerto form included Abelardo’s Concerto in B-flat Minor, 1923; Santiago’s Concerto in B-flat Minor, 1924; Hernandez’s Piano Concerto in D Minor, 1939; and Cornejo’s First Piano Concerto in D Minor, 1933.

 

One-movement orchestral works proliferated and they came in the form of overtures, symphonic poems, suites, and fantasies. Examples of these short symphonic works include Antonino Buenaventura’s Concert Overture, 1930, By the Hillside, 1941, Pag-asa Symphonic Poem (Hope Symphonic Poem), 1943, and Youth, 1946; Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Cinderella Overture, 1931; Jose Estella’s Ultimo Adios Symphonic Poem (Last Farewell Symphonic Poem), 1927; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Banner of Victory, 1939, Mariang Makiling Overture, 1939, Mga Katutubong Tanawin (Native Scenes), 1939, Bataan, 1947, and Banyuhay (New Life), 1947; Lucio San Pedro’s The Devil’s Bridge, 1937, Malakas at Maganda Overture (The Strong and the Beautiful Overture), 1937, and Hope and Ambition, 1946; Antonio Molina’s Oras ng Gabing Mangitngit (The Hour of Darkest Night), 1937, and Kundiman-Kundangan (If Not For-Because Of), 1939; Lucino Sacramento’s Concert Overture in A minor, 1934, and Tayo Na sa Langit (Let Us Go to Heaven), 1939; Hilarion Rubio’s Florante at Laura Overture (Florante and Laura Overture), 1933, The Elements, 1940; Bernardino Custodio’s Malayan Suite, 1932; and Rodolfo Cornejo’s Oriental Fantasy, 1944. A few orchestral works combined vocal parts and choruses such as Antonino Buenaventura’s Ode to the Filipino Heroes, 1934; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Banyuhay, 1947; and Lucino Sacramento’s Gamugamo (Mayfly), 1934.

 

An important addition to the symphonic poem genre was the seven-part cycle composed for the 15th death anniversary of Jose Rizal on 30 Dec 1911. Pablo Ocampo, the manager of the Rizal Day celebration of 1911, commissioned seven composers to write descriptive orchestral music to be premiered at the Manila Grand Opera House. The result was the following seven symphonic poems: Rizal en el Alba de la Vida (Rizal at the Dawn of Life) by Francisco Buencamino; Rizal Bajo el Manto de Minerva (Rizal under the Cloak of Minerva) by Crispino Reyes Mijares; Rizal Sobre el Pegaso (Rizal on Pegasus) by Tereso Zapata; Rizal Cruzado de la Patria (Rizal Crusader of the Country) by Juan Hernandez; Rizal en Las Tristezas de Dapitan (Rizal in the Sorrows of Dapitan) by Gavino Carluen; Rizal en Su Ultima Noche (Rizal on His Last Night) by Antonio Escamilla; and Rizal Glorificado (Rizal Glorified) by Marcelo Adonay.

 

Another genre favored by the Filipino composers was chamber music. Works in this genre included Francisco Santiago’s String Quartet in G Major, 1924, and Remembrance for Violin, Cello and Piano, 1930; Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Visayan Caprice for Violin, Cello and Piano, 1930, Sonata for Violin and Piano, 1931, and Sonata for String Quartette, 1932; Antonino Buenaventura’s Children’s String Quartet, 1934; Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s Sonata for Violin and Piano, 1932, Cello Sonata, 1932, String Quartet, 1944, and Piano Quintet, 1945; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Night Dreams, 1939, Serenity, 1939, and Serenade, 1944; Lucio D. San Pedro’s Melody in G for Violin and Piano, 1937, and Romance in A Major for Cello and Piano, 1937; Antonio Molina’s String Quartet, 1925, Preludio for Cello and Piano, 1928, Romanza, 1928, and Rondo en Fa, 1928; Hilarion Rubio’s Salamisim, 1933, and Prelude and Fugue for String Quartet, 1934; Lucino Sacramento’s Souvenir, 1934, Tu Es Petrus for Two Violins, 1937, Andante and Caprice for Filipino Themes for Two Violins, 1938; Bernardino Custodio’s Serenade for Violin, Cello and Piano, 1932; Pedro Navarro’s Divertissement for Bb Clarinet, 1929, Saxophone Duet: Olivia-Floring, 1930, and Clarinet Duet: Tansing-Poleng, 1930; and Amada Santos Ocampo’s Romance in G for Violin and Piano, 1943.

 

The popularity of the piano as a household instrument also paved the way for numerous multi-movement compositions and miniature works catering to both the serious music student and the proficient amateur player. Numerous solo piano pieces composed included Rodolfo Cornejo’s Piano Sonata, 1929; Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Sonata in G Major, 1921, “First Nocturne,” 1921, and “Valse in D Flat,” 1922; Antonio Molina’s “Scherzo in D,” 1923, “Impressiones,” 1927, “Malikmata” (Phantasm), 1939, “A Dove Came Down in Sunshine,” 1941, “Camia,” 1942, and “Dancing Fool,” 1942; Lucino Sacramento’s “Prelude and Fugue,” 1934, “A Song Without Words,” 1934, and “Romance in B flat,” 1939; Amada Santos Ocampo’s Piano Sonata in D Flat, 1942, “Impromptu,” 1942, and “Romance in G,” 1943; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s “Sayaw ng Igorot” (Igorot Dance), 1939, “To a Flower,” 1942, and “Song of the Bamboo,” 1943; and Lorenzo Ilustre’s “Recuerdo a Un Amor” (Memory of a Beloved), 1900, “Jota Rizal,” “Banahaw,” “Funebre” (Funeral March), “Rosal Danza,” and “Tagala Batangueña” (Batangas Lady), ca 1920.

 

The appropriation of Western forms by American-educated Filipino composers such as Abelardo, Santiago, and Cornejo drastically changed the listening habits of the Filipino people. Classicism was introduced to the masses through large orchestral works such as symphonies and concertos, as well as through miniature piano pieces that echoed well-loved Romantic favorites such as Chopin and Debussy. The audience started to appreciate long concerts that featured abstract instrumental music as an alternative to the more popular sarsuwela and bodabil. It was also a period when the kundiman was elevated into an art form through the delicate marriage of poetry and music in the works of Filipino composers such as Bonifacio Abdon, Nicanor S. Abelardo, and Francisco Santiago and their lyricists like Jose Corazon de Jesus and Deogracias A. Rosario. Through their works, this particular song genre developed into the classical kundiman. Representing a high point in musical romanticism and chromatic harmonic writing, the kundiman art song was exemplified by Abelardo’s “Nasaan Ka Irog?” (Where Are You My Love?), 1923, “Kundiman ng Luha” (Kundiman of Tears), 1924, “Magbalik Ka Hirang” (Come Back, My Love) and “Pahimakas” (Last Farewell), 1925, and “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig), 1926; and Santiago’s “Kundiman” (Love Song), 1917, “Pakiusap” (Plea), 1921, “Ang Pag-ibig” (Love), 1922, and “Alaala Kita” (I Remember You), 1929.

 

The large repertoire of music for stage included major operas and operettas like Ladislao Bonus’ Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), 1902; Jose Estella’s Veni, Vidi, Vici (I Came, I Saw, I Conquered), 1904; Gavino Carluen’s Gayuma (Love Potion), 1902; and Rodolfo Cornejo’s operetta, Together, 1937.

At the same time that the nationalist movement in Philippine music was being realized mainly through works in chromatic harmony, developments in European and American contemporary music also reached the consciousness of several Filipino composers. Early contact with 20th-century music was made through the few local musicians who trained in the West, as well as foreign teachers and artists who came to settle or worked in the Philippines. The music of important Western composers such as Stravinsky, De Falla, Prokofiev, Ravel, Debussy, Shostakovitch, and Khatchaturian gradually found their place in recital and concert programs, in spite of some resistance on the part of teachers and audiences.

 

Nicanor S. Abelardo, upon his return from his studies in the United States, was the first to break away from traditional musical idioms and to apply a new harmonic language in his landmark compositions Cinderella Overture, Sinfonietta for Strings, Panoramas, and other works written in and after 1931. Abelardo’s modern style of writing showed the strong influence of the expressionist school of Arnold Schoenberg, characterized by ambiguous tonalities, long-drawn and disjunct melodic lines, and polyrhythmic structures. His early death in 1934 prevented what could have been an earlier spread of modernism in Philippine art music. Having established himself as a highly respected pedagogue, Abelardo could have very easily disseminated knowledge of modern music to his disciples. In the years immediately following the death of Abelardo, a number of compositions were written with some elements of early 20th-century idioms. Highly precipitous rhythms and dissonances were used by Ramon Tapales in the “Savage Dance” of his Philippine Suite, 1937. Ambiguous and dissonant tonalities were also used by Antonio J. Molina in his piano pieces “Malikmata” (Phantasm), 1939, and “Dancing Fool,” 1942, while impressionist tonal structures served as main texture materials in Antonino Buenaventura’s symphonic works Rhapsodietta on a Manobo Theme, 1937, By the Hillside, 1941, and Youth, 1946. In these works, however, the modern elements were used more as coloristic dressing and programmatic effects rather than as part of an acquired language.

 

Semiclassical Music

 

Filipino popular music of the 20th century covers a wide range of forms: folk songs, music from the Filipino theater and films, songs and ballads, band music, rondalla music, and the newly introduced American song and dance genres such as jazz, blues, Charleston, and fox-trot. They were made popular through the most common form of entertainment during the American period: theater, film, and radio. With the exposure of the mass audiences to entertainment music of various types, Philippine popular music became a major industry and a source of commercial profit for entrepreneurs and musicians alike. This body of music was widely disseminated in lowland centers of population and was usually heard in semiformal musical events like open-air concerts, programs, parades, singing contests, in the electronic media, and, on rare occasions, in formal concerts.

 

Folk Songs. The field collection of folk songs undertaken in the 1920s and the 1930s yielded a substantial body of regional songs from different language groups all over the country. Initially transcribed in Western staff notation, many of these were arranged for chorus and published as educational materials for the school system. These songs were later popularized in musical performances that called for native music, including folk dance presentations. One of the first anthologies that contained Filipino folk songs was the Progressive Music Series, where traditional tunes such as “Comintang de la Conquista” (Comintang of the Conquest) and “Cachucha” were harmonized by Norberto Romualdez. The book also contained songs with named composers such as “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) attributed to Dolores Paterno and “Nena’s Lullaby” by Francisco Buencamino.

 

Music for Theater. Early Philippine theater forms such as the komedya and the sarsuwela served as sources of light entertainment music. Although music played an incidental role in the komedya, it nevertheless fulfilled certain functions—providing an overture; accompanying the dances, fight scenes, entrances and exits of principal personalities; providing background to sentimental scenes; and breaking the monotony of the straight dialogue format with some sung parts. Instrumental ensembles such as the comparza (plucked instruments) or a small band of wind instruments and drums always complemented komedya productions. Signature music for the choreographed battle between Christians and Muslims was the “Himno de Riego,” a march in 6/8 time which was continuously repeated until the fight was over.

 

The Spanish zarzuela was adapted in the Tagalog region as well as in other parts of the country like Pampanga, Ilocos, Bicol, and the Visayas. Early regional works included Mariano Pabalan’s Ing Managpe (The Patcher), 1900; Vicente Sotto’s Gugma sa Yutang Natawhan (Love for the Native Land), 1901; Valente Cristobal’s Ang Capitan (The Captain), 1902; Asisclo Jimenez’s Pagkamoot sa Banuang Tinoboan (Lover for the Native Land), 1907; Mena Pecson Crisologo’s Codigo Municipal (Municipal Code), 1908; and Jose Ma. Ingalla’s Dinaguit (Kidnapped), 1910. Some of the Tagalog sarsuwela written from 1900 to the 1930s included Pantaleon Lopez’s Masamang Kaugalian (Bad Customs), 1901, and Ang Ynferno (Hell), 1903; Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1902, Minda Mora (Minda, the Muslim Girl), 1904, Filipinas para los Filipinos (The Philippines for the Filipinos), 1905, and Ang Puso ng Isang Filipina (The Heart of a Filipino Woman), 1923; Maximino de los Reyes’s Dahas ng Pilak (The Violence of Silver), 1905; Aurelio Tolentino’s Sumpaan (Oath), 1904, and Ang Sulo y Yebana (The Torch and the Cigar), 1909; Patricio Mariano’s Unang Binhi (First Seedling), 1912, and Anak ng Dagat (Child of the Sea), 1921; Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (In the Jaws of the Shark), 1921; and Hermogenes Ilagan’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1917, and Buhay ng Himala’t Kababalaghan (Life of Miracles and Mysteries), 1923.

 

Music for these sarsuwela was written by composers such as Bonifacio Abdon, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Jose Estella, Juan Hernandez, Leon Ignacio, Crispino Reyes, Fulgencio Tolentino, Gavino Carluen, and Hipolito Rivera. Some of the outstanding songs and airs came from Abdon’s Luha at Dugo (Tears and Blood), 1901, and Tulisan (Bandit), 1901; Abelardo’s Dakilang Punglo (Noble Bullet), 1926; Estella’s Filipinas para los Filipinos, 1905; Hernandez’s Minda Mora; Ignacio’s Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920, and Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1926; Reyes’s Ang Tatlong Bituin (The Three Stars); Tolentino’s Walang Sugat, and Ang Kalupi (The Wallet), 1902; and Felipe Padilla de Leon’s At Sa Wakas (And at the End), 1928, Hiram Lamang (Borrowed Only), 1929, Busog at Palaso (Bow and Arrow), 1935, Ang Ating Bukas (Our Future), 1942, Mataas na Lipunan (High Society), 1942, Dakilang Ina (Great Mother), 1942, and Malapit na Ang Umaga (Morning is Almost Here), 1942.

Popular leading ladies of the sarsuwela of the pre-war era were Casiana de Leon, Titay Molina, Estanislawa San Miguel, Maria Carpena, Juanita Angeles, and Atang de la Rama.

 

Toward the 1920s, two alternative forms of entertainment took over the popularity of sarsuwela: the bodabil and the talking picture. The bodabil was an entertaining variety show that featured brassy American songs, dances, comedy skits, and circus acts, while the talking picture presented melodramas, comedies, and musicals in a new form featuring a motion picture with synchronized sound. By the 1930s, many film studios were founded, among which were Filippine Films, Parlatone Hispano-Filipino, Sampaguita Pictures, LVN Pictures, and X’Otic Films.

 

During the Japanese occupation, there was an attempt to revive the then moribund zarzuela to offset the Japanese ban on Anglo-American entertainment music. However, the productions were mostly Spanish zarzuelas with the exception of the propaganda-oriented skits of Felipe Padilla de Leon known as “Gindula.”

Songs and Ballads. Songs originating from the Filipino sarsuwela were able to survive the sarsuwela’s gradual demise during the American regime and served as models for the development of the classical kundiman as well as a light repertoire of vocal music for radio, phonograph, and cinema. The popularity of these songs stemmed not only from the amount of exposure they enjoyed in the media, but also from a structural simplicity that made the music easy even for amateur musicians to perform. The latter repertoire was characterized by dance-oriented rhythms like those of the balse, tango, balitaw, danza, and fox-trot. The melodies were lyrical yet simple, sometimes folk song-like; and their lyrics were in traditional 19th century Tagalog style.

 

A few of the well-loved sarsuwela arias which became popular included Jose Estella’s “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow) from Filipinas para los Filipinos; Leon Ignacio’s “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Clay Jar Was Broken) from Dalagang Bukid; Abelardo’s “Bituing Marikit” (Beautiful Star) from Dakilang Punglo; and Juan S. Hernandez’s “Amadha” from Minda Mora. Other composers who wrote light versions of the kundiman included Jose Canseco Jr, Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Santiago, Francisco Buencamino, Fulgencio Tolentino, and Ramon Corpuz—all identified with both the sarsuwela and the kundiman literatures.

Even as American films were driving the Filipino sarsuwela off the stage, the sarsuwela emigrated from the stage to the movies, as seen in the movie versions of famous sarsuwela like Ang Mahiwagang Binibini (The Mysterious Lady) which was an adaptation of Ang Kiri, and in original sarsuwela-type film musicals like Pakiusap (Plea). Producers also borrowed the titles of songs from popular sarsuwela for their films to attract the mass audience. Among these films were Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1939; Ay, Kalisud! (Ah, Misery!), 1938; Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939; and Pakiusap, 1940.

 

Philippine cinema from the 1920s to the 1940s generated a large number of popular songs such as Norberto Romualdez’s “El Mensaje” (The Message) from the movie Dalisay (Pure); Tito Arevalo’s “Magandang Bituin” (Beautiful Star) from Estrellita; Constancio de Guzman’s “Azucena” from the movie of the same title; “Bakit Mo Ako Pinaluluha?” (Why Do You Make Me Cry?) from Ay, Kalisud!; “Binatang Bukid” (Young Man From the Farm) and “Langit ang Magmahal” (Heaven is to Love) from Takip-silim (Dusk); and “Halina’t Magsaya” (Come and Celebrate) from Lambingan (Tender Affection); Juan Silos Jr’s “Giliw Ko” (My Love) and “Ikaw ang Buhay” (You Are My Life) from Giliw Ko, and “Maligayang Araw” (Happy Days) from Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory); Santiago Suarez’s “Bagong Sinderela” (New Cinderella), “Bulalakaw” (Comet), and “Ikaw pa Rin” (It’s Still You) from Diwa ng Awit (Essence of the Song); “Magbabakya” (Wooden Clog Maker) from Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng); “Dungawin Mo Hirang” (Look Down From the Window, Beloved) from Walang Sugat; Mike Velarde’s “Dahil Sa Iyo” (Because of You) from Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star) and “Taga-bukid” (Native of the Farm) from Pakiusap; and Josefino Cenizal’s “Amihan Sa Bukid” (Country Breeze) from Dolorosa. The songs were sung and popularized by movie idols such as Elsa Oria, Rudy Concepcion, Fely Vallejo, and Teddy Benavides.

 

Patriotic songs as well as commemorative and institutional hymns were also part of the general repertoire to which many composers contributed. Juan S. Hernandez’s “Canto Patriotico de Maria Clara” (Maria Clara’s Patriotic Song), 1907; Francisco Buencamino Jr’s “En el Bello Oriente” (In the Beautiful Orient), 1909; Antonio J. Molina’s “Lamentos de Mi Patria” (Laments of My Fatherland), 1913; Constancio de Guzman’s “Bayan Ko” (My Country), 1928; and Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Sa Lupang Sarili” (On One’s Own Land), 1940, were just a few of the hundreds of songs and hymns that have been written expressing patriotic or nationalist sentiments. Some examples of commemorative hymns, on the other hand, were Antonino Buenaventura’s “Philippines Triumphant,” 1936; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s “National Heroes’ Day Hymn,” 1936, “Sa Mga Bayani ng Lahi” (To the Heroes of the Race), 1945, and “Manuel L. Quezon,” 1945; and Hilarion Rubio’s “National Heroes Day Hymn,” 1934. Institutional hymns included Nicanor S. Abelardo’s classic “UP Beloved,” 1917; Antonino Buenaventura’s “Arellano University March,” 1947; and Hilarion Rubio’s “Narra, Our National Tree: School Song,” 1940, and “Ang Magsasaka: School Song,” 1940. A hymn for the suffragette movement is Luis Borromeo’s “Votad,” ca 1936.

 

Instrumental Music. Philippine band music has become an integral part of the life of lowland Christian communities. Tracing its roots to the regimental music in the Spanish garrisons, the local band has become an indispensable feature in military affairs, town fiestas, and other community events. Its extensive repertoire includes music for parades, folk theater like the komedya and sinakulo, social dancing in town plazas and cabarets, religious and funeral processions, as well as indoor and outdoor concerts. A particular band’s musical prowess is tested during competitions in the traditional serenatas that are held within the nine-day period before the actual celebration of a town fiesta. In this competition, the depth of one’s repertoire in terms of quantity and degree of difficulty receives equal rating as the musical and artistic quality of the performance. A standard concert program usually includes marches for warming up, concert overtures, medleys of folk songs or popular tunes, character pieces, concertante compositions (with soloist/s), and symphonic works. The latter are usually band adaptations of well-known orchestral pieces by Western composers like R. Wagner’s Tannhauser Overture, G. Rossini’s William Tell, F. von Suppe’s Light Cavalry Overture. In some instances, an enterprising band would attempt to play formidable works such as Dimitri Shostakovitch’s Symphony No. 5.

 

The Philippine band as an institution produced hundreds of outstanding musicians during the American regime. The Philippine Constabulary Band under General Walter S. Loving received the highest accolades at the St Louis Exposition in 1904 and was later invited to play during the inauguration of Pres William Taft in 1909 and at the Panama Canal Exposition in 1915. During the American period, weekly concerts at the public parks such as Luneta and Binondo were given by the Philippine Constabulary Band and the 7th and the 30th Infantry Bands. Right up to the 1920s, they were performing standard band repertoire from Western composers, ending their program with the playing of the “Star Spangled Banner.” By 1925, works of Filipino composers began to be included in their repertoire such as Pedro Navarro’s “Olimpia,” 1925, “Enharmonica Chromatica March,” 1927, and “Resident Commissioner Osias March,” 1929; Lakandazon’s “Rhapsodical Overture,” 1925, and “Atong Awit: Visayan Folk Dances,” 1926; and Antonio Escamilla’s “Philippine Airs,” 1927.

 

During the same time, civilian bands proliferated in towns all over the country. Some of the outstanding ensembles that flourished at the turn of the century were the Zabat Band, the Peñaranda Band of Nueva Ecija, the Pasig Band, and the Banda Arevalo. The Banda Arevalo, founded by Bonifacio Arevalo and based in Quiapo, was reported to have received a compensation of 2,000 dollars per month in 1904 as it was alternating with the 7th and 30th Infantry Bands and the Philippine Constabulary Band in rendering concerts at the Luneta Park.

 

It should be noted that many of the classical music composers received early musical training as band members or as members of a band musician’s family. Prominent among them were Alfredo S. Buenaventura, Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Hilarion F. Rubio, Lucino T. Sacramento, Lucio D. San Pedro, and Rosendo Santos. Local composers wrote many Philippine marches commemorating the important events in the country’s political history. These included Julio Nakpil’s “Salve Patria” (Save the Homeland), 1903, and “Victory March,” 1944; Lorenzo Ilustre’s “Imno al Recibimiento de los Restos del Apolinario Mabini” (Hymn at the Reception of the Remains of Apolinario Mabini), 1921; Antonino Buenaventura’s “Triumphal March,” 1930; Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Triumphal March,” 1937, “Martsa ng Bagong Pilipinas” (March of the New Philippines), 1942, and “Victory in Parade,” 1943; and Felipe Padilla de Leon’s “Magiliw” (Affectionate) Symphonic March, 1947.

 

Larger works for band consisted mostly of concert overtures, concertante pieces, tone poems, and even symphonies like Lucio D. San Pedro’s Overture in B-flat Major, 1935; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Fantasy for Trombone and Band, 1932; and Antonino Buenaventura’s Echoes from the Philippines, 1938, Dedication, 1940, and The Corps on Parade, 1941.

 

Aside from the bands, another favorite ensemble among the native musicians for light classical music playing was the rondalla, a group consisting of plectrum instruments which evolved from the Spanish murga (band of street musicians) and the estudiantina (student musical groups). During the American period, it was more popularly known as the comparza and it was made up of five to six plucked string varieties, which included the bandurria, octavina, laud, guitar, and double bass. The comparza’s wide repertoire ranged from native folk tunes and ballroom music to classical pieces, including operatic overtures. Early pieces for the rondalla repertoire included the “Romance” from Saint-Saëns’ Samson and Delilah; H. von Tizler’s “All Alone,” and Czibulka’s “A Dream After the Ball.” Locally composed and adapted pieces consisted of marches and folk songs like “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly), “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), “Lawiswis Kawayan” (Murmuring Bamboo) in mambo, cha-cha, and calypso rhythms, as well as love songs such as “Bakya Mo, Neneng” (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng) and “Tapis Mo, Inday” (Your Skirt, Inday). Some of the outstanding groups in the first four decades of the 20th century were the all-girl Comparsa Santa Cecilia, 1908; Rondalla Ideal of Antonio J. Molina, 1909; Comparsa Gumamela and Rondalla Apollo of Juan Silos Jr; and the Yellow Taxi Rondalla, 1940, which was supervised by Antonio J. Molina.

 

Popular Music

 

Popular music was first heard in the dance halls called kabaret and in bodabil shows, which combined slapstick-comedy acts, tap-dance numbers, skits with renditions of popular songs, and even serious kundiman. In the dance halls, live orchestras and dance bands played the latest dance rhythms such as the fox-trot, swing, Charleston, tango, and waltz. Some of the instrumental groups that specialized in dance music were the Abelardo Orchestra which played at the Santa Ana Cabaret, the Ilaya Orchestra managed by Santiago A. Cruz, the Batangas Rizal Orchestra conducted by Lorenzo Ilustre, and the groups of Juan Silos Jr, Tito Arevalo, and Serafin Payawal. Aside from the Santa Ana Cabaret, other famous cabarets in the 1930s were the La Loma Cabaret in Rizal and the Lerma Park Cabaret in Caloocan. They were also referred to as dancing pavilions.

 

The bodabil provided a venue for song and dance performances, among others, which helped popularize American entertainment, particularly jazz and fox-trot. In 1920, Lou Borromeo founded the first Filipino bodabil company, Borromeo’s Follies, which featured an orchestral band that played jazz music at the Manila Grand Opera House, the Philippine Carnival, and other theaters. He is credited for having popularized the big band jazz sound in the country, and his compositions included “My Beautiful Philippines,” 1921, and “Manila Mia” (My Manila) and “Oh! Pancho,” 1922. Borromeo’s bodabil company also boosted the careers of many stage performers such as Katy de la Cruz, Diana Toy, Miami Salvador, Bayani Casimiro, and Canuplin. Other prominent jazz bands in the era of the bodabil in the 1920s were the Oriental Syncopators, headed by Santiago Suarez; the Nifties, led by Vitang Escobar; and Electric Jazz, which performed in different venues such as the Luz, Rizal, and Zorrilla Theaters.

 

Both foreign and local songs were performed in bodabil productions, and among the popular tunes in the 1920s-30s were “Ain’t We Got Fun,” “Second-Hand Rose,” “All By Myself,” “My Man,” “April Showers,” “Careless Love,” “Let Me Call You Sweetheart,” “You are My Sunshine,” “Ma, He’s Making Eyes at Me,” “Blue Hawaii,” “Ramona,” “Magandang Juaning” (Beautiful Juaning), and “Balut-Penoy” (Duck Eggs).

 

Similar to sarsuwela’s migration into the movies, many of the songs from well-loved sarsuwela also enjoyed airtime on the newly established radio stations. Among the earliest radio stations were KZKZ, established by Henry Herman in 1924; KZIB, founded by Isaac Beck in 1925; KZRM, 1927; and the first radio station in Cebu, KZRC, 1929. These radio stations aired reports, press news, sports news, religious services, advertisements, educational programs, and music. Live singing and drama renditions took a big percentage of airtime, and by the 1930s, much of the radio personalities enjoyed celebrity status comparable to movie stars. Among these were singers Lina Flor, Priscilla the Kolynos Girl, Alma Corro, Ramon Escudero, Diana Toy, Ramon Alberto, Ramon Estella, Enya Gonzales, Dalisay Aldaba, Conchita Gaston, Tinay Arellano, Dionisia Castro, Vicente Ocampo, Katy dela Cruz, Atang dela Rama, and Cecil Lloyd, more popularly known as “the Mystery Singer.” They sang foreign and local songs, and the airing of kundiman and balitaw revived the popularity of these Philippine musical traditions such that a few of the local singers were even brought to the United States to record them. Some of the Tagalog favorites were “Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig” (My Only Love), “Dahil Sa Iyo” (Because of You), “Paalam sa Pagkadalaga” (Farewell to Maidenhood), “Ang Dalagang Filipina” (The Filipino Maiden), “Aking Bituin” (My Star), and “Maalaala Mo Kaya?” (Will You Remember?), recorded by prominent Filipino singers such as Tinay Arellano, Maria Carpena, Victorino Carrion, Katy dela Cruz, and Atang de la Rama under Victor or Columbia Records. Other early Filipino popular music compositions popularized via the radio and variety shows consisted of folk songs such as “Sarung Banggi” (One Night) and “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), arranged in dance rhythms and movie theme songs. These compositions were published as sheet music by such companies as the St Cecilia Chamber of Music and Jose Oliver Successors and sold at leading music outlets such as Fajardo Music Store, Ideal Music Store, Philippine Music Store, and Nanawa’s Music Store.

 

During the Japanese Occupation, jazz and popular dance music were banned by the government, which branded them as symbols of American cultural decadence. After World War II, the resurgence of popular music introduced new dance styles such as samba, rhumba, guarracha, appalachicola, and mambo. The jukebox was a principal conduit in popularizing music from the United States. Most of the styles of the immediate postwar period were derived from Latin American dances.

 

Philippine music in the American period shows how Filipino composers have appropriated the Western idiom earlier introduced during the Spanish colonial period in creating works that represented their mastery of the musical language of the Western colonizers in their quest to bring the Filipino composer at par with international standards. Their efforts resulted in the two-fold direction of bringing out the Philippine soul in their musical output: the Filipinization of western genres through the use of folk materials in composing concertos, symphonies, chamber music, operas, among others, and the westernization of existing Filipino musical forms such as the elevation of the kundiman into an art song and its popularization, together with other indigenous traditional forms such as the danza and balitaw, due to the advent of film and radio.Written by Ramon P. Santos, u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan
