Historical Background
Classical Music
Semiclassical Music
Popular Music
Epilogue

Historical Background

The years following World War II were a period of regeneration. The population boomed, and economic growth ensued. The old social order before World War II that supported the few rich—the oligarchs—was restored in due course.

 

In the context of music as a cultural product, the burgeoning middle class, comprising what one would call “civil society,” continued to patronize classical music from the West and supported activities of music institutions, especially music education, through musical organizations that mushroomed in a society wanting an appearance of stability. The Philippine government invested in the arts, especially the conservative classical music type, in order to reestablish the old social order (Attali 2003; Small 2007). Thus, conservativism became the distinctive character of this period, especially from 1946 to 1960.

 

However, another characteristic of the period, the move towards democratization and Filipinization of music, became visible from 1960 to 1970. After 1946, infrastructure rebuilding resumed, boosting the manufacturing sector and developing educational and social services that created opportunities for many people to climb the social ladder. As a result, new aspirants to the upper status group—the middle class—arrived. They bought commodities like records, record players, radio, and TV sets and gained access to American popular culture. It was in the first Philippine Republic that the first Filipino recording company was born, leading to the propagation of American cultural products. However, even as American culture was propagated, many Filipinos continued to work for the independence of the country from the United States. Their efforts were supported by artists who sought to define a native Filipino culture.

 

Civic Organizations. While many private associations had been organized to support musical activities during the years before the war, the government became more actively involved in the promotion of culture, establishing state institutions that oversaw activities in support of the arts, with emphasis on music. Following the creation of the United Nations and the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), the International Music Council (IMC) was instituted as one of the artistic advisory bodies, and the UNESCO encouraged member nation-states to establish their own National Music Councils. Thus the Philippine National Music Council was organized in 1953 under the auspices of the UNESCO – IMC.

 

In Jun 1955, under Republic Act No 1370, the government established the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines, which offered scholarships so that gifted young artists could study in the Philippines and abroad. The foundation was headed by Jovita Fuentes. Occasionally, it sponsored opera productions and concerts in different venues in Metro Manila. The organization also published An Album of Philippine Art Songs, which contained 27 works by 17 composers—Rosalina Abejo, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Antonino Buenaventura, Francisco Buencamino Sr, Paulino Cadsawan, Crispina Garcia, Leon Ignacio, Lucrecia Kasilag, Felipe de Leon, Corazon Maceda, Antonio Molina, Consolacion Roy, Hilarion Rubio, Lucino Sacramento, Lucio San Pedro, Rosendo Santos Jr and Ramon Tapales.

 

In the same year, Filipino art music composers formed the League of Filipino Composers (LFC). Also in 1955, the Philippine Music Educators Group was founded by leading music educators under its first president, Eliseo M. Pajaro.

 

The year 1955, a banner year for musical organizations, also saw the first attempts to organize music scholars and musicologists. The first national and international conferences were held that year with the intent to advance musical discourse and enhance the understanding of the role of music in society. The First Regional Conference of Southeast Asia was held in Aug 1955, organized by the Philippine government in cooperation with the International Music Council headed by its President Stuart Wilson and with the assistance of the Asia Foundation and the UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines. With the theme “Understanding Our Neighbours Through Music,” the conference drew participants from Taiwan, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, West and East Pakistan, Thailand, and Vietnam. Ramon Tapales was the Chairman of the Regional Commission of Southeast Asia and the President of the National Music Council of the Philippines.

 

The first major international music symposium that was held in Manila was “Musics of Asia,” which was organized by Jose Maceda under the auspices of the International Music Council and the UNESCO in 1966. The symposium conjoined the two disciplines of ethnomusicology and composition, and was attended by renowned musicologists and composers such as W.D. Amaradeva of Sri Lanka; Chou Wen Chung of China and the USA; Shigeo Kishibe and Yuji Takahashi from Japan; Ton de Leeuw from Holland; Mantle Hood, William Malm, David Norton, and Robert Garfias from the USA; Rulan Chiao Pian from China; Ravi Shankar from India; Prasidh Silapabanleng from Thailand; Tran Van Khe from Vietnam; Tsai Ping Liang from Taiwan; and Iannis Xenakis from Greece.

 

From its founding in 1953, the National Music Council also organized conferences with themes such as “Revitalizing Music for Contemporary Living” and “The Role of Music in a Changing Society.” Aside from holding conferences, the National Music Council also served as the umbrella organization for specialized groups that were later established, which included the Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines, the Philippine Choral Society, the Jeunesses Musicales (in affiliation with its international mother organization), the Philippine Society for Music Education (PSME), the LFC, the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas (PASAMBAP), the Philippine Association of Recording Industries (PARI), and the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (FILSCAP). Although the FILSCAP was organized by Felipe Padilla de Leon Sr, an art music composer, it later became a copyright agency, primarily for popular songs in the music industry.

 

 

 

Government Initiatives. Meanwhile, the national government established the Republic Cultural Heritage Award to honor distinguished artists, especially in literature and music. The composers who received the award for their works were Lucrecia Kasilag in 1960 and 1966, Antonino Buenaventura in 1961, Lucio San Pedro in 1962, Eliseo M. Pajaro in 1964 and 1970, Antonio Molina in 1965 and 1972, Rosalina M. Abejo in 1967, Jose Maceda in 1968, Felipe Padilla de Leon in 1971, and Alfredo Santos Buenaventura in 1972. The award gave way to the National Artist Award in April 1972 by virtue of Proclamation No. 1001 issued by then President Ferdinand Marcos.

 

The late 1960s saw the growing involvement of the national government in the promotion of the arts. Then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos focused on the appreciation and the cultivation of music as her priority program. Under her initiative, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) was built amidst protests from political opposition and inaugurated in 1969 with a festival of different musical and dance activities that featured both international and local artists. It premiered such works as Lucrecia Kasilag’s drama-tableux Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot) and Eliseo Pajaro’s Mir-i-nisa ballet.

 

Headed by Jaime Zobel de Ayala and later by composer Lucrecia Kasilag who was its artistic director from 1969 to 1986, the CCP was responsible for: 1) the dramatic increase in the production of new commissioned works (symphonic, chamber music, and ballet music) by members of the LFC which were premiered in an annual Philippine Music Festival; 2) the hosting or funding of international and national music festivals, conferences, symposia, and summer music camps; 3) the production of full length operas such as Madame Butterfly, Tosca, Lucia di Lammermoor, The Magic Flute, La Traviata, La Boheme, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the latter two by Felipe Padilla de Leon; and 4) the establishment of the CCP Dance Company (now Ballet Philippines) which commissioned many original works for their performances.

 

Music Education. In Philippine music, the government took the initiative in supporting and promoting the activities of musical artists. Congress passed the Music Law in 1966 (Republic Act 4723) directing all public schools to teach music as a regular subject in the curriculum.

 

The major effort to improve music literacy among the Filipinos begun by the American colonial government was later continued by local music educators. The passing of the Music Law spawned various endeavours towards the improvement and development of music teaching in the Philippines. In-service trainings for music teachers were held by the Bureau of Public Schools (BPS), and later, the Department of Education, Culture and Sports (DECS), in cooperation with professional music institutions. The Philippine Society for Music Education was founded in 1961.

 

New materials authored by Philippine musicians were published for the elementary and high schools, mostly in the form of multi-volume series aimed at providing Filipino students with pedagogical materials that highlighted folk songs from the different regions of the country. Commemorative and institutional hymns that instilled love for one’s heritage and respect for specific social institutions were also commissioned and sung at school events. Some examples of these are Felipe de Leon’s “General De Jesus Academy Hymn,” 1948, “University of the East Hymn,” 1951, and “Zonta Blessing,” 1968; Antonino Buenaventura’s “St. John Academy Hymn,” 1952, “University of Baguio Hymn,” 1969, “Angeles University Hymn,” 1970, and “Philippine National Red Cross Jubilee Song,” 1972; and Eliseo Pajaro’s “Ring the Bell for Mental Health,” 1970.

 

Eventually, the music of upland and Islamic cultural communities was also included in the curriculum of schools and universities, notably, in the University of the Philippines (UP). In 1968, Jose Maceda of the UP College of Music invited Aga Mayo Butocan, a Maguindanaon educator, to teach kulintang at the university. She was soon followed by Ben Pangosban, who likewise taught Kalinga musical instruments to UP students. Thus, Filipino students belonging to lowland Christian culture were able to learn indigenous music as a secondary tradition.

 

 

 

Classical Music

 

Western Classical Music. Despite the rapid development of the repertoire of music written by Philippine composers, concert programs generally consisted of western classical music performed by leading artists who had studied and concertized abroad. They performed a standard musical repertoire, which was comprised of the masterpieces written by western composers. Many European-educated Filipino singers rendered arias from favored operas of Verdi, Puccini, Donizetti, Bizet, and Mascagni in their concerts—works which had first been performed in the late 19th century by visiting Italian opera troupes.

 

The more significant classical music events from the 1950s to the early 1960s were the season concerts of the Manila Symphony Orchestra which, under the musical and artistic direction of Herbert Zipper, presented varied programs of symphonic works, including premieres of modern pieces such as Modest Mussorgsky’s Pictures at an Exhibition and Arnold Schoenberg’s Transfigured Night, as well as operas such as Johann Strauss’s Die Fledermaus and Georg Friedrich Handel’s Acis and Galatea. Regular concerts were also presented by the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra (FYSO) under Luis Valencia; the UP Symphony Orchestra, which regularly presented pops concerts at the St Cecilia’s auditorium, under Ramon Tapales; the Quezon City Philharmonic Orchestra, which had a regular season at the Rizal Theater in Makati, also under Ramon Tapales; the Manila Concert Orchestra; the National Philharmonic Orchestra under Redentor Romero; the Manila Little Symphony Orchestra under Federico Elizalde; the Artists’ Guild of the Philippines; the Philippine Choral Society; and the Jeunesses Musicales of the Philippines. Except for the conductors who led them, the different orchestras tended to be staffed by the same small group of musicians who moved from one group to another.

 

 

 

Filipino artists who performed western classical music included pianists Jose Maceda, Regalado Jose, Benjamin Tupas, Nena del Rosario-Villanueva, Reynaldo Reyes, and Jose Contreras; violinists Ramon Tapales, Sergio Esmilla Jr, Oscar Yatco, Basilio Manalo, and Carmencita Lozada; and singers Jovita Fuentes, Mercedes Matias, Isang Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, Andrea Veneracion, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Conching Rosal, Salvacion Oppus-Yñiguez, Irma Potenciano, Evelyn Mandac, Lilia Reyes, Eleanor Calbes, Conchita Gaston, Aurelio Estanislao, Don David, and Emmanuel Gregorio. Performances were also given by foreign artists such as Jacques Genty and Lola Bobesco, Arrigo Pola, Helen Traubel, Marianne Anderson, the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra under Alfred Wallenstein, Gaspar Cassado, the New York City Ballet, Margot Fonteyn and the Stars of the Royal Ballet, the Little Singers of Paris, Jan Pierce, Blanche Thebom, Andre Watts, the Boston Symphony Orchestra with conductor Charles Munch and composer Aaron Copland, the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra under Herbert von Karajan, and the Boston Pops Orchestra under Arthur Fiedler. Most of the concerts were presented by impresarios Alfredo Lozano, Rafael Zulueta of International Relations Inc. and the Manila Symphony Society, in cooperation with foreign government agencies.

 

 

 

These performances were mostly held in school auditoriums such as the Far Eastern University auditorium, the St Scholastica’s College St Cecilia’s Hall, the Fleur de Lis Auditorium of St Paul’s College, and the old UP Theater. Occasionally, the Rizal Memorial Coliseum was used for such large visiting ensembles as the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, as well as the Boston Pops Orchestra. The acoustically sound Philamlife Auditorium constructed in 1961 at the United Nations Ave provided the venue for many notable classical music performances. In 1962, the Abelardo Hall Auditorium of the UP Conservatory of Music (renamed UP College of Music in 1968) served as the main venue for serious classical music concerts in the Quezon City area.

 

 

 

Filipino Classical Works. Since the beginning of the 20th century, Filipino composers took pride in having cultivated the ability to write operas, symphonies, and concertos—symbols of European high art in the field of music. After the war, a good number of symphonic works were in the concerto and the symphonic or tone poem and symphonic overture genres. Among the plentiful concerti composed during the period are Rosendo Santos’s Piano Concerto No. 1 in G, 1948, and Piano Concerto No. 2 in A, 1956; Lucio San Pedro’s Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, 1948; Rosalina Abejo’s Aeolian Piano Concerto, 1949, and Jubilee Piano Concerto, 1958; Rodolfo Cornejo’s Second Piano Concerto in G Minor, 1950, Third Piano Concerto, 1968, and Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, 1972; Amada Santos Ocampo’s Piano Concerto in A Minor, 1957; Eliseo Pajaro’s Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, 1960, Concerto for Piano and Orchestra, 1964, and Concerto for Cello and Orchestra, 1965; Jerry Dadap’s Violin Concerto in Three Movements, 1965; Lucino Sacramento’s Violin Concerto in E Minor, 1969; Angel Peña’s Concerto No. 1 for Double Bass, 1969; and Hilarion Rubio’s Panamin Concerto for Cello, 1970.

 

Symphonic works in the typical classical multi-movement structure include Eliseo Pajaro’s Philippine Symphony No. 1, 1952, and Philippine Symphony No. 3, 1962; Antonino Buenaventura’s Symphony in C Major, 1961; Rosendo Santos’s Symphony No. 1, 1961; Symphony No. 2, 1961; Symphony No. 3, 1962, and Symphony No. 4, 1965; Amada Santos Ocampo’s Symphony No. 2, 1964; Hilarion Rubio’s Symphony for Greatness, 1966; Jerry Dadap’s Symphony No. 1, 1966, and Symphony No. 2, 1967; Ramon Santos’ Four Movements for Chamber Orchestra, 1968, and Parangal kay S. W. for Symphony Orchestra and Javanese Gamelan (Tribute to S. W. for Symphony Orchestra and Javanese Gamelan), 1971; Rosalina Abejo’s Thanatopsis Symphony, 1967, Beatriz Symphony, 1968, The Trilogy of Man Symphony, 1971, and Guerilla Symphony, 1972; Alfredo Buenaventura’s Kayumanggi Symphony (Brown Symphony), 1971; and Lucino Sacramento’s Symphony in D Minor, 1972. The rich literature of one-movement symphonic works includes Felipe de Leon’s Cry of Balintawak, 1948, and Roca Encantada, 1950; Eliseo Pajaro’s The Oblation, 1949; Lucio San Pedro’s The Transfiguration of Christ, 1950, and Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), 1962; Hilarion Rubio’s Pilipinas Kong Mahal (My Beloved Philippines) symphonic overture, 1960; Jerry Dadap’s The Passionate and the Wild, 1960; Alfredo Buenaventura’s Bataan Symphonic Poem, 1965, and Corregidor Symphonic Poem, 1965; and Bayani de Leon’s Batong-Buhay Symphonic Poem (Live Stone Symphonic Poem), 1968. Other orchestral works are suites and fantasies such as Felipe de Leon’s Manila Sketches, 1949; Rosalina Abejo’s The Covent Garden Suite, 1956; Lucio San Pedro’s Suite Pastorale, 1956; and Angel Peña’s Igorot Rhapsody, 1959.

 

Some cantatas and oratorios, and similar large forms written for vocal soloists, choirs and orchestras were also composed. These include Antonino Buenaventura’s Mass in C for Mixed Chorus and Chamber Orchestra, 1962; various cantatas by Alfredo Buenaventura and Rodolfo Cornejo, San Pedro’s Easter Cantata, 1950; and Eliseo Pajaro’s grand scale odes: Ode to Academic Freedom, 1958, and Ode to the Golden Jubilee, 1958. Song cycles with orchestra were written by Dadap, Amada Santos-Ocampo, and Eduardo Parungao.

 

Music for chamber ensemble include Hilarion Rubio’s Maligayang Araw (Happy Day) Quartet, 1948, and Silahis (Rays of the Sun) for Wind Septet, 1967; Eliseo Pajaro’s String Quartet No. 1, 1957, String Quartet No. 2, 1958, Harana Serenade for String Quartet, 1959, and Trio for Violin, Cello, and Piano, 1967; Lucio San Pedro’s Woodwind Quartet, 1959; Lucino Sacramento’s Capriccio Sarcastico for Violin and Piano, 1960, and In Dreams for Violin and Piano, 1961; Rosendo Santos’s Wind Quartet, 1961, Trio En Quatro for Horn, Tuba, and Piano, and Suite Breve for B-flat Clarinet, Alto Saxophone, and Piano, 1972; Antonino Buenaventura’s Quintet in C, 1963; and Rodolfo Cornejo’s Piano Trio, 1966. Substantial contributions by each major composer were scored for different instrumental combinations and formats, encouraged by the yearly Philippine Music Festival of the CCP.

 

Music for the stage also proliferated and was presented in the different regions and in different vernaculars. There were major productions like the celebrated Noli Me Tangere, 1953, by Felipe Padilla de Leon Sr, followed by his El Filibusterismo, 1970, as well as Eliseo Pajaro’s Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seed of Freedom), 1961. Alfredo Buenaventura contributed Maria Makiling, 1961, Diego Silang, 1966, Princesa Urduja, 1969, and Hinilawod, 1971, which were all about heroes and Philippine legendary characters. Other major stage productions where dance was a major component included Lucrecia Kasilag’s March Royale and Moro Ceremonial, 1958, Mindanao Myth: “Darangan,” 1958, Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto, an opera-oratorio using native instruments, and Amada, 1970; Antonino Buenaventura’s Buhay (Life), 1965, Farewell to a Warrior, 1966, and An Afternoon Rendezvous, 1969; Eliseo Pajaro’s Mir-i-nisa, 1969; Rodolfo Cornejo’s Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1970, and The Months and the Lamp, 1972; and Ramon Santos’s Ang Puting Waling-Waling (The White Orchid), 1972.

 

The 1950s saw a number of composers who, fresh from their studies abroad, espoused the cause of modern music. Eliseo Pajaro developed a neoclassic style based on counterpoint and fugal devices, pandiatonic harmonization, chromatic sequence of melodic fragments, and syncopation. His repertoire of works includes symphonies and tone poems such as The Life of Lam-Ang, 1951; concertos and choral odes, operas, quartets, and song cycles like Himig Iloko No. 3 (Ilocos Melody No. 3), 1966, and Himig Iloko No. 4, 1968, which mostly quote from Ilocano folk songs.

 

Lucrecia Kasilag also studied theory and composition in the United States and learned the stylistic techniques of the neoclassic school. Through her involvement as music director of the Bayanihan Philippines Dance Company of the Philippine Women’s University, Kasilag was exposed to traditional Philippine music. She collected and made studies on native instruments, as well as other types of Asian music during her travels. Her concept of East-West fusion became the main basis for her numerous works, where she combined timbres of native and Western instruments and scales of different musical systems. Her major works include Toccata for Percussion and Winds, 1958; Divertissement for Piano and Orchestra, 1960; The Legend of Sarimanok, 1963; Filiasiana, 1964; and the grand-scale Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto for indigenous instruments, soloists, and chorus. The works of Lucrecia Kasilag, using native instruments and scales in a neoclassic idiom, marked another phase in the Filipinization and indigenization of art music.

 

Other composers using neoclassic school techniques were Manuel Maramba, Eduardo Parungao, Angel Peña, Rosendo Santos, and Amada Santos-Ocampo. Alfredo Buenventura was known for his programmatic works and his extensive repertoire of symphonies.

 

The 1960s saw a dramatic change in Philippine art music literature. A leading role was played by Jose Maceda who abandoned his career as a concert pianist and piano pedagogue in favor of ethnomusicology and composition. His contact with the musique concrete movement in France as well as his in-depth studies of the music, philosophies, and social structures of village cultures provided the basis for his unique compositions. Maceda’s compositions in the 1960s and 1970s featured the exclusive use of Philippine and Asian instruments, the combining of mass structures of timbres or sound colors and durations, and explorations in the simulation of the village as sonic space. These may be seen in Ugma-Ugma (Structuers), 1964, Agungan (A Play of Gongs), 1966, and Pagsamba (Worship), 1968.

 

Semiclassical Music

 

Sarsuwela and Western-Style Musicals. During this period, the traditional sarsuwela, together with the komedya, had disappeared from Manila and was struggling to survive in the regions. In the Ilocos and the Ilocano-speaking provinces, the Iloko sarsuwela was produced by writers and/or directors like Pascual Agcaoili, Isaias Lazo, and Barbaro Paat. Coexisting with the sarsuwela was the komedya, which continued to be shown in towns like Santa Lucia and Santa Catalina, Ilocos Sur. By this time, the new sarsuwela written after the war had begun to integrate popular rhythms like the cha-cha into the forms traditionally associated with the genre like the kundiman, balitaw, and paso doble.

 

The sarsuwela had bowed out of the Manila stage even before World War II with the ascendancy of bodabil. In the post-war era, bodabil, now known as stage show, dominated the theaters of Manila and even the annual fiesta celebrations in the provinces. As before, the stage show was a showcase of American pop songs and dances. However, it now also began to witness the rise of original Filipino pop songs like “Waray-Waray” (a person from Samar or Leyte), “Ikaw Kasi” (Because of You), “Hahabol-Habol” (Chasing After), and “Pitong Gatang” (a fictional street in Tondo). Bodabil eventually deteriorated into burlesque and declined in the early 1970s.

 

But even as stage shows continued to entertain the masses in Manila, sarsuwela began to enjoy a revival, perhaps brought about in part by the nationalist or activist ferment that began to be felt in the mid-1960s. In the 1970s, a revival movement emerged with the restaging of Sundalong Mantika (Sluggish Soldier), Ang Mestisa (The Half-Breed Lady), and Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) by the Centro Escolar University, and Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness) by the Ateneo de Manila University. The Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines was established by columnist Teodoro Valencia, specifically to restage old sarsuwela and commission new ones. With these fresh initiatives, classic sarsuwela like Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (No Wounds) and Antonio Molina’s Ana Maria were reconstructed and reproduced. Meanwhile, the sarsuwela contest yielded new works like Bayani M. De Leon’s Ako! (Me!), 1971.

 

In the 1960s and early 1970s, Filipino audiences especially in Manila witnessed the proliferation of Broadway musicals not only on screen but also on stage because of the locally produced versions of these musicals. Some music schools, like the UP Conservatory of Music, St Paul’s College, and Santa Isabel College took to producing musicals such as My Fair Lady, The King and I, Carousel, The Sound of Music, and West Side Story. Outstanding baritone Aurelio Estanislao starred as the king in The King and I conducted by Ramon Tapales, while West Side Story was conducted by Eliseo M. Pajaro. Later, the Broadway hit Jesus Christ Superstar was produced in Manila, making stars of Boy Camara and Marilen Martinez.

 

Now familiar with the spirit and style of the modern Broadway musical, Filipino composers began to create original musicals. A pioneer in this genre was Halimaw (Monster), 1971, by Isagani Cruz and Lutgardo Labad, staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association at the new Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago. This musical alluded to a kingdom that would soon be established by the ongoing Constitutional Convention.

 

Traditional Songs and Ballads. Ballads are narrative songs displaying romantic feelings or special events in the life of a community which are commonly performed by a solo singer. Some traditional ballads use materials from existing folk songs, and are typically arranged in rounded binary form. Ballads have been composed and are still being composed in abundant numbers, catering to the everyday musical needs of a wide listening public. The native form of ballads is exemplified by the kundiman, which was widely circulated by Philippine recording companies, particularly, the Villar Recording Company.

 

A varied repertoire of kundiman, love songs and folk songs in several local languages, marches, and folk dance music were recorded by musical ensembles and famous singers contracted by Villar. The instrumental groups consisted of the Juan Silos Rondalla, Leopoldo Silos and his Orchestra, and the Villar Recording Symphonette and Band conducted by Clod Delfino. For kundiman and folk ditties in all the Philippine languages, Sylvia La Torre topped the list of recording artists. Ruben Tagalog and Cely Bautista were the idols associated with the Tagalog love song, the former recording Constancio de Guzman’s “Bayan Ko” (My Country). Rey Lucero recorded traditional Ilocano love songs such as “Bannatiran” (a mythical bird), “Biag ti Balasang” (The Life of a Maiden), and “Dungdung-wen Kanto” (I Love You So), while Nora Hernandez specialized in Visayan pieces. Other well-known performers of Filipino semi-classical music were Tres Rosas, the Lovers Trio, and later, Diomedes Maturan, the Mabuhay Singers, Carmen Camacho, Pilita Corales, Cenon Lagman, Ric Manrique, Rufina Esperancilla, and the superstar of cinema and television, Nora Aunor. It should be noted that a good number of these artists were discovered in amateur singing contests, the most famous of which was Procter and Gamble’s Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), which was first aired on radio in 1954 and then on television in 1957.

 

The initial song repertoire of Villar Records consisted mostly of kundiman by Abelardo, Santiago, Buencamino, and Hernandez, as well as lighter genres and movie songs such as Mike Velarde’s “Ikaw” (You), “Buhat” (Ever Since), “Gabi at Araw” (Night and Day), and “Habang Buhay” (While I Live); Constancio de Guzman’s “Ilaw ng Langit” (Light of the Sky), and “Babalik Ka Rin” (You Will Come Back); Josefino Cenizal’s “Hindi Kita Malimot” (I Cannot Forget You); Juan Silos’ “Luha” (Tears); Ruben Vega’s “Ako’y Lumuluha” (I Am Crying); and songs by Manuel Velez, Leopoldo Silos, and Santiago Suarez. Visayan songs include Balds Gonzales’s “Giampingan” (Treasured), “Saksi ang Langit” (Heaven Is a Witness) and “Gugma” (Love); Gibbs Cabral’s “Kon Imong Talikdan” (If You Leave Me) and “Ikaw” (You); and Minggoy Lopez’s “Rosas Pandan.” I. Mirasol and T. Villa contributed songs in Ilongo such as “Sa Tuburan” (By the Spring), “Daw Pispis Nga Bukaw” (Like an Owl), and “Dalawidaw” (Yellow Bird). A leading lyricist for many Tagalog songs was Levi Celerio, a violinist, a musical comic, and master of light poetry. He was lyricist to major songwriters like Santiago Suarez, Restie Umali, Leopoldo Silos, Antonio Maiquez, Ernani Cuenco, Josefino Cenizal, but also contributed some of his original tunes.

 

In the 1960s and 1970s, the Filipino love songs in the lyric style of the kundiman maintained their presence in the overall popular music repertoire and became known as ballads. While the sarsuwela-derived movie formats were no longer dominant as in the previous decades, many of the songwriters who produced ballads in the second half of the century were active in musical scoring for the movie industry. Some of the leading works include Mike Velarde’s “Pangarap Ko’y Ikaw Rin” (My Dream, Too, Is You), 1947, “Tanging Ikaw” (Only You), 1948, “Hanggang Ako’y May Hininga” (While I’m Still Breathing), 1948, “Ngayon at Kailanman” (Now and Forever), 1949, and “Kung Nasaan Ka” (Wherever You Are), 1962; Leopoldo Silos’s “Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak” (Because of a Flower), 1966; and Restie Umali’s “Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin” (You are Everything to Me), 1969, “Pag-ibig, Ikaw ang Maysala” (Love, You are the Cause), 1969, “Habang Ako’y Nabubuhay” (While I am still Alive), 1969, “Gintong Alaala” (Golden Memory), 1970, and “Life Everlasting,” 1971. The songs that were recorded by a number of companies that succeeded Villar’s pioneering effort captured a market of music listeners belonging to the 21-and-above age bracket. The pop ballads did not only cater to a listening public but also were considered appropriate music for programs, convocations, weddings, party socials, and occasionally for funeral rites.

 

Meanwhile, outside of mainstream middle class culture, semiclassical genres like kundiman and danza were used as the formal basis for protest songs. The Visayan composo, another folk ballad form used for protest songs, also came from the grassroots. This appropriation was advocated by members from the peasant and urban workers who formed the socialist group Hukbong Mapagpalaya ng Bayan in 1949 to resist American imperialism and class oppression.

 

Folk Song Collection, Compilation, and Arrangement. Another favored source of songs and ballads were the existing folk songs which had been arranged for solo voice or choir with instrumental accompaniment. Many of these were published for school use. Filipino Folk Songs, 1950, was a collection arranged by Emilia Reysio-Cruz and harmonized by Francisco Santiago. It contained choral arrangements of “Chichiritsit,” “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), “Leron-leron Sinta” (Leron-leron Beloved), “Dandansoy” (Unfaitful), and “Si Nanay, si Tatay, Namasol sa Dagat” (My Mother, My Father, Went Fishing in the Sea), “Atin Cu Pung Singsing” (I Have a Ring), “Ti Ayat Ti Meysa nga Ubing” (Love of a Child), and “Chua-ay.” In the same year, the Selected Songs of the Philippines, compiled by Bernabe Roxas Solis and containing “Ay, Kalisud!” (Ah, Misery!) and “Lulay,” among others, was published in New York by the Soledy Music Society. In 1952, Ramon Tapales, then director of the UP Conservatory of Music, published a series titled Singing and Growing for Primary Grades, whose selections were mostly Filipino compositions and folk songs but included songs from the United States and Europe. In 1953, Corazon S. Maceda and Crispina C. Garcia published Philippine Choruses for All Occasions. It was a compilation of compositions by Antonio Molina, Lucio San Pedro, Buencamino Sr, Francisco Santiago, and Juan Hernandez. Another anthology edited by Corazon Maceda, this time with Candida B. Bautista, featured choral works by Alfredo Buenaventura, Julian Felipe, Salvador Imperio, Leon Ignacio, Lucrecia Kasilag, Felipe de Leon, Antonio Molina, Cayetano Rodriguez, Vicente Sales, Jose Sanchez, Lucio San Pedro, Francisco Santiago, Miguel Velarde, and Manuel Velez. These anthologies were widely disseminated in the school system as Maceda, Garcia, and Bautista mentored many school teachers bred in the Philippine Women’s University, the Philippine Normal College, and in the public schools. In 1963, composer Felipe Padilla de Leon and Luz Odulio Villanueva, the supervisor of music of the Division of City Schools in Manila, published Music Time for both the lower and higher primary grades. These likewise contained Filipino compositions and folk songs. Still another set of materials was issued in 1966: the two-volume Sing and Be Happy, jointly authored by Antonino Buenaventura, Jose M. Hernandez, and linguist Jose Villa Panganiban. These focused on aspects of Filipino history and culture.

 

In 1957-8, Priscilla Venturanza Magdamo published the multivolume Philippine Folk Songs: Songs of the Visayas through the Silliman Music Foundation Inc. The different folk songs were collected in the field from different singer-informants, transcribed and arranged by Magdamo herself. The volumes contain folk songs from the Ilongo, Aklanon, Cebuano, and the Waray.

 

The collection of folk songs is an ongoing task and is still being undertaken by both scholars and teachers all over the country. While many of the folk songs included in anthologies and collections were initially transcribed for educational purposes, many of them, too, were arranged as medleys and short pieces for chorus, band, and rondalla ensembles. Examples are Paruparong Bukid, 1949, and Bahay-Kubo, 1953, for band by Felipe de Leon Sr; Himig Pilipino No. 1 (Filipino Melody No. 1), 1956, Himig Pilipino No. 2, 1958, Philippine Medley, 1959 and Himig Iloko No. 3, 1966, for choir by Eliseo Pajaro; and the Balitaw Series for Rondalla progressively written between 1958 and 1963 by Jerry Dadap.

 

Instrumental Music. In this period, Philippine band music produced hundreds of outstanding musicians such as Hilarion Rubio, Lucio San Pedro, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Antonino Buenaventura, Alfredo Buenaventura, Lucino Sacramento, Eliseo Pajaro, Rosendo Santos, Eduardo Parungao, and Francisco Feliciano. It was through the contributions of these composers that the Philippine band tradition has developed an extensive repertoire ranging from marches, patriotic pieces, and folk song arrangements to large-scale symphonic compositions. Many Philippine marches were composed after the World War II like Felipe de Leon’s “Martsa ng Republika ng Pilipinas” (March of the Republic of the Philippines), 1948, “The Tamaraw March,” 1950, “The Ilocano National Association March,” 1958, and “Bagong Pagsilang” (March of the New Society), 1972; Antonino Buenaventura’s “President Magsaysay March,” 1954, and “President Eisenhower March,” 1969; and Lucio San Pedro’s “Philippine Independence,” 1964, “Festival March,” 1969, “Golden Heart March,” 1971, and “Angononian March,” 1972. Other than the marches, composers wrote longer works for band such as concert overtures, tone poems, and even symphonies. Examples of these are Felipe de Leon’s Ang Karomata (The Carriage), 1948, Fantasie for Trombone and Band, 1949, Mayumi Theme and Variations, 1950, Bulaklak ng Lahi (Flower of the Race) Symphonic March, 1952, Philippines Forever Military March, 1952, and Ang Watawat (The Flag), 1952; Eduardo Parungao’s Suite for Band, 1960, and Philippine Airs Medley No. 1, 1968; Lucio San Pedro’s Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), 1961; and Hilarion Rubio’s Three Kings Overture, 1970.

 

When lavish fiestas were discouraged by the austerity program of the government in the 1960s, band activities declined. However, this was not permanent. Band competitions under the auspices of the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas (PASAMBAP) reinvigorated the fading medium. These national band competitions were first held at the Rizal Coliseum in cooperation with Manila Lion’s Club and the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines. Later, these were co-sponsored by the Folk Arts Theater and the Balik Banda program of the San Miguel Corporation.

 

Another popular medium for light classical music during the period was the rondalla, an ensemble consisting of plectrum instruments. Prominent composers like Antonio Molina, Lucino Sacramento, Lucio San Pedro, Jerry Dadap, and Bayani M. de Leon explored this instrumental group and wrote art music compositions for these ensembles. Examples of these pieces are Jerry Dadap’s Symphonic Balitaws Nos. 1-7, 1958-1963, and Philippine Symphonic Rondalla, 1967; and Bayani de Leon’s Tatlong Bulaklak (Three Flowers) for symphonic rondalla, 1968. Juan Silos composed and arranged marches, folk songs, kundiman, and balitaw for the rondalla and recorded them through the Villar Recording Company. At the same time, comparza groups remained in the countryside, with members coming from the older members of the community who generally played and harmonized tunes by ear.

 

Competitions, likewise, became a venue for the development of the rondalla. One of the most well known was “Hamon sa Kampeon” (A Challenge to the Champion) in the 1960s, broadcast on radio and television (DXZL, Channel 3, and DZAQ) and hosted by Dely Magpayo and Pepe Pimentel. Dominic Salustiano, who was a regular adjudicator of the competition, also composed many pieces for the rondalla. In 1967, the Manila Times sponsored the National Symphonic Rondalla Composition Contest in which Jerry Dadap’s composition Philippine Symphonic Medley for Rondalla won the much-coveted prize. In 1970, Felipe Padilla de Leon organized the Taliba National Rondalla Contest, and the Pio del Pilar High School Rondalla from Makati, conducted by fifteen-year old Rosario Tobias, won. Other groups that won prizes were the Round Table Rondalla from Bulacan, the Ramon Magsaysay High School Rondalla, and the Araullo High School from Manila.

 

In 1966, the Pangkat Kawayan was organized by Victor Toledo. It was an ensemble of elementary school children playing different types of bamboo instruments—flutes, marimba, clappers, angklung, bumbung. It was an attempt to revive the musikong bungbong, an ensemble of bamboo instruments patterned after those of the marching band that became popular during the revolutionary wars of the turn of the 19th century. By the 1960s these ensembles had almost disappeared. The Pangkat Kawayan, whose repertoire of folk songs and dances was similar to that of the rondalla, was usually featured in school programs and was showcased in the tourist industry especially during the Marcos administration.

 

Popular Music

 

After World War II, the global Euro-American music recording industry fuelled investment in local music recording and live and media entertainment companies that promoted the recordings. The recording artists of the period were the same personalities who had graced the live shows in Manila Opera Houses and Savoy Theater. Commercial enterprises distributed Euro-American music commodities­—songs in rock ‘n’ roll, Broadway, jazz, American dance, ballad “standard,” and later disco styles and idioms—as well as a wide array of local popular music genres. These local popular music genres included Philippine popular and folk music as well as older forms such as the kundiman, balitaw, and danza. All these types of music, commodified through 33 RPM or long-playing vinyl records and 45 RPM or singles, catered mostly to the urban youth and originally reached them via radio and TV.

 

Aside from the transistor radio and stereo playback machines with a record player, the coin-operated jukebox was a distinctive conduit for popularizing music from the Euro-Americas. Most of the styles of the immediate postwar period were derived from Latin American dances. Xavier Cugat, the “King of Rhumba,” visited the Philippines in 1953 and had a strong impact on local amateur musicians. In the next few years, the cumbanchero, an instrumental group that featured the harmonica, guitar, bongos, maracas, conga drum, and one-stringed bass improvised from an empty gasoline tank, proliferated in towns and barrios. Its repertoire consisted mainly of folk songs and medleys of local tunes arranged to different Latin American beats. Cumbanchero groups livened up town fiestas and other public gatherings, including competitions, with their musical renditions and their colourful costumes fashioned after Xavier Cugat’s conjunto attire.

 

From the mid-1950s to the 1960s, rock ‘n’ roll gained widespread popularity among the middle-class youth. The new music drew elements from blues, gospel, boogie, country, and western. Rock and roll stars included Billy Haley who introduced the new style with “Rock Around the Clock,” Chubby Checker, Buddy Holly, Cliff Richards, and the “King of Rock and Roll” himself, Elvis Presley. The electronic media also introduced other styles identified with such personalities as Neil Sedaka, Johnny Mathis, Perry Como, Tom Jones, the Platters and others. Because Filipino singers sang imported music with an English cultivated by the public school system for a local audience just as well versed in the language by the system, the few attempts to translate English lyrics into Filipino failed to flourish.

 

When singing idols such as Neil Sedaka, Nat King Cole, Timi Yuro, Johnny Mathis, and Harry Belafonte visited the Philippines, Filipino singers tried hard to sound just like them. The popular noontime show Student Canteen even launched contests to search for local versions of Elvis Presley (Eddie Mesa), and Johnny Mathis (Bert Nievera). Diomedes Maturan, winner of Tawag ng Tanghalan, another amateur singing contest, was called the Philippine Perry Como.

In contrast to this mimicry, there were original compositions based on the new styles of this period. Among the interpreters of such a repertory was Sylvia la Torre, a graduate of the Conservatory of Music of the University of Santo Tomas, who had ventured into musical comedy and bodabil. She recorded the hit song “Waray-waray” (Juan Silos Jr) with a blues chord progression under Villar Records in the 1950s. This hit was followed by Bobby Gonzales’s version of Clod Delfino’s “Hahabol-habol” in rock n’ roll style and by Fred Panopio’s “Pitong Gatang” in country and western style. These works exemplify attempts to localize appropriated foreign musical styles.

 

Also in the 1950s, Philippine love songs and other light classical pieces were further popularized in record discs, which were played on the radio, home phonographs, and jukeboxes all over the country. The burgeoning record industry that promoted Filipino music was led by Mabuhay Recording Company, which issued recordings under two labels, Villar Records and Mabuhay Records beginning in the 1950s. This company had a tremendous impact on the production of Filipino music coming from different regions of the country. The commercial circulation and consumption of semiclassical Philippine music helped bring about the Filipinization and nationalization of Philippine music.

 

In the 1960s, rock and roll reached its peak and during the first half of the decade, instrumental groups such as the Ventures and the Shadows inspired many young people from both the affluent and the working class to learn to play the guitar. The phenomenal rise of the Beatles towards the mid-1960s provided the impetus for the emergence of other pop groups. These included the Rolling Stones, Cream, The Doors, Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Chicago, Procol Harum, and Santana, to name a few.

 

The local pop music industry grew as radio and television shows such as the Night Owl Dance Party and Jam Session promoted the latest dance crazes. Discotheques competed with cocktail lounges. Local groups imitated the Beatles and other pop idols. The successful groups in the 1960s include RJ and the Riots, Technocolors, Electromaniacs, the Hijacks, the Deltas, the Moonstrucks, and the Downbeats. They popularized rock ‘n’ roll, the twist, mashed potato, and watusi. Some leaders of these local rock groups like Ramon Jacinto, Mike Hanopol, and Joey “Pepe” Smith would later on contribute to the development of Pinoy rock in the 1970s.

 

It was also in the late 1960s that classical music was overshadowed by popular entertainment and Broadway musicals. Some music schools like the UP Conservatory of Music, St Paul’s College, and Santa Isabel College even took to producing musicals such as My Fair Lady, The King and I, Carousel, The Sound of Music, and West Side Story. Outstanding baritone Aurelio Estanislao starred as the king in King and I in a University of the Philippines production conducted by Ramon Tapales, while the West Side Story was conducted by Eliseo M. Pajaro.

 

Pinoy Pop Ballads. Most local compositions in the 1960s were love songs such as those by Antonio Maiquez, Mike Velarde, and Manuel Villar. Songs of love in English, inspired by American ballads, also found their place in the local popular music repertoire. Ballads in English and Filipino were later written by local composers such as Alice Doria Gamilla with her “A Million Thanks to You” and were called middle-of-the-road songs. Mike Velarde’s contribution to the genre includes “Dedicated to You,” 1949; “Be Mine” and “Eternally Yours,” 1953; “Sa Hirap at Ginhawa” (Through Hardships and Comfort), 1954; “It’s You,” 1963; “What Else Can I Ask For,” 1963; “Since You Went Away,” 1970; and “As Long as Forever,” 1970. Restie Umali also wrote a few ballads such as “Ang Hangganan ng Aking Buhay” (The End of My Life), 1969, and “Dearest Forever,” 1971. Leading arrangers of ballads were Danny Holmsen, Pastor de Jesus, Nestor Robles, and Josefino Cenizal.

 

Earlier, local balladeers were influenced by the Platters, Nat King Cole, Everly Brothers, Harry Belafonte, Johnny Mathis, Connie Francis, and Cliff Richards. Later, Pilita Corrales, Carmen Soriano, Carmen Pateña, Mercy Molina, Ric Manrique, and other local singers developed their own styles, departing from the usual trend of merely imitating foreign idols. Succeeding them were a younger generation of recording artists led by Nora Aunor, Tirso Cruz III, and Eddie Peregrina. Among the singing groups of the 1960s, the Ambivalent Crowd, the Sheraders, and the Fourth Generation figured prominently.

 

Pinoy Rock. Pinoy Rock is the offshoot of the rock boom of the 1960s, when groups equipped with electronic instruments, then known as combos, began to make their presence felt in the local music scene. Among the better-known combos then were the Downbeats, Birth of the Cool, D’Bankers, Mon Pestaño and the Robins, Skylark, Red Fox, Bits and Pieces, and RJ and the Riots. The lesser known sported such names as Hydraulic Banana Rag Band, Intensity, and Fastback 2 + 2. Their repertoire consisted mostly of cover versions of early hits by the Beatles, Rolling Stones, Led Zeppelin, Chicago, the Doors, Jimi Hendrix, and Jefferson Airplane. They also belted out soul music performed by black artists under the Motown label. Considered as the pioneer Philippine rock group is the Juan dela Cruz Band, founded in 1968, whose members include Wally Gonzalez, Mike Hanopol, Pepe Smith, and Edmund Fortuno, among others. Their first album, Up in Arms, was released in 1971.

 

Pinoy Folk. The influence of the 1960s American folk balladeers Bob Dylan, Joan Baez, Peter Paul and Mary, and Judy Collins was felt within Filipino popular music culture, which adapted not only the singing style and structural elements of the music but also the general character of the text.

Filipino artists then used the folk ballad to communicate nationalist ideas and semi-didactic messages and to convey their rebellion against authority and convention. The counterculture protest songs of the leftist student activists from the mid-1960s consisted of simple strophic melodies combined with texts that were poetic and steeped in political rhetoric and issues that covered a wide range of topics—Filipino colonial mentality, freedom from tyranny, or an espousal of positive Filipino values.

 

Novelty Songs. Novelty songs were distinguished from the other popular music genres of the period for the humor they contained, their satirical nature, and their use of catchy and novel musical techniques. When American rock ‘n’ roll was introduced to Filipinos in the 1950s, the new musical phenomenon prompted musicians and the staff of Villar Records to come up with songs, some of them written by American country and western songwriters, with humorous Tagalog texts. The mix localized or Filipinized the foreign, and thus struck a chord among the Filipino masses. Sylvia la Torre, a classically-trained singer, recorded “Bahala Na” (Come What May), “Puting Texas” (White Fighting Cock), “Golpe de Gulat” (Kick of Surprise), and “No Money, No Honey.” Other singer-songwriters of novelty songs were Fred Panopio who sang “Ang Kawawang Cowboy” (The Pitiful Cowboy), a comic ditty sung to the tune of Glen Campbell’s “Rhinestone Cowboy.” Original novelty songs were also composed by Filipinos. The Big Three Sullivans wrote the text and sang the song “Aswang” in 1966 to the tune of Antonino Buenventura’s “Pandanggo sa Ilaw.” Original novelty songs would continue to be written by songwriters like Yoyoy Villame and Max Surban from the 1970s to the 1990s.

 

Jazz. Appreciation of jazz as a unique genre of musical entertainment came into its own in the Philippines in the 1950s and 1960s after Filipino musicians had been emancipated to a degree from the stereotype connection with music of the dance bands of the swing era before World War II. Immediately after the war, jazz was heard principally in American military bases in Pampanga, Zambales, Baguio, and in Cavite. In Manila, it was patronized by the affluent sectors of Philippine society who formed clubs such as the Army Navy Club, Bayside Club, and Men’s Club.

 

Jazz music in the period flourished mainly in hotels and cocktail lounges such as the Manila Hotel, and later, Cafe Indonesia, which were important in the cultivation of this genre which requires the technique of improvisation. Jazz concerts such as the annual Upsilon Sigma Phi concerts at the UP, which drew fairly large audiences, were also occasionally held. Some of the more prominent artist-exponents of Philippine jazz from the 1950s were Chino Santos, Tirso Cruz Sr, Pete Aristorenas, Exequiel “Lito” Molina and the Jazz Friends, Romy Posadas, Angel Peña, Piding Alava, Romy Katindig, and Fred Robles. They sometimes experimented on the use of folk tunes as basic melodic materials for improvisation and imbued the tunes with characteristic jazz rhythms and chord progressions. Original jazz compositions by local composers were scarce since many Filipino jazz musicians played the standard and readily available American repertoire. Examples of the few pieces of jazz music written by Filipino composers in the years before 1972 are Angel Peña’s “Blues-a-Nova,” 1960, “Theme in F,” 1960, and “Igorhythm,” 1963. The prevailing jazz music repertoire from America played by the local artists includes “Boogie-Woogie Bugle Boy,” “Softly as in a Morning Sunrise,” “Lover Come Back to Me,” “Jazz Me Blues,” “Sophisticated Lady,” and “One O’clock Jump.”

 

In the 1960s, the fusing of elements of rhythm-and-blues and the heavy, highly amplified variety of rock music came to be known as jazz fusion. Later, the term referred to the merger of jazz with other pop music genres, as exemplified by the music of Larry Coryell, Stanley Clarke, and George Duke.

 

Epilogue

 

The music of the First Philippine Republic is important for three main reasons. First, it was in this period when music institutions that nurtured, protected, and regulated the musical life of the nation were founded: the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines; the League of Filipino Composers; the grassroots band association Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas; and the Cultural Center of the Philippines. It was also in this period that music education became a requirement in the public schools throughout the country.

 

Second, it was in this period that the Philippine music industry was born. Products of the industry, mostly semi-classical pieces for band and rondalla, consisting of traditional forms such as the kundiman, danza, and balitaw, were broadly circulated through radio, TV, and film. As with the indigenized sarsuwela and bodabil, imported western semiclassical forms and styles were fused to local texts and tweaked to suit the local tastes and thus, genres like the novelty song were produced and enjoyed by the broader Filipino population. Forms, styles, and performers from regional music also entered the national consciousness through the music industry.

 

Third, the period saw the beginnings of original popular music. Upon seeing the effect of recorded music circulated through radio, television, and film, Filipino composers realized the lucrativeness of writing music with popular mass appeal. A number of these composers capitalized on accepted American forms such as rock ‘n’ roll, Broadway-inspired songs, ballads, and jazz, and adopted these in their original compositions. Pioneering original songs such as this paved the way for the rise of Original Pilipino Music (OPM) in the next decade.Written by Ramon P. Santos, with additional notes by Jose S. Buenconsejo, Arwin Q. Tan, and Nicanor G. Tiongson
