Section:

Historical Background
Classical Music
Semiclassical Music
Popular Music

Historical Background

 

Ferdinand E. Marcos won his first term as president of the Philippine Republic in 1965. Drug dealing, arms smuggling, and oligarchic control over the vast resources of Philippine society were some of the major issues that hounded him up to the end of this term. In 1969, he won a second term in what was considered as one of the most corrupt elections in Philippine history. During this term, militarization of the countryside, cronyism, and abuse of power at all levels of government drove some of the people to take up arms in a protracted war to challenge the Marcos regime and its cohorts. Dissidence from the rural areas crept into the urban jungle when students and artists started to identify with the plight of the peasantry and the working class. Turning the mounting dissent and the perceived threat of communism to his advantage, Ferdinand Marcos signed on 21 Sep 1972 Proclamation No. 1081—the law that placed the Philippines under martial rule.

 

It would take almost a decade for martial rule to be lifted through Proclamation 2045 signed in Jan 1981. This proclamation, however, ensured that all proclamations and decrees that Marcos issued during martial law would still be enforced. In effect, martial rule continued, albeit with a more “democratic” mien. Marcos continued to control the country, but his grip on power started to weaken in 1983 when Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino II was assassinated. Aquino was seen by the Filipinos as a martyr. Not long after, Aquino’s wife, Corazon or “Cory,” was fielded by the PDP-LABAN Party to challenge the strongman in the Feb 1986 Snap Presidential Election that ultimately toppled the Marcos regime in the ensuing, and now historic, EDSA People Power Revolt.

 

Under martial law, Marcos attempted to build his Bagong Lipunan or New Society, which later on turned out to be a society controlled by him, his wife Imelda, and their powerful cronies. On paper, though, the New Society recognized that the Filipino consciousness was deeply colonial and that political will was needed to rectify it. The philosophy behind the New Society’s transformative thrusts paralleled the World War II Japanese occupation policy of “decolonizing” the Filipino in the “New Order” under the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. The regime’s concept of the New Society, outlined in Marcos’s An Ideology for Filipinos, was skillfully fed to the people through the schools and media.

 

The New Society encouraged a sense of nationalism by emphasizing the native and the local. It encouraged the use of Filipino as the national language, and the use of local materials for clothes (e.g., through the Bagong Anyo fashion shows) and buildings (e.g., Coconut Palace or Bahay Pilipino). It promoted as well as the translation of local architectural concepts and motifs into large-scale projects (as in the Baguio Convention Center and National Arts Center) and the creation of Filipino music that embodied the Filipino in both the popular and classical idioms. Through all these, the “New Filipino” was supposed to be defined.

 

As the sociocultural aspect of the New Society aimed at developing a reconstituted Filipino consciousness, its sociopolitical aspect was designed to answer the corporal needs of the people. Both aspects needed infrastructure to effect changes. Among the structures built under Marcos’s presidency and the New Society were the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Folk Arts Theater, Manila Film Center, Philippine International Convention Center, Nayong Pilipino (Philippine Village), Philippine High School for the Arts, and National Arts Center. Luneta Park, Intramuros, and Metropolitan Theater were also revived or restored from the ravages of World War II while government hospitals like the Philippine Heart Center, National Kidney Institute, Lung Center of the Philippines, and Philippine Children’s Hospital mushroomed in the Quezon City government center.

 

Imelda Marcos, in her 1974 book Seven Tasks, enumerated the following priority projects: Bagong Anyo, Design Center, Asian Handicraft Center, Nayong Pilipino, Bagong Anyo ng Industriyang Pilipino, Philippine Assistant on National Minorities, Museum of Traditional Culture, Cultural Center of the Philippines, Young Artists Development Foundation, National Arts Center, National Artist Award, and National Parks Development Committee. Through the Young Artist Foundation of the Philippines, talented young Filipinos received music scholarship grants that enabled them to pursue advanced music studies abroad. Promising young artists like Cecil Licad (Curtis Institute), Rowena Arrieta (Moscow Conservatory), Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz (Manhattan School of Music), Joseph Esmilla (Juilliard School of Music), Alfonso Bolipata (New School of Music in Philadelphia), Ma. Elenita Buenaventura (University of Texas), Dionisia Fernandez (Juilliard School of Music), Antonio Maigue (Conservatoire National de Musique Rueil Malmaison), and Conrado del Rosario (Universität der Künste Berlin) studied abroad through the support of the foundation. Today, many of these musicians are considered beacons of Philippine music.

 

With the support of the CCP, music organizations also flourished. Annual music competitions like the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) were established to identify and encourage young artists from all over the archipelago who excelled in vocal and instrumental music. Young talents discovered by NAMCYA performed during the regular concerts at the Paco Park, Puerta Real, and Rizal Park. These concerts were broadcast over TV for many years and thus were important in the dissemination of art music or classical music to the nation.

 

Music books, choral and instrumental, were also published under NAMCYA auspices, including the National Music Competition for Young Artists series for children’s choirs, with the 1973-8 and the 1979-1982 compilations both published in 1983; and the 1975-8 compilation for youth choirs coming out in 1979.

The Marcos regime knew the importance and role of propaganda music in controlling the people as well as winning their support. The regime invested heavily in both political and police powers in wresting control of mass media companies to directly influence the content, tone, and general themes of both broadcast and print. Radio, television, and newspaper became the New Society’s primary tools in disseminating mediated information to the public.

 

As music was utilized by the Marcos regime to celebrate advances in its political aspirations, it was also used by activists among the academe and the masses, and the middle and upper classes to voice dissent against the regime in the 1970s and even more so after 1983.

 

Protest music during the martial law period was given much color and meaning by the songs that emanated from the revolutionary movement, guided by Marxist-Leninist-Mao Tse Tung thought. These songs embodied the revolutionary ideology and themes of the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP), the New Peoples Army (NPA), and the National Democratic Front (NDF). Montañez (1989) stated that the “songs of the countryside” foregrounded “three basic themes: the national democratic revolution, the armed struggle, and the revolutionary peasant mass movement.” The anti-Marcos national democratic revolution songs “present[ed] the necessity, principles and line of the national democratic revolution, the leadership of the proletariat and the basic alliance of workers and peasants, the international character of the anti-imperialist and anti-feudal struggle, the history of exploitative rule in the country, and the conditions obtaining in a semi-colonial, semi-feudal society.” Under the armed struggle theme, “the songs depict[ed] the armed struggle carried out by the New People’s Army and the revolutionary masses. These songs deal[t] with the principles and policies which guide the people’s fighters in their work, the experiences which undergo in combat, and their attitude towards sacrifice and martyrdom.” Under the last category, “the songs in the countryside deal[t] with the revolutionary peasant movement. These songs unite[d] the peasants and farm workers to fight against economic oppression and military brutality, to support the armed struggle and carry on the agrarian revolution” (5-8).

 

When Ninoy Aquino was assassinated on 21 Aug 1983, the ranks of the protest movement swelled in number and became even bolder in expressing anger and bitterness against the dictatorial government. A newly conscienticized middle class, whose symbol became the yellow ribbon, formed a strong counterhegemonic bloc with the nationalist Left, symbolized by the color red, in opposing the Marcos regime. This period ended with the abdication of the Marcoses from power in the famous People Power Revolt in 1986 that set a model for social change among other countries of the world.

 

Classical Music

 

Imelda Marcos’s cultural projects revolved around the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), which was inaugurated on 10 Sept 1969. Imelda became the main patron of classical music. During the Marcos era, national Filipino music performing groups were established and/or supported by the state such as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra, founded in 1973 (known as the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra since 1982), the UP Madrigal Singers, founded in 1963 (known as the Philippine Madrigal Singers since 1980), and the Philippine Opera Company, founded in 1983. Local artists who represented the best in Filipino artistic expression were also honored with the National Artist Award, the highest honor given by the nation to Filipinos who have distinguished themselves in the different fields of the arts. The National Artist Award was signed into law through Proclamation 1001 on 27 Apr 1972. Musicians given the said award during martial law years were composer Antonio Molina, 1973, and soprano Jovita Fuentes, 1976.

 

The regime also honored foreign artists for their contributions to the world of music. Imelda Marcos gave the International Artist Awards to Van Cliburn and Margot Fonteyn. Moreover, CCP hosted internationally recognized names in music like Cliburn, Mstislav Rostropovich, and the New York Philharmonic. The San Francisco Opera Association was even invited to perform Tosca, the renowned opera by Giacomo Puccini in 1979, with a cast that included Eva Marton (Floria Tosca), Justino Diaz (Baron Scarpia), and Placido Domingo (Mario Cavaradossi).

 

Local artists were also encouraged to feature Western music. The yearly Philippine Music Festival of the League of Filipino Composers (LFC) always presented a program of newly commissioned ballet works in cooperation with the CCP Dance Company (now BalletPhilippines). In addition, Filipino adaptations of foreign operas and other stage works were produced such as Bizet’s Carmen, Puccini’s Gianni Schichi, Verdi’s La Traviata by RolandoTinio, and Stravinsky’s ballet-cantata Les Noces (The Wedding) by RamonP.Santos.

 

Imelda Marcos also met with the members of the LFC and challenged classical music composers in the Philippines to create distinct Filipino music. A few became very actively involved in the efforts of the Marcos regime, and their names would later be identified with projects launched by the regime. Eliseo Pajaro published a collection of songs titled Himig Pilipino ng Bagong Lipunan (Filipino Tunes of the New Society), 1974. Kasilag wrote Philippine Scenes for Orchestra, 1974, and Misang Pilipino No. 2 (Filipino Mass No. 2), 1974. Rodolfo de Leon set to music the regime’s slogan, “Isang Bansa, Isang Diwa” (One Country, One Mind), and Lucino Sacramento composed two concertos for piano and orchestra dedicated to Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos titled Ang Maharlika (The Noble Man), 1973, and Ang Bituin (The Star), 1974. Rosalina Abejo came up with Overture 1081, 1974, and Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Bayan (Love of the Native Country), 1979.

 

Many of the composers centered on music that was Filipino in design and sentiment. This was achieved by using themes from epics, folk tunes, and Filipino ethnic instruments. Well-known operas with this thrust were Eliseo M. Pajaro’s BinhingKalayaan (Seed of Freedom) and Balagtas at Celia (Balagtas and Celia); Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Maria Makiling, Diego Silang, Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), and Hinilawod; and Francisco F. Feliciano’s LaLobaNegra (The Black She-wolf). Other works for the stage with this thrust were Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot) and Amada; Antonino Buenaventura’s Kulas na Batugan (Lazy Kulas); Ryan Cayabyab’s Rama,Hari (King Rama) and Kapinangan; Jerry A. Dadap’s Tomaneg at Aniway (Tomaneg and Aniway); Francisco Feliciano’s ballet music Yerma; Ruben R. Federizon’s VisionofFire; Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Mir-i-nisa; and Ramon P. Santos’s Siklo (Cycle), Awit (Song), and Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden).

 

The literature for solo pieces and choralworks also increased with the emergence of outstanding solo artists and choralgroups. The initial successes of the UPMadrigalSingers inspired some composers to write choral pieces in madrigal style, the first being Ramon P. Santos with “Tuksuhan” (Teasing) and “Tula-tula” (Poetica), followed by Fabian Obispo with “Telebong.” NAMCYA commissioned solo pieces and short choral works such as Bernardino Custodio’s “Ritual Dance,” Kasilag’s “Derivation V,” Bayani M. de Leon’s “Kimkim” (Clenched), and Ramon P. Santos’s “Klintang” and “Abot-tanaw III” (Horizons), for solo piano; San Pedro’s “Sa Mundong Ibabaw” (On this Earth) and R. Santos’s “Handog Sa Ina” (Offering to Mother) for children’s choir; and Chino Toledo’s “At Maging Ang Kuwerdas Ay Humihingi Ng Kapayapaan Para Sa Mundo” (And Even the Strings Are Begging for World Peace) and Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s “Panaghoy” (Outcry) for solo violin.

 

The dramatic change in Philippine art music literature which began in 1960s and which was linked to the avant-garde movement in Europe and the United States continued. With the discovery of new sources of musical thought, a new path was opened, suggesting alternative materials and processes of composition. JoseMaceda, ethnomusicologist and composer, played a leading role during this period. His contact with the musique concrete movement during his performance training in France as well as his in-depth studies of the music, philosophies, and social structures of village cultures provided the basis for the unique character of his compositions. What may be regarded as Maceda’s writing idiom stemmed from the combination of musical and extramusical concepts such as mass structures of timbres (sound colors) and durations. After his Ugma-Ugma (Structures), 1964, Agungan (A Play of Gongs), 1966, and Pagsamba (Worship), 1968, he continued “experimenting” with the slow permutation of events in time in his Ading, 1978, and Siasid and Aroding, 1983, Ugnayan (Coordination), 1974, Udlot-Udlot (Fluctuation), 1975, and Suling-suling, 1985. Most of his works were supported by the University of the Philippines that was outside of Marcos’s control.

 

 

The first among a younger generation of composers to respond to the challenges of New Music movement was Ramon P. Santos. During his studies in the United States, Santos first wrote pieces in the neoclassic idiom such as Suite for Flute, Clarinet, Viola, Cello, and Piano, for chamber orchestra, and in atonal language like Music for Nine Instruments, and Pied Beauty. He later focused his creative energies on experimental procedures, as in his Time Improvisations, Toccata for one piano and two performers, and open-ended forms, like his Five Pieces for Two Pianos. He began to use timbres from Philippine instruments in his Ding Ding Nga Diyawa (Beat the Gongs) and in the two-act opera-tableau Ang Puting Waling-Waling (The White Orchid). Upon his return to the Philippines, he expanded his compositional horizons by incorporating concepts of other musical traditions that he was able to study—Chinese, Indonesian, and northern and southern Philippines. His interest in the functional aspects of traditional music was shown in Para Sa Intermisyon (For the Intermission) and Ritwal ng Pasasalamat (Thanksgiving Ritual). His concern for nature and the environment could be gleaned from Likas-an (Nature-ing), and his love for multiart forms from Siklo (Cycle), Awit (Song), Ta-O (Per-son), Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau), and Daragang Magayon.

 

Santos’s contemporary, FranciscoF.Feliciano, studied in Germany and the United States, where he mastered the latest techniques in textural writing and creating sound architectures from simple tonal materials. Some of his major works included Fragments and Verkläerung Christi for large orchestra; Transfiguration for orchestra, chorus, and narrator; Isostasie III for strings and woodwind; and Eight Character Pieces for solo timpani, five timpani, trombone, bassoon, and contrabass. Two of his large-scale contributions to modern music theater were his ballet Yerma and the full-length modern opera La Loba Negra on the libretto of the diva and opera director Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. In his orchestral work Pagdakila sa Kordilyera (Ode to Cordillera), Feliciano incorporated Philippine ethnic instruments in his score. In addition to composition and conducting, Feliciano also established the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music, a school devoted to the exploration of traditional musical idioms in Asia for utilization in Christian liturgy and worship.

 

In the 1970s, a notable degree of ideas surfaced in some of the works of the older colleagues of Santos, Feliciano, and De Leon. In 1972, Lucrecia R. Kasilag wrote Ekologie I: On a Day Off for tape recorder and indigenous instruments, Five Portraits: A Parody for two amplified pianos, gongs, and transistor radio, and Diversions for violin, cello, harp, piano, percussion, and taped sounds of Kalinga instruments. In 1971, RamonTapales composed Sonata Satirica, an improvisation piece for solo violin. Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Fantasy for Four Flutes and Percussion, 1975, Tatlong Tunog Larawan (Three Sound Portraits) for orchestra, 1976, and Concerto for Flute and Orchestra, 1980, all represented a departure from the conventional harmonic idioms and attempt new tonal combinations and textures. Other works by romanticist-impressionist composers who had been influenced by 20th-century art music included Suite No. 2 for string quartet, 1971, by AntoninoBuenaventura, The Strutting Peacock and Ang Manok at ang Bayawak (The Rooster and the Iguana) by HilarionF.Rubio, and Reminiscence by AlfredoS.Buenaventura.

 

 

BayaniM. deLeon, son of FelipePadilladeLeon, almost of the same age as Santos and Feliciano, started his career as a composer by writing sarsuwela, such as Handog ng Diyos (God’s Offering), Hibik Sa Karimlan (Cries in the Dark) and progressive pieces for the rondalla like Tatlong Bulaklak (Three Flowers) and Mulawin (Molave Tree). He tried to contradict his own basic materials from existing folk melodies, transforming them into new structural elements that assumed different characters. He applied the technique in such major works as Pagkamulat (Awakening) symphonic poem, Bahay-bata (Mother’s Womb), and Arok-Diwa (The Depths of the Soul). De Leon’s interest in the relationship between the material symbols of sound and the cosmic universe is illustrated by two of his compositions written while learning avant-garde techniques at the University of California in San Diego: Puso (Heart), based on yin and yang, and space and time; and Okir which is about the forces that shape agents in the universe.

 

Young composers of new music in this period included Ruben Federizon whose works combined new music techniques and structural properties of Philippine and Asian music, and were characterized by percussive rhythms and imaginative fusion of tone colors derived from the sounds of native instruments as in RitmosTabulare and Tinig ng Lupa (Voice of the Earth). Chino Toledo created constantly permuting sound architectures made up of mode-oriented melodic layers in Ug-nay (Link) and Kulambo: Isang Kayumangging Puntod (Mosquito Net: A Brown Grave). He explored improvisational procedures in Samu’t sari (Variety) and Terminal Lamentations. Contemporary issues also found their place in Toledo’s writings, as in For Edwin Thumboo and All of Us Who Suffer Through English in Asia for soprano, clarinet, oboe, vibraphone and cello. Verne de la Peña expanded the idea of the drone in N(y)uma for 36 Voices and Asian Instruments. He also composed several interesting multimedia works such as the puppettheater Si Suan, Si Suan (It’s Suan, It’s Suan). Jonas Baes used nonconventional sound sources such as scrapers and leaves, and involved the audience in his works, as in Pangtawag (Music for Calling People) and Kalipay (Happiness).

 

Semiclassical Music

 

Traditional sarsuwela continued to be produced in the countryside like in the Ilocos region where it had a continuous life. In Manila, however, it lost an audience after mass media, i.e., radio, sound film, and TV dominated the entertainment scene since the 1930s. In the late 1960s to early 1970s, a revival movement emerged with the restaging of Sundalong Mantika (Sluggish Soldier) and Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) by the Centro Escolar University, Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness) by the Ateneo de Manila University, and AngKiri (The Flirt) by the CCP and by the management of the newly restored MetropolitanTheater. The Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines was established by the famous columnist Teodoro Valencia specifically to reproduce old sarsuwela and commission new ones. With these fresh initiatives, works such as Walang Sugat (No Wounds) and Ana Maria were reconstructed and reproduced, while new works were written and composed such as Isagani Cruz and Lutgardo Labad’s Halimaw (Monster).

 

 

Modern sarsuwelas tackled socially relevant issues of the day such as militarization, the foreign-dominated local economy, and the colonial tendencies of the Filipino. Thus, creative nationalists who were mainly anti-martial law and anti-Marcos like Amelia Lapeña-Bonfacio and Fabian Obispo came up with Ang Bundok (The Mountain), 1977, and Nicanor Tiongson and Lutgardo Abad, Louie Pascasio, Lucien Letaba finished Pilipinas Circa 1907, 1982. Some sarsuwela, however, were not politically themed like Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow), 1976, by Domingo Landicho and Reynaldo Paguio, Miss Philippines, 1980, by Isagani Cruz and Reynaldo Paguio, and Ang Palabas Bukas (Tomorrow’s Show), 1979, by Bienvenido Lumbera and Lucio San Pedro.

 

After the music world was roused by the success of rock operas such as Hair, Jesus Christ Superstar, and Godspell, the local popmusic scene saw the creation of Pinoy counterparts in Gomburza written by Philip Monserrat and Chinggay Diaz-Lagdameo, TalesoftheManuvu by Nonong Pedero and Bienvenido Lumbera, the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s May-I, May-I, 1979, NukleyarI, 1983,and NukleyarII, 1985, and Ateneo de Davao’s Sa Bundok ng Apo (At Mount Apo). The music of the last three musicals was eclectic and was designed by Joey Ayala.

 

A distinctive set of songs in semiclassical forms like march and anthem, and in simple, homophonic strophic structure with singable melodies came from this period and could be conveniently called “songs of the New Society.” This music repertory was dished out by the state and was purposively propagandistic, conveying messages of the militarized power of the Marcos administration and its cronies. Felipe de Leon Sr composed many of these anthems and marches, the most popular of which were the “Bagong Lipunan” (Hymn of the New Society) and the “Bagong Pagsilang” (March of the New Society). Other songs in the repertory were “Mabuhay” (Long Live), “Masagana 99” (Prosperous 99), “Magtanim, Magtanim” (Plant), and “Ako Ay Pilipino” (I Am A Filipino). These were used to gather support for Marcos’s projects, even from among its avowed enemies. As Ferdinand Marcos once said of the New Society songs, “these songs very well express what I have conceived of the New Society. I am confident that these will tame the restless hearts of some of our countrymen who have bitterness and hate in their hearts” (as cited in de Leon 1974, 13). Imelda, on the other hand, highlighted the importance of music in the fulfillment of the New Society’s goals. According to her, “it is our ardent hope that this collective work of our artists…will further inspire our people to greater heights of achieving the aims of national reformation to which we are all committed” (7).

 

Designed to sell the concept of “democratic revolution or the revolution from the center,” this type of propaganda music was disseminated through vinyl record albums. “Bagong Pagsilang” (New Birth), “Bagong Lipunan” (New Society), “Bagong Buhay” (New Life), “Tayo’y Magtanim” (Let Us Plant), “Awit ng Magsasaka” (Farmer’s Song), “Masagana 99 “ (Bountiful 99), “Karunungan” (Wisdom), “Magandang Pilipinas” (Beautiful Philippines), “Pasko sa Bagong Lipunan” (Christmas in the New Society), and “Isang Bansa, Isang Diwa” (One Nation, One Spirit) were regularly played on the radio. They were printed in the book Mga Awit sa Bagong Lipunan (Songs in the New Society), 1974, and sung in the classroom as part of the everyday activities in school. Some children were even brought to the political rallies held at the Luneta Park to help increase attendance and to make them experience firsthand the euphoria at rallies hailing the strongman. Probably the most popular march then was “Bagong Pagsilang” (March of the New Society), with lyrics by Levi Celerio and music by Felipe Padilla de Leon:

 

Ang gabi’y nagmaliw nang ganap

At lumipas na ang magdamag.

 

Madaling araw ay nagdiriwang

May umagang namasdan.

 

Ngumiti na ang pag-asa

Sa umagang anong ganda.

 

May bagong silang, may bago nang buhay

Bagong bansa, bagong galaw, sa Bagong Lipunan

 

Nagbabago ang lahat tungo sa pag-unlad

At ating itanghal Bagong Lipunan

 

(Night has passed

A new day has come.

 

There’s revelry at the break of dawn

A new day has come.

 

Hope smiles

At the morn so full of beauty.

 

There’s new birth, new life

New country, new ways, in the New Society

 

Everything changes towards progress

Let us all hail the New Society.)

 

A popular hymn then was “Bagong Lipunan” (Hymn of the New Society), with lyrics and music by Felipe Padilla de Leon:

 

Ang bayan kong may dangal

Puri’t kagitingan

Dagat, bundok ay sagana

At kay yaman ng lupa.

 

Pilipinas sa piling mo

Maligaya ang buhay ko

Bagong Lipunan ang dapat

Malaon nating hinahangad.

(My country has honor

Pride and courage

The seas and mountains, bountiful

The soil, fertile.

 

Philippines, in your arms

My life is joyful

New Society it must be

We had been longing for.)

 

Aside from songs that exulted the creation of the New Society, the Marcos regime commissioned works that promoted a variety of flagship projects. The song “Masagana 99” (Bountiful 99), which was first heard in 1973, proudly sings of the bountiful harvest brought about by the new technology that produced 99 cavans of rice per hectare:

 

Kung wasto ang pag-aalaga sa bukid na sinasaka

Ang ani’y sasagana, pamumuhay sasagana.

Paunlarin natin ang palayan sa makabagong paraan

“Masagana Ninety-nine” kaban-kaban na karagdagan

Makakamtan sa sakahan pati na rin ang ating bayan

Tutungo sa kaunlaran.

 

(If proper care is used in farming

Harvest will increase, life will be more prosperous

Let us improve the fields with modern technology

“Masagana Ninety-nine” will yield more rice

For the country, and the nation will prosper.)

 

The launch of “Masagana 99” went hand in hand with an earlier Imelda Marcos project, the Green Revolution, which was launched at Nayong Pilipino in 1971. This project encouraged the populace to use idle plots to greening and livestock raising in order to help alleviate the threat of food insufficiency. “Tayo’y Magtanim” (Let Us Plant) also has lyrics and music by Felipe Padilla de Leon:

 

Lahat ng makakain ay ating itanim

Magtanim, magtanim, tayo’y magtanim

Gawing kulay luntian, bansang minamahal

Tayo nang magtanim upang mabuhay.

 

Magtanim (magtanim) Magtanim (magtanim)

Tayo nang magtanim upang mabuhay

Magtanim (magtanim) Magtanim (magtanim)

Tayo nang magtanim upang mabuhay.

 

(Let us plant everything that we can eat

Plant, plant, let us plant

Let us make our beloved country green

Let us plant to live.

 

Plant, plant

Let us plant to live

Plant, plant

Let us plant to live.)

 

The regime also boasted of the improved plight of farmers. Through Presidential Decree No 27 or the Land Reform Act signed on 21 Oct 1972, tenants were supposedly emancipated from their servitude to feudal lords. As this law decreed, ownership of the land they tilled would be transferred to them. The song “Awit ng Magsasaka” (Land Reform March), with lyrics by Tess Pulido and music by De Leon, trumpeted this “triumph over feudalism”:

 

Narito kaming magsasaka

Ngayo’y nagsisipagbunyi

Pagka’t kami’y pinalad na

Sa adhika at lunggati.

 

Kaming lahat noon ay kasama

Sa paggawa’y lubhang api

Nagbubungkal ng pagsinta

Ano’t gutom pa rin kami.

 

Nagbubungkal ng pagsinta

Ano’t gutom pa rin kami.

 

Tanikalang kaalipnan

Nilagot na nitong batas

Ang kasikeng patakaran

Ay naglaho na ring ganap.

 

Aming lupang binubungkal

Sarili na’t aming amin

Salamat po, Poong Mahal

Kami’y hindi na alipin.

 

(We farmers are here

Rejoicing

Fortunate are we

In purpose and aspiration.

 

We were all vassals

At work, always downtrodden

We cultivate love

And yet we starve.

 

We cultivate love

And yet we starve.

 

Chains of slavery

Broken by this law

The cacique way

Totally erased.

 

The land that we till

Finally we own

Thank you, Lord

We have been freed from slavery.)

 

State support in the use of the Tagalog language also translated into commissioned songs in the lingua franca. The regime exerted much effort towards this end. This was in essence a policy towards decolonization. Songs in the vernacular proliferated during this period.

 

The New Society was more than an attempt to create an ideal society. It was also an imagined birthing of the new Filipino, with Imelda as the Society’s mother, and Ferdinand, the father. The couple had themselves depicted as the mythical Filipino progenitors, Malakas and Maganda (“The Powerful” and “The Beautiful,” respectively) to legitimize their claim of having authority over the Filipino nation. In this created society, everyone was pictured as living in a truly happy state in an ideal place—a utopia. Songs like “Magandang Pilipinas” (Beautiful Philippines), composed by Julian Balita, emphasized this point:

 

Lupa ng kagandahan, ating masdan!

Lahing magiliw na tunay, kayumangging kulay.

 

Tayo ay may kundimang awit ng buhay,

Sa suyuang walang hanggan ay tapat.

Sa langit ng ating bayan

Ang buwan at bit’win kay inam tingnan!

 

Dito’y may saganang lupa na nagpapasigla sa madla.

Magandang Pilipinas, mabiyaya at mapalad,

Laging kay saya ng buhay at may bago nang lipunan.

 

(Let us gaze upon this land of beauty!

This loving brown race.

 

We have kundiman, our song of life,

Honest in endless courtship.

Under the heavens of our land,

The moon and the stars are lovely to gaze upon.

 

Here land is bountiful, it energizes the people.

Lovely Philippines, blessed and fortunate.

Life is ever cheerful, and there is a new society.)

 

To further boost state propaganda in the time of military rule, the Department of Education and Culture, through the initiative of the First Lady, launched the National Song Writing Contest in 1973. The winning works of the competition, which were also included in the book Songs in the New Society, were “O Bayan Kong Pilipinas” (My Country Philippines) by V. Neniel, “Diwa ng Bagong Lipunan” (Spirit of the New Society) by I. de los Reyes, and “Paraiso Kong Bayan” (My Country is a Paradise) by R. Babat.

 

All the songs of the New Society had one end: to propagate an unquestioning “patriotism” that would cover up the many abuses committed in the name of the New Society. Babat’s “Paraiso Kong Bayan” (My Country is a Paradise) reflected this objective:

 

Paraiso ang ating bayan

Pugad ng laya’t kaligayahan

May dangal at giting na taglay

At sagana sa lahat ng bagay.

 

Ang Bagong Lipunan ang s’yang may dulot

Ng biyayang sa ati’y isinabog

Anong tamis nang mabuhay sa paraisong bayan.

 

(Our land is a paradise

Home of freedom and happiness

It has honor and valor

Bountiful in everything.

 

The New Society brought all these

The blessings bestowed upon us

How sweet it is to live in this paradise of a land.)

 

Outside of this New Society repertory, traditional but semiclassicized forms like the kundiman and danza composed from the previous decades continued to have an audience. These were sung by groups like Mabuhay Singers whose repertoire best illustrates music that was kundimanin (kundiman-like) in approach for its tender lyricism.

 

Imelda Marcos herself had used the traditional danza, in particular Miguel Velarde’s danza “Dahil Sa ‘Yo” (Because of You), to enchant the public with her singing persona. She started this to elicit support during her campaigns for her husband in the previous decade. After 1986, she used the same song to solicit sympathy from TV audiences during interviews connected with her public trials on corruption.

 

But some traditional kundiman became associated with the anti-Marcos movement. Originally a protest song against the American imperialists, the most popular semiclassical kundiman of 1928 by Constancio de Guzman resurfaced as the radical anthem of the underground movement against the Marcos dictatorship and later of the middle class protesters after the Aquino assassination. “Bayan Ko” was sung by the huge crowds that staged the 1986 People Power Revolt. Another song, which used lyrics from an old poem related to the fight against Spain, reawakened the revolutionary impulse. Andres Bonifacio’s “Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Lupa” (Love for the Native Land) was given a new melody by Salvador Jorque to condemn both colonialism and authoritarianism.

 

Popular Music

 

Popular music produced by the music industry gained more presence in the national landscape with the availability of portable radios, cassette recorders, and especially TV. They were marketed as commodities in the physical forms of vinyl records and audiocassettes. The bombardment of American rock and pop music in the Philippines intensified, along with the marketing of consumer electronic products that played it. Songwriter Jim Paredes conceded that majority of Filipinos grew up with American music.

 

Hit songs, which were decided by the American music industry’s Top 40 chart, spawned local imitations across different music genres. From having local versions of Elvis Presley, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez, and Peter and Paul and Mary in the 1960s, the martial law years saw the proliferation of Bee Gees, Village People, and Karen Carpenter wannabes.

 

These developments pushed Filipino entrepreneurs to respond to this Anglo-American music invasion. On 8 Mar 1977, the Popular Music Foundation of the Philippines (PMPF) was established by people from the music industry and the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP). PMPF was founded to systematically promote the development of Filipino popular music, which had begun to rise in 1970.

 

The Broadcast Media Council (BMC) also passed resolution B75-31, mandating the airing of at least one Filipino composition every hour in all music radio stations. With the overflow of new compositions and the tremendous response of the record industry in providing a steady supply of “musical commodities,” Resolution 77-35 was then passed requiring the playing of two original Filipino works for every hour of broadcast. The number of works was raised to four later on. This helped counter American domination of local music radio broadcasts.

 

The launch of PMPF’s Metro Manila Popular Music Festival or MetroPop on 15 Aug 1977 signaled the gathering momentum of the Filipino popular music industry. The grand prizewinner of the first Metropop in 1978 was Ryan Cayabyab’s “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful is Our Music) sung by Hajji Alejandro. The second prize went to Nonoy Gallardo’s “Pagdating Mo” (When You Arrive), which was sung by Celeste Legaspi. Third and fourth prizes went respectively to Nonong Pedero’s “Narito Ako Umiibig” (I Am Here, In Love) sung by Maricris Bermont and Vic Villafuerte’s and Tinio’s “Ibig Kong Ibigin Ka” (I Want to Love You), which was interpreted by Anthony Castelo. Freddie Aguilar’s song “Anak” (Child) was only a finalist in that competition, but it was such an international hit that it merited translations in more than 20 foreign languages.

 

Metropop and the BMC ruling gave original Pilipino music (OPM), the umbrella term for all locally produced Filipino pop music, a stronger presence over the airwaves and made it more marketable. Radio became a level playing field for both the foreign and the local. As a result, OPM flourished in the 1980s and 1990s. Philippine popularmusic started to reflect the Philippine situation. More and more composers began to use street lingo to deliver their message. Inspired by the commercial success of “Hahabol-habol” (Chasing After) and Pilita Corrales winning the Best Singer award at the Tokyo Music Festival for her rendition of George Canseco’s “My Daughter,” they wrote more songs in both Tagalog and English.

 

Pinoy Ballads. The popular songs of the 1970s combined elements from the American ballad, Broadway, and light kundiman. These included Atek Jacinto’s “People Gotta Save the World,” Willy Cruz’s “Araw-Araw, Gabi-Gabi” (Every Day, Every Night), Jose Mari Chan’s “Refrain,” Philip Monserrat’s “Ang Puso Kong Nagmamahal” (My Heart that Loves), Canseco’s “Ngayonat Kailanman“ (Now and Forever), Gines Tan’s “MagsimulaKa” (Take the First Step), Louie Ocampo’s “Ewan” (I Don’t Know), and Charo Unite’s “Lupa” (Earth).

 

Heavy, heart-wrenching ballads were also very popular. Their lyrics spoke of unrequited love, lost love, free love, and unfaithfulness. “Sige, Malaya Ka Na” (Sure, You’re Free to Go) by singer Eva Eugenio, “Bakit Ako Mahihiya” (Why Should I Be Ashamed) by Didith Reyes, and Dulce’s “Ako ang Nasawi, Ako ang Nagwagi” (I Failed, I Triumphed) were big hits with the masses.

 

International popularmusic competitions like the World Popular Song Festival and Tokyo Music Festival, as well as local contests like Metropop, which ran from 1978 to 1985, and Himig Awards, catapulted to fame many young singing talents, many of them balladeers: BasilValdez, Ray-An Fuentes, Leo Valdez, HajjiAlejandro, Jun Polistico, RicoJ.Puno, Didith Reyes, CelesteLegaspi, Jacqui Magno, ReyValera, Janet Basco, Imelda Papin, Leah Navarro, KuhLedesma, among others. Noted groups and other solo singers also became popular like the New Minstrels, Ambivalent Crowd, the ApoHikingSociety, and the Circus Band and singers Sharon Cuneta, Nonoy Zuñiga, Eva Eugenio, and Anthony Castelo.

 

This period was also a creative time for film music writers who wrote songs that were substantially balladic in style. Ernani Cuenco’s “Diligin ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa” (Drench the Parched Earth with Dew), 1975, “Ang Bakya Mo Neneng” (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977, and “Bato sa Buhangin” (Pebble in the Sand), 1976, were just few of the notable songs for movies that had substantial airtime.

 

Pinoy Rock. Pinoy rock was the offshoot of the rock boom of the 1960s, when groups equipped with electronic instruments, then known as combos, began to make their presence felt in the local music scene. The distinct and politically charged Pinoy rock, with the typical gritty voice of its vocalists, were unique products of the early 1970s. Juan de la Cruz Band released the single “Ang Himig Natin” (Our Hymn) and opened the floodgates of Pinoy rock. The Juan de la Cruz Band consisted of drummer/vocalist Joey “Pepe” Smith, guitarist Wally Gonzalez, and bassist Mike Hanopol. “AngHimigNatin” was an anthem of sorts for a generation of Filipino youths. Other hits by the band were “Beep-Beep,” “Balong Malalim” (Deep Well), “Project,” “Sarap ng Buhay” (Good Life), “LakisaLayaw” (Spoiled Brat), and “Panahon” (Time). When the band broke up years later, Mike Hanopol embarked on a solo career, producing his own albums Buhay Musikero (Musician’s Life) and Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), while Wally Gonzales also waxed a solo album, Tunog Pinoy (Filipino Sound). The grand old man of Pinoy rock, Joey “Pepe” Smith, has kept a low profile, but appears from time to time in concerts and TV shows. Other notable Pinoy rock songs of the time included Maria Cafra’s “Pangako” (Promise) and “Cool Ka Lang, Pare” (Keep Cool, Man); Sampaguita’s “Bonggahan” (Razzle-dazzle), “Laguna,” “Nosi Balasi” (Who Are They), and “Tao” (Man); Anak Bayan’s “Probinsiyana” (Country Girl) and “Jeepney Rock”; Frictions’ “Perwisyo sa Lipunan”; and Banyuhay’s “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy” (We Are Filipinos).

 

In the 1980s, Pinoy rock slowly faded while its various spin-offs took center stage: folk rock as created by FreddieAguilar, Florante, Asin, Heber Bartolome and Banyuhay, Coritha, Bag-iw, Buklod, and Mike Hanopol; ethnic rock as popularized by Pen-Pen; and punk rock, featuring repetitive riffs and deliberately offensive lyrics by the Betrayed, Chaos, and Urban Bandits. In the 1990s, Pinoy rock further evolved, with new and old names such as the Dawn, Color It Red, Binky Lampano, Advent Call, Tropical Depression, Jerks, and Coco Jam. Bands such as Side A, Neocolours, Introvoys, and Afterimage were identified with soft rock.

Manila Sound. An important type of OPM came with the “Manila Sound,” which was characterized by romantic lyrics, often in “Taglish,” the urban jargon of students in Manila’s exclusive schools which combines Tagalog and English words and phrases. These catchy tunes catered mainly to teenagers. The Hotdog band started the trend with “Ikaw Ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You Are the Miss Universe of My Life). This was followed by “Pers Lab” (First Love), “Manila,” and “Bitin Ako sa Iyo” (You Keep Me Hanging), which captured the fancy of young people from all walks of life. Hotdog’s other hits include “Annie Batungbakal” and “Bongga Ka ‘Day” (You’re Fabulous, Girl). Another stalwart of the Manila Sound, Cinderella, capitalized on Hotdog’s success and came out with their own monster hits: “T.L. Ako sa Iyo” (I’m Truly in Love With You), “Superstar ng Buhay Ko” (Superstar of My Life), “Ang Boyfriend kong Baduy” (My Gaudy Boyfriend), and “Mr. DJ” that was popularized by Sharon Cuneta.

 

Childlike songs like Nonoy Gallardo’s “Saranggola ni Pepe” (Pepe’s Kite), sung by Celeste Legaspi, and Jose Mari Chan’s “Mamang Sorbetero” (Ice Cream Man), also sung by Celeste Legaspi, were some of local pop music’s hits that competed with the American top hits of that period.

 

Pinoy Disco. Pinoy disco began in the Philippines with the introduction of salsa music from New York Latinos in the mid-1970s. In 1976 the local disco album Blackbuster was released internationally, containing the songs written by localrecord industry executive Orly Ilacad under the pseudonym “J. Harris.”

 

Filipino pop music groups closely copied the disco music styles that had been developed by foreign groups such as the Bee Gees from Australia and the Village People from the United States, which topped the international charts. Imitating the Bee Gees to their last vocal vibrato were the Boyfriends with their hit “Sumayaw, Sumunod” (Dance,Follow),and VST and Co. which came out with “Disco Fever,” “Rock Baby Rock,” and “Awitin Mo, Isasayaw Ko” (Sing and I Will Dance). The Village People, on the other hand, was localized by Hagibis, a five-man group that projected Pinoy machismo in their singing style.

 

Due to the strong influence of Michael Jackson in the 1980s and 1990s, disco music even intensified due to GaryValenciano and his “Di Bale Na Lang” (Never Mind) and “Heto Na Naman” (Here It Comes Again), performed complete with his own commanding stage maneuvers.

 

Pinoy Folk. Filipino artists have used the folk ballad to communicate nationalist ideas and semididactic messages, and to convey their rebellion against authority and convention. Simple strophic melodies were combined with texts that were either poetic or steeped in political rhetoric. The songs could be a diatribe against Filipino colonial mentality, a plea for freedom from tyranny especially in the context of the Marcos regime, or an espousal of positive Filipino values.

 

Florante rose to fame with “Ako’y Pinoy” (I Am a Filipino), which celebrated love for the local national language, and “Handog” (Offering), while HeberBartolome and his band Banyuhay came out with “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy” (We are Filipinos) and “Nena.” FreddieAguilar’s international hit “Anak” (Child) was a semibiographical ballad about Filipino family values. InangLaya, composed of KarinaConstantino-David and Becky Demetillo-Abraham, specialized in protest music, dwelling on such issues as feminism in “Babae” (Women) and US military presence in the Philippines in “Base Militar” (Military Base). Folk singer Coritha sang of love and longing for the home in “Si Lolo Jose” (Grandfather Jose) and “Sierra Madre.” Other names that gained prominence in the Pinoy folk idiom, singing songs against oppression, political corruption, and environmental pollution were Susan Fernandez-Magno, JessSantiago, GaryGranada, and Noel Cabangon.

 

Folk groups penetrated the mainstream popular music scene and left their mark on the period’s soundscape. Like its mainstream pop variety, they were self-conscious, if not more so, of their Filipino identity. Banyuhay carried with it the trademark kubing (mouth harp) sound in “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy.” Asin, a folk music band, combined indigenous with mainstream band instruments. Some of the albums the band released included Asin (Salt), 1978, Himig ng Pag-ibig (Melody of Love), 1979, Himig ng Lahi (Melody of the Race), 1983, and Ang Mga Awitin ng Bayan Kong Pilipinas (Songs of My Country the Philippines), 1984. In the last album, the group incorporated traditional and contemporary songs gathered from different provinces in the Philippines. They also came up with socially relevant songs like “Ang Bayan Kong Sinilangan” (My Native Land), “Bayan Ko” (My Country), and “Masdan Ang Kapaligiran” (Look at the Environment).

 

The propaganda of the New Society songs had the opposite effect—the creation of a wide variety of songs of resistance from songwriters who reacted against the government’s unidirectional flow of power and who were sensitive to the needs of the poor and wanted to reveal the depths of injustice inflicted on the weak and the marginalized. Protest songs that were performed during street demonstrations or in underground meetings were usually in folk music style that intersected with diverse idioms—from pop to rock. The use of an amplified acoustic guitar, however, was characteristic of most of these songs. Handclapping and simple percussion instruments like drum and tambourine were also utilized to underscore the spirited protest, and the audience usually sang along with the singer/s. Performers like Susan Fernandez-Magno and Inang Laya were at the forefront of anti-martial law demonstrations.

 

The songs of resistance narrated the lives and struggles of the proletariat. Songs like “Sino Ang Manggagawa” (Who are the Proletarians) by Rody Vera of Patatag throbbed with lines that depicted the plight of the peasants and wage earners:

 

Kung ang magsasaka’y nakatali sa lupa

Ang manggawa’y nakatali sa wala

Iniwan ang bukid upang suyurin ang Maynila

Tanging maibenta ay lakas-paggawa.

 

(If a farmer is tied to the land

The laborer is tied to nothing

He left the ricefield to set out in Manila

His only capital is his skill.)

 

Other songs by Patatag such as “Welga” (Strike) and “Papuri sa Sosyalismo” (In Praise of Socialism) were blatantly anti-capitalist. Songs in this genre also included “Ang Buhay ng Proletaryo” (The Life of a Proletarian) by Francisco Laba Jr, “Huling Balita” (Latest News) and “Halina” (Come), both by Jess Santiago, and “Butil ng Palay,” (Grain of Rice) by Jess Satiago and Inang Laya.

 

Translations of foreign songs from the socialist movement were also done, foremost of which was “Internasyonal” (“The Internationale”), a song based on a poem by Eugene Pottier. It was written for the Paris Commune of 1871 and set to music by Pierre De Geyter in 1888. Other song translations included “Awit ng Nagkakaisang Hanay” (“United Front Song”), translated from the original French by the group Patatag; “Pandaigdigang Awit ng Manggagawa” (International Workers’ Song), also translated from French; and “Tumindig Ka” (Stand Up) by Victor Jara, one of the main proponents of the Nueva Cancion (New Song) socialist democratic political movement in Chile, translated by Jess Santiago from the original Spanish.

 

Published protest song collections, although undated, are worth mentioning here. These include Mga Kanta ng Rebolusyon ng Pilipino (The Filipino Songs of the Revolution), Paghahasik: Mga Awit ng Pabrika’t Lansangan (Sowing Seeds: Songs of the Factory and the Streets), and You are not Forgotten: Symbols During Martial Law. These collections captured a time when creativity and mass protests were at their zenith.

 

Novelty Songs. Novelty songs treated life lightly. Yoyoy Villame (Roman Tesorio Villame in real life) was a huge success in this genre. His songs about Philippine history and the Filipino’s way of life included the hits “Magellan,” 1972, “The Bible,” “Mag-eksersays Tayo” (Let’s Exercise), 1977, “Trapik” (Traffic), and “Diklamasyon” (Declamation), “Philippine Geography,” 1977, and “Butse Kik,” 1980. He came out with record albums titled Yoyoy, 1977, Yoyoy Is Barok (Yoyoy is Coarse), 1978, Gi-Indyan (Discarded), 1978, Harana ni Yoyoy (Yoyoy’s Serenade), 1981, and Tigmo (Riddle), 1980. With his highly witty narrative poetry sung to simple folk song-style tunes in a heavy Cebuano accent, his songs catered to a more plebeian audience. Another exponent of the genre, Max Surban, composed songs in both Filipino and Cebuano.

 

Mainstream Jazz. Appreciation of jazz as a unique form of musical entertainment came into its own in the Philippines in the 1950s and 1960s, after the genre was emancipated to a certain degree from its stereotype connection with the music of the dance bands of the swing era.

 

While jazz generally flourished in hotels and cocktail lounges, jazz concerts were occasionally held such as the annual Upsilon Sigma Phi concerts at the UP, which drew fairly large audiences. Some of the more prominent artist-exponents of Philippine jazz were Exequiel “Lito” Molina and the Jazz Friends, Romy Posadas, Angel M. Peña, Piding Alava, Romy Katindig, and Fred Robles. They sometimes experimented on the use of folk tunes as basic melodic materials for improvisation and imbued the tunes with characteristic jazz rhythms and chord progressions.

 

In 1978, Dr. Joseph Howard, a visiting Fulbright professor in jazz, formally established the UP Jazz Ensemble (small and big bands) which has since been specializing in mainstream jazz and providing basic training in the idiom to young progressive artists.

 

Pinoy Jazz Fusion. In the 1960s, the fusing of elements of rhythm-and-blues and the heavy, highly amplified variety of rock music came to be known as jazz fusion. Later, the term referred to the merger of jazz with other pop music genres as exemplified by the music of Larry Corel, Stanley Clarke, and George Duke.

In the Philippines, among the pioneers in jazz fusion were Eddie Munji and RyanCayabyab. Munji came out in the 1970s with his First Modern Pinoy Jazz album, where he set traditional Filipino songs to jazz rhythms. Cayabyab, a composer whose academic background afforded him wider exposure to different musical idioms, adapted traditional tunes and rhythms into the jazz idiom in his experimental From Roots to Routes. The fusion of jazz, Broadway music, and Philippine indigenous music characterizes the music of Cayabyab, as deemed from his more serious compositions like Misa (Mass), Maria Makiling, and Kapinangan, to his lighter pop songs like “KayGandangAtingMusika“ (How Beautiful is Our Music), “Isang Awit” (One Song), “Tsismis” (Gossip), and “Paraisong Parisukat (Square Paradise).

 

Other Filipino artists in the 1970s who were identified with jazz fusion were Bong Peñera and his Batucada band, whose music consisted of blending Tagalog lyrics and the Brazilian samba beat. The Vanishing Tribe also fused ethnic melodies and rhythms with progressive jazz-rock forms. Later exponents of Pinoy jazz fusion included Boy Katindig, EddieKatindig, Tots Tolentino, Rudy Lozano, Menchu Apostol, and Pete Canzon. John Lesaca introduced the classical violin as an effective jazz instrument, while internationally acclaimed jazz pianist Bobby Enriquez awed listeners with his unorthodox piano technique and musical intensity.

 

Ethnic Pop. The 1980s saw a new trend in the evolution of Philippine popular music. While the music of the previous decade Filipinized and vernacularized popular song styles, leading to the discovery of many talented local performers and songwriters, Pinoy pop remained Western in concept and idiom. Taking their cue from the art music researches and experiments with indigenous elements as well as from the innovative efforts of RyanCayabyab, folk music groups began to incorporate sounds and elements from indigenous and folk music traditions.

 

The use of Philippine folk instruments and motives in pop music like in the Bagong Tunog (New Sound) of Ryan Cayabyab became a fad. This neoethnic style was both incorporative of and oppositional to Anglo-American pop. Asin sung traditional folk songs to rock beat. Their hits included “Masdan Ang Kapaligiran” (Look at the Environment), “Ang Bayan Kong Sinilangan” (The Land of My Birth), and “Pagbabalik” (Return). Their songs were sometimes preceded by short preludes played on native instruments. Indigenous instruments such as the kubing, kulintang, tongatong, agung, and faglong were also used by rock groups like Lokal Brown and Grupong Pendong. Ethnic pop, in essence, sought to integrate ethnic elements—musical structures, instruments, costumes—into pop music culture. Emil Sanglay, who sought to promote this type of sound, even experimented with Muslim-inspired rhythms in 1970, with his band Penpen.

 

While the above ventures into the realms of ethnicity were still anchored on Western pop culture, recent endeavors reflect the desire to create new music and musical idioms from indigenous sources within the context of mass culture. EdruAbraham and his Kontra-Gapi (Kontemporaryong Gamelang Pilipino), a University of the Philippines-based group, experiment on new compositions by fusing various Philippine music traditions (i.e., pre-Christian, rural folk music) and modern song styles. JoeyAyala incorporates instrumental sounds from Mindanao highland cultures in his music, which can be characterized as a spontaneous fusion of folk ballad style and minimalist structural elements.

 

In Aug 1983, the anti-Marcos movement used the American pop song “Tie A Yellow Ribbon Round the Ole Oak Tree,” originally sung by the pop music group Tony Orlando and Dawn, to welcome Ninoy Aquino from exile. When Ninoy was assassinated at the Manila International Airport tarmac, yellow became the color of both mourning and defiance. As the regime’s hold on the society started to weaken, the people’s voice began to gather strength. By 1986 dissent had two colors: the yellow, which came to be associated with the pro-Aquino movement, and the red of the democratic Left. Whether red or yellow, the anti-Marcos forces found a common voice, a common enemy to fight, and a common occasion to celebrate—that of freedom from the repressive Marcos regime. During and after the EDSA People Power Revolution, the songs in mainstream pop song style, namely, “Magkaisa” (United), composed by Tito Sotto and sung by Virna Lisa, and “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo” (Filipinos’ Gift to the World) by Jim Paredes, celebrated the end of the dictatorship. Through the latter’s lyrics, the Filipino people’s voice soared as they sang in celebration of their newfound freedom from the dictator:

 

Di na ’ko papayag mawala ka muli

Di na ’ko papayag na muling mabawi

Ating kalayaan kay tagal na nating mithi

Di na papayagang mabawi muli

 

Magkakapit-bisig, libo-libong tao

Kay sarap palang maging Pilipino

Sama-sama iisa ang adhikain

Kailan man di na paalipin

 

Refrain:

Handog ng Pilipino sa mundo

Mapayapang paraang pagbabago

Katotohanan, kalayaan, katarungan

Ay kayang makamit na walang dahas

Basta’t magkaisa tayong lahat

 

Masdan ang nagaganap sa aming bayan

Nagkasama ang mahirap at mayaman

Kapit-bisig madre, pari, at sundalo

Naging Langit itong bahagi ng mundo

 

Huwag muling payagang umiral ang dilim

Tinig ng bawat tao’y bigyan ng pansin

Magkakapatid lahat sa Panginoon

Ito’y lagi nating tatandaan

 

Coda:

Mapayapang paraang pagbabago

Katotohanan, kalayaan, katarungan

Ay kayang makamit na walang dahas

Basta’t magkaisa tayong lahat

 

(I will not allow you to be lost again

I will not allow for you to be taken away again

We’ve longed for our freedom for so long

We won’t let it be taken away again

Thousands of peopleholding hands

It feels good to be Filipino

Bound together by one goal

Never again will we let ourselves be enslaved

Refrain:

Filipinos’ gift to the world

A peaceful way towards change

Truth, freedom, justice

Can be attained without violence

As long as we all stand united

Watch what is unfolding in our country

The poor and the rich are coming together

Hand in hand, nun, priest and soldier

This part of the world is now Heaven

Do not allow darkness to prevail once more

Let every person’s voice be heard

Everyone is brother and sister in the eyes of the Lord

This, we must always understand

Coda:

A peaceful way towards change

Truth, freedom, justice

Can be attained without violence

As long as we all stand united

 

These songs gave credit and voice to the Filipino people who stood up to fight and overthrow a dictator, emphasizing the importance of unity among the citizens as the key to any form of social change. Ironically, it was this element of unity that was soon put to the test in the first year in office of the new president, Corazon C. Aquino. Written by Raul C. Navarro andRamon P. Santos

Historical Background
Classical Music
Semiclassical Music
Popular Music
Conclusion

 

Historical Background

 

The EDSA Revolt of Feb 1986 demonstrated the democratic impulse of the Filipino nation and led to the establishment of a new government under Corazon Aquino. For six years, the Aquino government toiled to restore democracy in the country, ratified a new constitution in 1987, and revitalized government agencies, nongovernment organizations, and private institutions. The Concerned Artists of the Philippines spearheaded the formation of a broad alliance of artists (later to form the Samahan sa Kultura at Sining or SAKSI). This ad hoc group called the Alliance of Artists for the Creation of the Ministry of Culture (AACMC) clamored for democratic change in the arts establishment, proposing the creation of a new ministry dedicated to the administration of the cultural affairs of the country, which later became the basis for the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) Bill proposed by Sen Leticia Shahani. The AACMC’s people-oriented approach to governance contrasted with the “elitist” approach of the Marcos administration, which emphasized the cultivation of Western high art culture. Majority of Filipino artists who had worked underground during the martial law years resurfaced and became involved in the new administration, as did progressive employees working at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Their voices heralded a major social and cultural shift in outlook in the new government.

 

Change in Cultural Policy. After the EDSA Revolt and the change in administration, Pres Aquino appointed a new team to administrate the CCP. Ma. Teresa Roxas took over the helm of the institution from Lucrecia Kasilag who had been its artistic director from 1969-86, and concurrently, its president from 1976-86. Roxas then invited Nicanor Tiongson to be CCP’s artistic director in July of 1986. It was during Roxas and Tiongson’s incumbency that CCP’s thrusts were reconceptualized and pertinent policies implemented. The post-Marcos CCP established five new guiding principles towards the development of state policy in the arts: Filipinization, democratization, decentralization, promotion of artistic excellence, and reorientation of international exchanges. Filipinization meant that CCP should first and foremost actively support Filipino artists and their works; democratization implied that CCP should encourage the participation of audiences from all the social classes in its programs; decentralization, which involved the creation of regional councils in arts and culture, entailed the participation of all regions and sectors towards the creation of a Filipino national culture; promotion of artistic excellence meant CCP should always work towards the highest artistic standards but relative to form and circumstance of production; and reorientation of international exchanges emphasized the promotion of Filipino artists abroad (Tiongson 2009b).

These five principles have guided CCP’s operations since 1986. They influenced the goals of other similar agencies throughout the archipelago, encouraging a more people-oriented representation in the creation and the articulation of the national culture. The institutional goals were to “achieve a national culture evolving with and for all Filipinos ... [through the formation of] a unified cultural consciousness among all Filipinos and the creation of original Filipino works that are rooted in the country’s traditions” (Tiongson 2009b). The encouraging environment fostered the development and growth of art works and productions. Regional artists, as well as those working in Manila, were inspired to produce works that were unique to their local situations and circumstances.

Succeeding leadership at the CCP continued the established democratization thrust of the Roxas-Tiongson administration, aligning the programs of the center to serve the political agenda of each subsequent Philippine president. During the terms of Nestor O. Jardin, who served as president from 2001 to 2009 with Fernando Josef as artistic director from 2001 to 2008, the institutional programs of the CCP were reoriented towards the Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo Administration’s poverty alleviation programs. Another priority program was the CCP Complex Development Project. During the presidency of Benigno Aquino III, the CCP administration, under the leadership of Raul Sunico as president with Chris Millado as artistic director, established new programs supporting the Aquino government’s political agenda, such as Arts Therapy Programs to different communities which suffered disasters, calamities, and even armed conflicts, and intensive outreach and training programs for artists, teachers, students, local government units, and other depressed and disadvantaged communities.

In response to the AACMC proposal, the Aquino government, under Executive Order (EO) 118 dated 30 Jan 1987, created the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts (PCCA), which eventually became the NCCA by virtue of Republic Act (RA) 7356, passed on 8 Apr 1992. NCCA was placed directly under the Office of the President and was tasked to strengthen a Filipino national identity by formulating cultural policies and coordinating the activities that promoted the culture of the people. Section 9 of RA 7356 stated that the commission should be comprised of the undersecretaries, directors, heads, and chairs of various government agencies that are connected to cultural development, among which are the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); the National Historical Institute (NHI); the National Museum; the National Library; and the Department of Education, Culture and Sports (DECS), presently reorganized as the Department of Education (DepEd).

The NCCA evolved from its initial mandate to formulate and implement policies and plans for Filipino cultural and artistic development and has worked as a coordinating body for all governmental cultural agencies as mandated by Executive Order 80 passed on 5 Mar 1999, the Governance of Basic Education Act of 2001 or RA 9155 passed on 11 Aug 2001, and the National Cultural Heritage Act of 2009 or RA 10066 passed on 26 Mar 2010. As the coordinating organization for all affiliated government cultural agencies, NCCA’s grants assistance program for the development, protection, preservation, and dissemination of Philippine culture and arts, was also centralized. Pursuant to RA 7356, the National Endowment Fund for Culture and Arts (NEFCA) was established and its administration assigned to the NCCA.

 

 

 

Effects of Changes in Cultural Policy. The music of the period reflected changes in national cultural policies as well as other developments. The period saw an enormous increase in new works being created, performed, and recorded, and old theatrical productions being restaged. Many musicians were now invigorated by the openness of the new government and the financial and logistical support for their projects provided primarily by the CCP and NCCA. Musicians from the capital enjoyed the freedom to create new provocative works defining the new spirit of the nation. Composers and singers of protest music marginalized during the Marcos presidency found legitimate venues for their performances. Joey Ayala, Heber Bartolome, Susan Fernandez, Gary Granada, and the protest-groups Inang Laya, Buklod, and Patatag rose to national prominence as artists after 1986. There was greater music collaboration between composers and artists using other art forms such as Joey Ayala and Ballet Philippines’ Encantada (Enchantress) and Ramon Santos’s full-length dance drama, Daragang Magayon: An Istorya ni Mayon (Beautiful Maiden: The Story of Mayon).

The period also witnessed the construction of innovative alternative concert venues such as the Casa San Miguel in Zambales and the Hiyas ng Bulakan Convention Center in Bulacan, the proliferation of national and international music festivals, and the increased participation of Filipino musicians in festivals abroad. Music festivals that featured hundreds, if not thousands, of Filipino and foreign participants were mounted in the different regions of the country and supported by national and regional government offices. Local artists in greater numbers pursued higher musical training in Europe and the United States, formerly supported personally by Imelda Marcos but now supported by a variety of sponsors.

Musicologists, music scholars and music critics, also assisted by the new grants and incentives offered by the state agencies, contributed to the national effort by actively participating in the production of books and other publications on Philippine music. The new dispensation fostered an environment open to critical judgments of musical works as seen in the published critiques in new periodicals and journals. Associations of artists, composers, and performers which operated as independent entities in civil society continued to flourish, such as the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP) and the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM).

New awards were also established to recognize artistic excellence such as the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA), the equivalent of the National Artist Award given to indigenous artists, and the Ani ng Dangal Award conferred annually by the NCCA since 2009.

Groups from the regions also benefitted from the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program that supported their tours and performances to other parts of the country and enabled them to come into the national consciousness. Among these were the Barasoain Kalinangan Ensemble of Malolos, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of Marawi, Dagyaw Dance and Theater Company of Iloilo, and Joey Ayala at ang Bagong Lumad.

CCP embarked on an aggressive campaign to showcase a wider selection of artists and Filipino original works by instituting full grants, venue grants, and production grants. The full grant allowed for the free use of CCP venues and provided financial assistance to cover production costs. The venue grant allowed for the use of Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino (formerly Little Theater) or Tanghalang Huseng Batute (formerly Bulwagang Gantimpala) for a total of six performances during the year. Chameleon Dance Company took advantage of this grant and was able to present the dance concert Unang Hakbang (First Step) at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino in 1991. The production grant provided financial assistance to produce a play outside the CCP. Through this grant, Enrico Labayen created Lab Projekt II, and Douglas Nierras produced Dating Gawi, Bagong Anyo (Old Habits, New Forms) in 1991. Aside from the three grants, the CCP also initiated a residency program in which artists lived in locales of their choice for an extended period to conduct workshops that culminated in community-based performances. Agnes Locsin and Ballet Philippines II were able to conduct dance workshops in Davao and Iligan in 1991 through this program.

An important component towards the Filipinization of the CCP was the Filipino Artists Series at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino. Since its launch in 1987, many outstanding Filipino musicians have been featured such as classically trained instrumentalists and singers Nita Abrogar-Quinto, Jonathan Zaens, Mariel Ilusorio, Wilfredo Pasamba, Rene Dalandan, Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro, Ronan Ferrer, Jasper Andra, Margarita Yulo Gomez, Aima Labra, Peter Porticos, Clarissa Ocampo, the Kabayao Family Quintet, Denise Huang, Greg Zuniega, Adolfo Mendoza, Camille Lopez, Andrew Fernandez, Manuel Cabrera II, Mark Anthony Carpio, Abelardo Galang II, Victor Asuncion, and Ariel Dechosa. The Series also showcased ethnic pop composer-singer Joey Ayala and Lito Molina’s Jazz Band—nonclassical musicians who espouse alternative music and non-commercial jazz, respectively.

The impressive output of Filipino composers, singers, actors, dancers, music educators, and musicologists after the 1986 EDSA People Power Revolt created a vibrant musical environment that resulted in a more participative national culture for the Filipino people.

 

 

 

Music Universities and Institutions. The years after 1986 were a period of growth in the musical arts and scholarship. Many Filipino artists and musicologists who studied in Europe and the United States returned to perform, teach in the academe, and embark on cultural and historical research projects. The growth of universities offering music degrees gave more opportunities for advanced musical training. In addition to performance (also known as applied music), the period saw a considerable number of publications of musical works and musicological books by a new generation of musicians and writers.

Formal music education flourished in 13 universities and institutes recognized by the state: the University of the Philippines (UP), University of Santo Tomas, St Scholastica’s College, Philippine Women’s University, St Paul University of Manila, Santa Isabel College, De La Salle University-College of St Benilde, Centro Escolar University, Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music, Unibersidad de Santa Isabel in Naga, University of San Agustin in Iloilo, University of the Immaculate Conception in Davao, and Silliman University in Dumaguete. The College of St Benilde offers a music course that specializes in music technology, the Bachelor of Arts in music production, which is geared towards the technologically oriented music industry.

In 2011, the UP College of Music instituted a PhD in music studies degree with emphasis on music research. At about the same time, the Philippine Women’s University School of Music also started to offer a doctor of philosophy in music, with a major in ethnomusicology.

In 2004, the Department of Education started to implement a special program focusing on the arts in selected secondary public schools all over the nation. Called Special Program in the Arts (SPA), it was envisioned to develop young students with strong inclination toward music, visual arts, theater arts, creative writing, media arts and dance.

 

Patronage of Private Companies. During this period, corporate patronage of the arts intensified. Many national and multinational companies in the Philippines ventured into corporate responsibility programs, setting aside a budget for cultural investments and sponsoring artistic groups and their projects. These contributed to nation building for corporate sponsorships enabled public music activities, thus enhancing the quality of social life in local communities. Big Filipino companies such as San Miguel Corporation (SMC), Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT), Toyota Motor Corporation, The Manila Peninsula, Philippine Airlines (PAL), among many, have a long track record of supporting Filipino music.

SMC was a staunch supporter of Philippine ballets and symphonies, the Balikbanda contests, and regular events such as the Concert at the Park and the Cenaculo at Rizal Park. In 2002, it founded the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts, which housed a symphony orchestra and a master chorale. Through its musical director Ryan Cayabyab, the foundation concertized extensively in the capital and some regions of the Philippines, employing more than a hundred instrumental and vocal artists until it was disbanded in 2007. Aside from the SMC Foundation, Toyota Motor Corporation has sponsored concerts by visiting orchestras, chamber groups, and instrumental and vocal soloists at the CCP through its Toyota Classics: A World of Harmony concerts held annually since 1990. PLDT has funded the CCP’s Filipino Artists Series, Teatro Pilipino, PPO Concert Series, and Dance Theater Philippines productions. Visiting artists have been flown into the country by airline companies such as PAL, and they were billeted at sponsoring five-star hotels such as the former Manila Holiday Inn (now Traders’ Hotel), Philippine Plaza, and the Peninsula Manila. Corporate financial and economic support for the arts has exposed audiences to diverse types of Filipino music.

 

 

 

Mass Media and Technological Advances. Since 1986, mass media has played an important role in the promotion of musical activities. After all, it is the recording, broadcasting and film industries, supported by the rapid developments in telecommunications technology in the late 1980s; the affordability of electronic equipment and computer software made available to consumers in early 1990s; and the shift from analog to digital audio recording in late 1990s, that facilitated the circulation of music for individual and collective consumption. Through the efforts of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM), an organization that promotes original Filipino music and seeks to protect the welfare of those who are part of the music industry, the government issued Executive Order 255, dated 25 Jul 1987, which required radio stations with music programs to play at least four original Filipino music compositions every hour. Television programs, particularly drama anthologies, also began to use OPM as background music in their shows. This helped create a steady market for the local pop music industry and gave Philippine artists a steady source of income.

In the recording industry, an artist’s success can be measured by the number of recordings he or she has sold. Various recording companies such as Vicor Records, OctoArts International, and Viva Records have awarded their artists with gold, platinum record, and diamond record certifications according to their respective guidelines. Since 1990, the awarding of certificates has been assigned to the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI), and since March 2012, PARI has awarded the Gold Record for every 7,500 units sold, the Platinum Record for every 15,000 units sold, and the Diamond Record for every 150,000 units sold (PARI website).

At the beginning of the 21st century, electronic gadgets such as mobile phones, laptops, iPads and tablets, which have the capacity to store digital files, midis and videos, became more affordable to the wider populace. These gadgets and the Internet have revolutionized the creation, distribution, and even production of music. The traditional channels of distribution via the recording industry were replaced by 21st century technology that allowed for the direct distribution of music from artists to consumers. The internet has become the main tool for transferring recorded music bypassing traditional industry channels and allowing musicians to reach a broader audience.

Live performances such as international choral competitions where many Filipino choirs have participated have been made available to the Philippine public electronically via telepresencing or livestreaming. Recorded performances are uploaded on the internet site YouTube. Current and relevant issues in the entertainment industry, classical concert scene, and university-based artistic groups are now enthusiastically discussed in public fora such as pinoyexchange.com, thus opening the discussion to those with internet access. Some Filipino piano students today even avail of lessons from friends from abroad via Skype.

Aside from the Internet having been able to democratize knowledge dissemination and the promotion of musical activities and productions, it has also been used as a venue for selling digital recordings, albeit this is still regulated by PARI. The regulation is set in place because the easy acquisition of recording equipment and the reproducibility of music expressions have contributed to the increase of music piracy which is financed by an international syndicate of thieves who distribute them through petty itinerant music peddlers in Philippine cities.

 

 

 

Musical Associations and Organizations. Many of the existing musical organizations such as the Filipino Society of Composers Authors and Publishers (FILSCAP), PARI, the League of Filipino Composers (LFC), which became a national chapter of the Asian Composers’ League in 2005, the Philippine Society for Music Education (PSME) and its corollary Piano Teachers’ Guild of the Philippines, and the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas (PASAMBAP) continued with their mandates. New associations have also emerged. The AACMC and SAKSI were formed to lobby for the creation of a separate government agency to administer cultural affairs, right after the change of government in 1986. The Philippine Federation for Choral Music (PFCM), organized in 1996, was geared towards the promotion and appreciation of choral music. However, this organization did not last long. The Philippine Choral Directors Association (PCDA), founded in 2008, continued the aims of PFCM.
