Since its foundation, the PCDA has been actively propagating Philippine choral arts through its annual conventions.

The Philippine Opera Company (separate from the 1983 Philippine Opera Company) was founded in 1999. This is the only opera company in the country that regularly presents staged drama with music. The Jazz Society of the Philippines was launched on 16 Mar 2003 as a venue for jazz enthusiasts to get together to enjoy, promote, and advance jazz music in the Philippines. In Oct 1986, the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM) was founded with the mission to promote original Pilipino music.

Critical Appraisal of Music. Classical music performances in the various venues in the capital receive immediate feedback through performance reviews that are printed in the daily newspapers. Music critics, who have been writing even before 1986, continue to share their opinion about these performances. Among them are Antonio Hila, Rosalinda Orosa, and Pablo Tariman who regularly write for periodicals such as Manila Bulletin, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, Malaya, and The Manila Times. Scholarly criticism of performances, recordings, and publications about music have also been written, and these are published in scholarly refereed journals such as Musika Jornal, Humanities Diliman, Asian Studies, Bulawan, Budhi, Kritika Kultura, Philippine Humanities Review, Perspectives in the Arts and Humanities, and Philippine Studies.

Another form of critical appraisal is the conferring of awards by respected institutions to encourage artistic excellence in the field of music. The highest award that is bestowed to a Filipino artist remains the National Artist Award, which was established in 1973 through Presidential Proclamation 1144. In the field of music, the following have been accorded the National Artist Award after 1986: Antonino Buenaventura, 1988; Lucrecia Kasilag, 1989; Lucio San Pedro, 1991; Levi Celerio, 1997; Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1997; Jose Maceda, 1997; Ernani Cuenco, 1999; Andrea Veneracion, 1999; Francisco Feliciano, 2014; and Ramon Santos, 2014.

The Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) or the National Living Treasures Award, on the other hand, is a recognition given to indigenous cultural bearers. Enacted through RA 7355 passed in April 1992, the GAMABA Award is given to “a citizen engaged in any traditional art uniquely Filipino whose distinctive skills have reached such a high level of technical and artistic excellence and have been passed on to and widely practiced by the present generation in his/her community with the same degree of technical and artistic competence.” It is currently administered by the NCCA. Since 1993, five indigenous musicians have been accorded the GAMABA award: Samaon Sulaiman, 1993; Masino Intaray, 1993; Uwang Ahadas, 2000; Frederico Caballero, 2000; and Alonzo Saclag, 2000.

Since 1977, the CCP has conferred an award that honors the country’s outstanding performing artists. The award was renamed Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 1989. Notable artists who have received this award for music include Cecile Licad, Andrea Veneracion, Levi Celerio, Jose Maceda, Ryan Cayabyab, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio.

Another award that recognizes the contribution of Filipino artists is the Ani ng Dangal, given for the first time in 2009 by the NCCA. Unlike the other awards that focus on individual achievements through many years of artistic productivity, Ani ng Dangal recognizes achievements received by artists during the year particularly in the area of international competitions. Some of the Filipino musicians and groups given the Ani ng Dangal award are Teresa Barrozo, Jed Madela, UP Singing Ambassadors, University of Santo Tomas Singers, University of the Visayas Chorale, Novo Concertante Manila, Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir, Imusicapella, and De La Salle University Chorale.

The achievements of pop music artists and bands in the field of popular culture are recognized by a number of award-giving bodies. The Katha Music Award is the most coveted among songwriters and popular music performers. It is an accolade not based on an artist’s popularity or marketability but on the quality of his or her work. The first Katha Awards were given in 1995. Some of the exceptional artists who have won include Grace Nono who was awarded four years in a row from 1996 to 1999, Eraserheads in 1996, South Border in 1999, Jungee Marcelo in 2000, and Gloc-9 in 2002.

Two other awards are the Awit Awards and the Aliw Awards. The Awit Awards recognize exceptional Filipino recordings and performers. The awards were originally managed by the Awit Awards Executive Committee comprised of representatives from various recording companies in 1969, and were later handled by the Philippine Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (PARAS) from 1970 to 1971. They were discontinued after 1971. The Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI) revived the awards in 1988. Recipients of the Awit Awards include Gary Valenciano who has won 12 times from 1989 to 2013, Smokey Mountain in 1991, The CompanY in 1992 and 2002, Side A in 1994 and 1996, Bamboo in 2006 and 2008, Sarah Geronimo in 2015 and 2016, and Ebe Dancel in 2016.

The Aliw Awards recognize excellence in opera, theatre, dance, and live instrumental and vocal performances. Given by the Aliw Awards Foundation, Inc. founded by Alice Reyes in 1976, these awards were conferred for the first time in 1977. The Aliw Awards Foundation, Inc. bestows the Entertainer of the Year award, which is the most sought-after honor. In recent years, the Entertainer of the Year was conferred on Regine Velasquez in 2009, Sarah Geronimo in 2010, Charice Pempengco in 2011, Lisa Macuja in 2012, Dulce in 2013, Jed Madela in 2014, Gerphil Flores in 2015, and Lea Salonga in 2016.

The NU Rock Awards recognized the work and artistry of rock artists. Given yearly from 1994 until 2010, the awards were sponsored by the now defunct radio station NU 107. The bands which were given the NU Rock “Artist of the Year” award are AfterImage in 1994, Eraserheads in 1995 and 1997, Wolfgang in 1996 and 1998, Parokya ni Edgar in 1999, 2000, and 2003, Slapshock in 2001 and 2002, Bamboo in 2004 and 2007, Orange and Lemons in 2005, Kamikaze in 2006, Pupil in 2008, Up Dharma Down in 2009, and Franco in 2010.

 

 

 

Music Festivals. One of the longest running music festivals in the country has been the annual Las Piñas Bamboo Organ Festival held at the St Joseph Parish Church. This event, featuring the famous bamboo organ and held in the month of February since 1975, has a weeklong concert schedule including works by Filipino composers like Lucio San Pedro, Francisco Feliciano, Lucrecia Kasilag, Chino Toledo, and Nicolas Sengson. Many Filipino concertists and vocalists, including Oscar Yatco, Andrea Veneracion, Joel Navarro, Eudenice Palaruan, Jonathan Velasco, Raul Sunico, Nolyn Cabahug, Otoniel Gonzaga, Wilfredo Pasamba, Rachelle Gerodias, Janet Sabas Aracama, Noel Velasco, and Armando Salarza, have participated. Choirs that have performed for this festival include the Philippine Madrigal Singers, Las Piñas Boys Choir, and the UP Concert Chorus. Its famous Concert Under the Tree has featured pop artists such as Isay Alvarez, Robert Seña, The CompanY, The Opera, TUX, and the APO Hiking Society.

 

The CCP initiated a number of national and international choral music festivals during this period such as the Philippine International Choral Festivals in 1998 and 2003. In 2009, the 1st CCP National Choral Competition took place on 18-22 Aug as part of the institution’s 40th anniversary celebration. Not long after, the Andrea O. Veneracion (AOV) International Choral Festival 2013 was held to celebrate the 50th founding anniversary of the Philippine Madrigal Singers that this National Artist nurtured in her lifetime. It was held on 7-10 Aug 2013, exactly a month after she passed away. The second AOV International Choral Festival was held on 22-25 Jul 2015.

Another festival that has been mounted regularly at the CCP is the International Guitar Festival and Competition. This began in 2010 and was organized by a group of Filipino guitar aficionados called Guitar Friends, together with the CCP. Related to this is the Philippine Ukelele Festival organized by Ukelele Philippines and Ukelele Underground Philippines. It aimed to popularize ukelele playing, and this festival was first held in Oct 2013.

Aside from these CCP-initiated festivals, a noteworthy one that began in 1991 is the Kundiman Fiesta. The goal of the festival was to revive the singing of Filipino kundiman among the youth. The first five years of the festival were financed by Hotel Manila Garden in Manila. In 1996, NCCA took over the program. In 1995, the Makati Coliseum and Cultural Affairs Office started another kundiman singing competition in celebration of the “Buwan ng Wika” (Philippine Language Month) in Makati City. The competition was aptly called Kampeon ng Kundiman (Champion of the Kundiman), and it has been held annually ever since.

In 1996, the Bolipata Brothers, who were all music scholars of the Marcos government, established the Pundaquit Festival in their home province of Zambales. The festival aims to provide both long and short-term residencies for visiting artists, and to hold performances, workshops, and exhibits that would help invigorate the local community. This is held in the Bolipata estate called Casa San Miguel, an alternative venue for concerts of classical music outside the capital. Since its foundation, the festival has featured many classical artists from the various music schools in the Philippines, as well as visiting musicians from abroad. They have a mentorship program with aims to develop young artists from Zambales. Respected Filipino artists such as Joey Ayala, Grace Nono, and Cecile Licad have played at the Casa.

In the field of popular music, the Puerto Azul Music and Sports Festival, launched in 1993 by Katrina Panlilio, exemplifies the fusion of art and the economics of tourism. Organized primarily to drum up interest in the Puerto Azul Resort in Ternate Cavite, this has become an annual affair that has attracted big names in the pop music industry. Followers of rock bands and pop groups are drawn to the sporty atmosphere of the resort. A similar gathering is the annual Malasimbo Music and Arts Festival, which is staged in Puerto Galera, Oriental Mindoro. It was started in 2011 by Hubert d’Aboville, a Frenchman who decided to stay for good in the country.

Several festivals celebrating the growth of jazz music in the Philippines have been organized such as the annual Manila Jazz Festival, initially staged as part of the annual French Spring Manila in the early 2000s; the Full Moon Jazz Festival in 2003; and the Candid Jazz International Festival, which began in 2004. The CCP also held its 1st International Jazz Festival in August 2011.

Competitions in popular music composition and performance make up most of the events for pop music. The Metro Manila Pop Music Festival, later renamed as Metropop Song Festival upon its revival in 1996, was the most productive songwriting competition in the country of the period. Held annually from 1978 to 1985, it experienced a hiatus until its revival in 1996. The festival continued until 2003. The Metropop catapulted the musical careers of new songwriters and singers whose pop songs became instant hits. Among the songwriters are Danny Tan, Trina Belamide, Dodjie Simon, Vehnee Saturno, Mike Villegas, Bayang Barrios, Arnold Villegas, and Jonathan Manalo. Singers whose careers took off with the help of a Metropop distinction were Jaya, Rannie Raymundo, Gary Granada, Carol Banawa, Lani Misalucha, Dessa, Zebedee Zuniega, Cynthia Alexander, and Ella May Saison.

Another songwriting tilt with an international pool of participants was the Musika Manila which awarded a cash prize of $20,000 for the First Prize winner. Held from 27 Nov to 1 Dec 1996, it attracted 12 contenders from different countries. Winner of the grand prize was the Philippine entry “Build a Bridge” that was composed by Christine Bendebil and sung by Rommel Gonzaga. The 1998 edition was renamed Asia Song Festival, held at the AFP Theater within Camp Aguinaldo. The Second Prize was awarded to the Philippines’ Jungee Marcelo’s composition, “Handle With Care,” interpreted by Lani Misalucha. Misalucha was awarded Best Interpreter in the entire competition.

Launched on 15 Feb 2012 was the Philippine Pop Music Festival (PhilPOP) Songwriting Competition, which aimed to encourage Filipinos to create music that had the prospect of becoming classic hits. The grand prize winners for the first three years were: Karl Villuga with his song “Bawat Hakbang” (For Every Step), 2012; Thyro Alfaro and Yumi Lacsamana with “Dati” (Before), 2013; and Jungee Marcelo with “Salbabida” (Lifesaver), 2014.

In the field of traditional Philippine music, the International Rondalla Festival, initiated by Ramon Santos, was held in different regional centers. These featured string ensembles from different countries, together with rondalla groups from the Philippines. The festivals were staged in Naga, 2004; Dumaguete, 2007; Tagum, 2011; and Manila, 2014. A related festival that highlighted gongs and bamboo instruments was organized also by Ramon Santos in Dipolog City from 16-23 Feb 2013. Titled Tunog-Tugan: 1st International Gongs and Bamboo Music Festival, this came with an academic conference, a practical workshop, and lecture-demonstration.

Outside of Manila, the City of Tagum in Davao del Norte hosts an annual music festival called Musikahan sa Tagum. Started in 1999, the festival features various competitions in several categories like brass band, parade music, choir competition, and songwriting. Since its inception, the festival has grown and is recognized as an annual major music event in the Philippines, attracting participants from the various regions of the country.

Foreign Training of Artists and Scholars. After the change in government in 1986, scholarship grants given through Imelda Marcos’s Young Artist Foundation were cut. However, many of the scholars were able to continue their studies with the help of philanthropists, organizations, or their own families. CCP had its own scholarship fund, and it sent a few young artists abroad.

Most of these scholars returned to the Philippines after completing their studies and enriched the country’s cultural life through their performances or through their commitment to teaching in the various music conservatories in the country. There were also other successful foreign-based Filipino musicians who regularly visited the Philippines to give concerts. These were Oscar Yatco (violinist and conductor), Carmencita Lozada (violinist), Otoniel Gonzaga (tenor), Aries Caces (pianist), and Cecile Licad (pianist).

In the field of musicology, two Filipino scholars returned in the late 1990s to teach at the University of the Philippines College of Music. Jose Buenconsejo, who graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, and LaVerne dela Peña, a graduate of the University of Hawaii, added to the slowly growing group of foreign-trained Filipino PhD in music holders, which has included Jose Maceda from the University of California in Los Angeles, Corazon Canave Dioquino from the Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C., Ramon Santos from the State University of New York at Buffalo, Felicidad Prudente from the University of Michigan, Mercedes Dujunco from the University of Washington in Seattle, and Arsenio Nicolas from Cornell University in New York. Kristina Benitez from the University of Michigan would later be an addition to the group after finishing her degree in mid-2000s.

The number of Filipino musicians who went abroad to take further studies in music performance or establish a musical career continues to rise. The long list includes Raul Sunico, Rowena Arrieta, Albert Tiu, Jonas Baes, Rene Dalandan, Joseph Esmilla, Aries Caces, Ariel Dechosa, Jonathan Velasco, Alegria Ferrer, Eudenice Palaruan, Camille Lopez-Molina, Pablo Molina, Jonathan Zaens, Gary del Rosario, Ramon Acoymo, Renato Lucas, Eugene delos Santos, Ronan Ferrer, Charisse Baldoria, Gerard Salonga, Abelardo Galang II, Robin Estrada, Karen Francisco, Peter Porticos, Michelle Nicolasura, Randy Gilongo, Thea Prosia, Nathan Manimtim, Hiyas Hila, Isidora Miranda, Adolfo Mendoza, Alejandro Consolacion II, Rica Nepomuceno, Beverly Shangkuan, and Ena Aldecoa.

Worth noting are two scholars from the St Joseph Parish in Las Piñas, Cealwyn Tagle and Edgar Montiano, who underwent three years of intensive on-the-job training for pipe organ construction and maintenance in Austria. Upon their return in the early 1990s, their first assignment was to construct a pipe organ at the St Joseph’s Academy Auditorium, adjacent to the church where the bamboo organ is located. The organ was inaugurated in 1994, and from then on, they constructed new pipe organs and restored existing ones in older churches under the company Diego Cera Builders Inc. Some of the pipe organs they constructed are to be found at the Cathedral of Cebu, the Immaculate Conception Church Parish in Pasig, and the San Sebastian Cathedral in Lipa. They also restored the pipe organs of the San Agustin Church and the Manila Cathedral in Intramuros, allowing the two historical churches to organize music festivals with pipe organ music as the main attraction. The San Agustin International Music Festival started in 1998, while the Manila Cathedral Pipe Organ Festival began in 2006.

Music Publications. Many books on music and about music have been published since 1986. Choral arrangements and scores for voice with piano accompaniment dominate this market of print music. In 1990, the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music (AILM) and the Christian Conference of Asia published the Sound the Bamboo. Other published books containing songs are Patatag: Masdan, O Yahweh (Patatag: Look, Oh Yahweh), 1990; 50 Immortal Filipino Duets; 1992, Kundiman At Iba Pa (Kundiman and Others), 1994; Mga Awiting Bayan (Folk Songs), 1994; Himig: A Collection of Philippine Folksongs, Vols. 1-5, late 1990s to early 2000s; Philippine Choral Music, 2003; Koro Leyteño, 2004; The AILM Collection: Hymns, Psalms, and Songs for Worship, Volume 1, 2005; Mga Awiting Bayan Para sa Korong Pilipino (Folk Songs for the Filipino Chorus), 2008; Serenata: A Treasury of Traditional Kapampangan Folksongs, 2009; and Aweng ti Kailokuan: The Musical Heritage of the Ilocanos, 2011. The Jesuit music ministry Himig Heswita has also contributed several volumes of music for the liturgical services of the Catholic Church.

The flourishing of musical scholarship in the Philippines is evidenced by the growth in the publication of books on Philippine music. Among the earliest publications after 1986 were the accompanying monographs of CCP’s Tuklas Sining in 1989. Tuklas Sining was a 28-part series of educational videotapes and monographs on the evolution of the seven arts: film, theater, music, architecture, visual arts, dance, and literature. This project was followed by the landmark publication of the 10-volume CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art in 1994, edited by Nicanor Tiongson, with the music volume edited by Ramon Santos and Corazon Dioquino. Envisioned as a reference material on Philippine art and culture, the encyclopedia was the product of a vast collaborative network of scholars, artists, and experts in the different artistic fields.

Aside from these two major publications, several books in music have been printed after 1986. Elena Rivera Mirano published Subli: One Dance in Four Voices, 1989, which won the National Book Award in 1989; and Ang Mga Tradisyonal na Musikang Pantinig sa Lumang Bauan, Batangas (Traditional Vocal Music in the Old Bauan, Batangas), 1997. Gongs and Bamboos: A Panorama of Philippine Musical Instruments, a summation of Jose Maceda’s decades-long, extensive research on indigenous instruments of the ethnolinguistic groups in the country, was published in 1998. Songs and Gifts at the Frontier: Person and Exchange in the Agusan Manobo Possession Ritual, Philippines written by Jose Buenconsejo was published by Routledge in 2002.

Other books on Philippine music include Music in History, History in Music by Antonio Hila, 2004; Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music by Ramon Santos, 2005; Myth, Mimesis and Magic in the Music of the T’boli, Philippines by Manolete Mora, 2005; The Bamboo Organ of Las Piñas, second edition, by Helen Samson-Lauterwald, 2006; Kolonyal na Patakaran at ang Nagbabagong Kamalayang Filipino: Musika sa Publikong Paaralan sa Pilipinas 1898-1935 (Colonial Policies and the Evolving Filipino Consciousness: Music in Public Schools in the Philippines) by Raul Navarro, 2007; The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay edited by Elena Rivera Mirano, 2009; Kirial de Baclayon año 1826: Hispanic Sacred Music in 19th Century Bohol, Philippines by Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua, 2010; Colonial Counterpoint: Music in Early Modern Manila by David Irving, 2010; Musical Renderings of the Philippine Nation by Christi-Anne Castro, 2011; Laon-Laon by Ramon Santos, 2012; Dictionary of Filipino Music Terms edited by Ramon Santos, 2013; Musika at Bagong Lipunan: Pagbuo ng Lipunang Filipino, 1972-1986 (Music and the New Society: Creating the Filipino Society, 1972-1986) by Raul Navarro, 2014; Sibod: Ideology and Expressivity in Binanog Dance, Music, and Folkways of the Panay Bukidnon by Ma. Christine Muyco, 2016; and Musika sa Kasaysayan ng Filipinas: Pana-panahong Diskurso (Music in Philippine History: Discourses Through Time) by Raul Navarro, 2016. Biographies have also been published on the following Filipino musicians: Lucrecia Kasilag, Andrea Veneracion, Antonino Buenaventura, Gilopez Kabayao, Angel Peña, and Samaon Sulaiman.

 

Classical Music

 

Continuing the tradition of composing and performing Western classical music by Filipino musicians of the early 20th century, composers and various instrumental and vocal performers sustained their creativity after 1986 with the production of new instrumental and vocal compositions, operas, and choral music. Many of the new serious works came from established composers such as Lucio San Pedro, Ramon Santos, Francisco Feliciano, Lucrecia Kasilag, Angel Peña, Chino Toledo, Jonas Baes, LaVerne dela Peña, and Jeffrey Ching. The UP College of Music continues to train young composers in the tradition of art music composition. A benchmark of this unparalleled distinction held by UP in the field of composition is that a number of their alumni have pursued advanced studies in composition in Europe and North America such as Ma. Christine Muyco, Joy Marfil, Robin Estrada, Nilo Alcala, Dominic Quejada, and Feliz Anne Macahis. For live performances, the main source of musical labor continues to be the musicians trained in the various music colleges and conservatories in Manila.

Instrumental and Vocal Compositions. Orchestral music continues to be cultivated and listened to in the country. The repertory of genres termed “symphonic” manifests a diversity of idioms and styles, whose influences lie in a continuum between neoclassical treatments (i.e., symphony, concerto, symphonic poem, and so on) on one hand and progressive new music writing on the other. The latter employs unrestricted treatment to the orchestral performance medium by including unconventional instruments and incorporating the tone colors and rhythms of indigenous Philippine instrumental music. On the conservative side are Lucrecia Kasilag’s In the Beginning, 1988, and Violin Concerto No. 2, 1994; Antonino Buenaventura’s Concerto for French Horn and Orchestra, 1987, and Rizal: The Great Malayan Antagonist, 1988; Angel Peña’s Concerto No. 2 for Double Bass, 1991; and Philippine Festival Overture, 1993; and Jeffrey Ching’s Symphony No. 4 ‘Souvenir des Ming,’ 2006, and Symphony No. 5 ‘Kunstkammer,’ 2006. On the experimental side are Jose Maceda’s Music for a Chamber Orchestra, 1997; Ramon Santos’s Du-A, 1986, for large orchestra, Time Space, 1990, for two orchestras, and L’BAD, 1995, for a large orchestra. Somewhere in between the treatments are some orchestral work outputs by Chino Toledo such as Kantus: Tagabawa, 1999, and Dignum et Iustum est (Worthy and Just It Is), 2000, for chorus, piano, and orchestra. Another example is Ryan Cayabyab’s Misa 2000 (Mass 2000), 2000, for chorus and orchestra.

Unlike Maceda and Santos whose works are produced and listened to almost exclusively in institutional-commissioned work settings, Toledo and Cayabyab write for paying audiences in the concert world. This space has naturally affected the characteristics of their compositions. Toledo, a teacher of academic composition and conductor of conventional orchestra, connects, for example, the rift between the new and the conventional in concert music. His vision of orchestral music is manifest in his Music Underkonstruction Orchestral Reading Project, which has been supported by the Institute for Orchestral Development in the Philippines since August 2005. This aims to encourage the creation and performance of new works by young Filipino art music composers for a music that is to be valued in the concert music world. Since its inaugural concert, many new compositions for orchestra by young composers have been premiered by the Metro Manila Chamber Orchestra (MMCO). Toledo’s ouvre contrasts with the experimental compositions of the Manila Sound Lab founded in 2008 and led by Jonas Baes, who has also worked almost exclusively in a music world inhabited by institutional or organized commissions. He has collaborated with foreign composers and has presented works of young composers.

In the realm of chamber music, composers have continued fusing elements of Filipino indigenous and other Asian music influences with Western classical traditions. Similar to works for the large orchestra, works in this domain also exhibit a wide range of stylistic influences. In the repertory of the domain are some by Ramon Santos such as S’Geypo, 1993, and Dw’gey, 2006; Francisco Feliciano’s Siya-Kuno, 1990, and Kochi, 2002; Lucrecia Kasilag’s Fanfare and Rondo, 1987, and Munting Principe (Little Prince), 1988; Jose Maceda’s Strata, 1988, and Distemperament, 1992; Chino Toledo’s Dasal (Prayer), 1997, and Hoy! (Hey!), 2004; Jeffrey Ching’s Kunstkabinett Part I, 2008, and Raven Mantra, 2013; Jonas Baes’s Daluy (Flow), 2000, and Patangis-Buwaya (Cry of the Crocodile), 2003; and Christine Muyco’s PagbaBagtasBagtas (Affixations), 2006, and Agit-it (Squeaking), 2009. In the 1998 centennial celebration of Philippine independence, the CCP commissioned five Filipino composers to create a special musical offering for the nation. The concert featured Ramon Santos’s Nagnit Igak G’nan Wagnwag Nila (Alingawngaw ng Kagitingan) [Echoes of Courage], Lucrecia Kasilag’s Centennial Tribute to Filipino Womanhood, Chino Toledo’s Sandaang Tagpi (A Hundred Patchworks), Jeffrey Ching’s Symphony No. 3 ‘Ritual’, and Lucio San Pedro’s Alamat ng Lahi (Legend of the Race).

In the realm of orchestral music performance, the period has experienced an upsurge in new orchestras. Aside from the established Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and the historic Manila Symphony Orchestra, the following orchestras were founded: Manila Chamber Orchestra, 1985; Manila Philharmonic Orchestra, 1998; UP String Chamber Orchestra, also known as UP Arco, 1998; UST Symphony Orchestra, reorganized in 1961; San Miguel Foundation Orchestra, founded in 2001 and disbanded in 2007; Peace Philharmonic Orchestra, originally the Cebu Youth Symphony Orchestra founded in 1995; Metro Manila Community Orchestra, 2000; and ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra, 2012.

Aside from orchestral and chamber works, there was a substantial increase in the number of compositions utilizing voice, either taken singularly or collectively, with accompaniment or a cappella. Examples in this category are Ramon Santos’s Likas-An II (Nature-ing II), 1994, and Oggayam (Kalinga welcome song), 2004; Francisco Feliciano’s Pamulinawen (Stonehearted), 1992, and Enduken (Muslim song), 2002; Lucio San Pedro’s The Redeemer, 1990; Chino Toledo’s Alitaptap (Firefly), 1995, and Misa Sama-Sama (Mass Together), 2012-14; Christine Muyco’s Wasak na Lupa (Ruined Land), 1993, and Lupang Tinubuan (Land of One’s Roots), 1994; Ryan Cayabyab’s Te Deum, 1990, Mi Ultimo Adios (My Last Farewell), 1996, and Misa 2000, 2000; Fidel Calalang Jr’s Ama Namin (Our Father), 1999; Robin Estrada’s Awit ni Solomon (Song of Solomon), 1999, and Awit sa Panginoon (The Lord’s Song), 2001; Eudenice Palaruan’s Gapas (Harvest), 2005; Joy Nilo’s Umawit Kayo sa Panginoon (Sing to the Lord), 2008; and Nilo Alcala’s Kaisa-isa Niyan (The One and Only), 2006. Many of these works have been sung by Filipino choirs who competed in international choral festivals. The impressive tone colors and dynamic rhythms of the compositions that emphasize the uniqueness of Philippine indigenous music contribute to the high level of technical showmanship that makes Filipino choirs stand out in international competitions.

Operas. In the first few years after the 1986 Revolution, opera production was focused on the restaging of western operas but with Filipinized librettos. The CCP tasked Rolando Tinio to translate and adapt Verdi’s La Traviata in 1989, and Puccini’s La Boheme and Verdi’s Rigoletto in 1992. By the turn of the 21st century, other Western operas were staged in various theaters in Manila, in their original languages. Among them were Mozart’s Der Schauspieldirektor, Cavallo’s Pagliacci, and Tschaikovsky’s Eugene Onegin in 2006; Pergolesi’s La Serva Padrona and Purcell’s Dido and Aeneas in 2007; Strauss’s Die Fledermaus, Humperdinck’s Hansel and Gretel, and Puccini’s La Boheme in 2008; Verdi’s La Traviata and Puccini’s Madama Butterfly in 2012; and Dvo?ák’s Rusalka in 2014.

The staging of these operas was through the concerted efforts of the CCP, UP College of Music, UST Conservatory of Music, and the Philippine Opera Company under its founder Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. Their goal was to maintain an active opera environment in the country, as well as to create performance opportunities for classically trained Filipino singers, many of whom performed in the various opera productions of the Singapore Lyric Opera in Singapore. Also noteworthy is the collaboration with opera companies from Korea such as the Daejeon Opera Company.

New operas written by Filipino composers during this period include Sikhay (Zeal), 1994, composed by Francisco Feliciano, with libretto by Sedfrey Ordoñez and Beth Puyot, and directed by Anton Juan; and Lorenzo Ruiz, Escribano (Lorenzo Ruiz, Court Clerk), 1994, composed by Jerry Dadap, with libretto by Ophelia Dimalanta, translated into Filipino by Florentino Hornedo. Rizal: Mga Huling Araw (Rizal: Final Days), 1995, was composed by Ed Parungao, with libretto by Frank Gomez, and directed by Tony Espejo. Jeffrey Ching composed Rendezvous in Venice, 1996, with Daniel Huang as his co-librettist. Lapu-Lapu the Opera, 1997, was composed by Jose Gentica V, with libretto by Henry Tejero. Another theatrical work by Jeffrey Ching was the dramatic cantata Rizal, 1997, with libretto by Leonor Orosa Goquinco. In 1997, Mayo, Bisperas ng Liwanag (May, The Eve of Light), a re-adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s May Day Eve, was composed by Reynaldo Paguio, with libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. Francisco Feliciano composed Dangal ng Lahi (Honor of the Race) in 2000 with libretto by Lilibeth Nacion Puyot. Inspired by Luna’s masterpiece, Spoliarium, the opera of the same title, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan Asensio, was produced at the CCP with Alex Cortez as director in 2003. That same year, The Venerable Lord Takayama Okun by Manuel Maramba, OSB with libretto by Edward Tuazon-Ishita was premiered. Why Flowers Bloom in May is probably Lucrecia Kasilag’s last major work for music theater which she finished in early 2007. The libretto was by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. The latest additions to this considerable list of Filipino operas are Chino Toledo’s San Andres B., 2013, with libretto by Virgilio Almario, and Jeffrey Ching’s chamber opera, Before Brabant, 2014.

Ballet Music. An important large-scale composition of the period was Daragang Magayon: An Istorya ni Mayon (Beautiful Maiden: The Story of Mayon). This was composed by Ramon Santos and premiered in 2013. It tells of the famed beauty, power, and sacrificial love of Daragang Magayon in a production that incorporates poetry, music, dance, and cinematography. It was directed and choreographed by Gerald Mercado, with poetry by Virgilio Almario, and dramaturgy by Abdon M. Balde Jr. For a full-length dance drama, the music of this work warrants interest because it utilizes the rondalla, piano, percussion, chorus, soloists, and narration. Earlier in 1991, Ramon Santos also composed the music for a different Daragang Magayon, with poetry by Merlinda Bobis. It was staged at the loading dock at the back of the CCP Main Theater with choreography by Hazel Sabas.

 

Semiclassical Repertoire

 

Another family of music genres from the classical music tradition is the semiclassical piece. This is comprised of music written for sarsuwela, Anglo-American musicals, music for ballet and modern dance, brass bands, and rondallas. They have been performed in formal and informal venues including theaters, churches, school auditoriums, open-air amphitheaters, and even streets. Copies of such performances have also been circulated via TV, radio, as well as the Internet.

 

New Sarsuwela and Revivals. From 1986, quite a number of sarsuwela have been revived but most have been reworked with the addition of new themes and contemporary worldviews, and the incorporation of modern staging techniques and lighting design that would cater to the contemporary audience. The revitalization also included the rewriting of dialogues, rearrangement of scenes to make the plot more logical, addition of more relatable songs or up-to-date dances, and fashion.

The CCP and the University of the Philippines initiated their own series of sarsuwela productions, leading to the comeback of this theatrical genre. The Tanghalang Pilipino, established by the CCP as one of its resident companies in 1986, restaged Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) with libretto by Hermogenes Ilagan and music by Leon Ignacio, 1987; Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness) with libretto by Precioso Palma and music by Leon Ignacio, 1989; Pilipinas Circa 1907 with libretto by Nicanor Tiongson and music by Lutgardo Labad, Lucien Letaba, Louie Pascasio, Chino Toledo, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Scott Joplin, and Barry Fagan, 1992 and 2007; Walang Sugat (No Wounds) with libretto by Severino Reyes and music by Fulgencio Tolentino, 1994 and 1997; and Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks) with libretto by Julian Balmaceda and music by Leon Ignacio, 1995.

Regional sarsuwela was also produced such as Kumpas Kag Ambahanon Sang 5 de Noviembre Rebolusyon (Rhythm and Song of the November 5 Revolution) in Silay, Negros Occidental in 1995. The kapampangan Ing Managpe (The Patcher), libretto by Mariano Proceso Pabalan Byron and music by Amado Gutierrez David, was first staged in 1900 and was restaged in 2006.

Likewise, the University of the Philippines, under the UP Presidential Committe on Culture and the Arts (UPPCCA), initiated the Zarzuela Revival Program in 1992. In 1995, Dagiti Naulbod by Pascual Agcaoili was presented in Baguio and Ilocos Norte. Riri ken Tiri, written by Filemon Palafox and composed by Fernando Madamba, was staged in La Union in 1997. In Feb 2009, a nationwide sarsuwela festival was organized by Virgilio Almario of the UP College of Arts and Letters, and it showcased sarsuwela from a number of theater companies all over the country.

While sarsuwela revivals were being staged, new ones were also being written, composed, and produced by emerging theater groups in different parts of the country. Among the earliest sarsuwela composed after 1986 is the Ilonggo Matam-is Man Gali ang Kalamay (No Matter How Sweet the Sugar Is), 1991, by Ligaya P. Ardenio. The centennial celebration of Philippine independence in 1998 was an occasion to highlight cultural creations that exhibited nationalistic ideals. A sarsuwela contest was sponsored by the National Centennial Commission, and it resulted in the production of newly created sarsuwelas in the succeeding years after 1998. Among the winning sarsuwela were Palasyo ni Valentin (The Palace of Valentin), libretto by Mario O’Hara and music by Minda Azarcon and Vince de Jesus; Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (The Cries and Rebellion of Victoria Laktaw and Others), libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera and music by Lucien Letaba; Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom), libretto by George de Jesus III and music by Jesse Lucas; and Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (My Country, Just One Step More), libretto by Melba Padilla Magay and music by Lucio San Pedro. In 2005, a pop-sarsuwela by Joseph Sonny Cristobal, Bato sa Buhangin (Stone in the Sand), was written to honor Ernani Cuenco as a native of Barangay Tikay, Malolos. It was directed by Armando Sta. Ana. Two years later, in 2007, a modern zarzuela in English, Something to Crow About, with libretto by Alejandro Roces, music and lyrics by Ferdie Dimadura, and orchestration by Agripino Diestro, was staged. With additional lyrics by Isagani Cruz, this was presented in New York and California, with direction by Cecile Guidote-Alvarez. Also in 2007, Dulaang UP presented Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), libretto by Nicanor Tiongson and music by Joy Marfil. Two of the latest additions to the list of newly written sarsuwela are Baler ng Puso Ko (Baler of My Heart), 2009, libretto by Isagani Cruz and music by Lutgardo Labad, and the Ilonggo Brokin Layns (Broken Lines), 2011, libretto by Emmanuel Rodriguez, Ireneo Reyeas, Armin Paredes and Cristina Loredo, and music by Rodney Davo.

Among the active theater groups which produced sarsuwelas from 1986 were CCP’s Tanghalang Pilipino, PETA, Dulaang UP, UP Repertory, FEU Art Theater Clinique, Paat Dramatic Guild of Bantay, Ilocos Sur, St Catherine Zarzuela Group of Santa Catalina, Ilocos Sur, Tamayo Stage Troupe of Santa Barbara, Pangasinan, Baay Dramatic Association of Lingayen, Pangasinan, Barasoain Kalinangan of Bulacan, Komedya ng San Dionisio of Parañaque, UP Visayas Alumni Theater Company of Miag-ao, Iloilo, Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop of Cebu, Kaliwat Theater Collective and the Mindanao Community Theater Network from Mindanao, and Kulturang Atin and Salidummay Music Theater Company from Davao. Ateneo de Manila University presented its first grand theater production in its 150th year celebration in 2010 with the staging of Walang Sugat.

The Musicals. The thriving theater scene in the country received more boost from musicals in the English language. Many Filipino theater companies, composers, and actors benefited from the cultural economy of these productions. The success of Lea Salonga and the huge Filipino cast of the premiere production of Schoenberg and Boublil’s Miss Saigon in London in 1988 demonstrated how the skills of Filipino singers are at par with other talents around the world. It opened many opportunities for casting in other musicals abroad and inspiring more Filipino singers to dream of a theatrical career. While the transnational movement of Filipino talents began in late 19th century, the late 1980s saw a marked acceleration in this movement due to musical globalization.

The other side of this globalization has been the importation of British and American musicals into the country. Repertory Philippines created and has sustained an audience for Anglo-American music theater in the country since its foundation in 1967. It has staged a number of Broadway Musicals such as Evita, Oliver, Man of La Mancha, Jekyll and Hyde, The Producers, Little Women, and The Secret Garden. With its long history of theater production, it helped develop the artistic career of many world-renowned Filipino theater artists such as Lea Salonga, Monique Wilson, Mio Ynfante, Cita Astals, Cocoy Laurel, Michael Williams, Bernardo Bernardo, Jaime Blanch, Bart Guingona, Miguel Faustmann, Audie Gemora, Leo Martinez, Zenaida Amador, and Carmen Barredo.

Ryan Cayabyab leads the group of Filipino composers who wrote more mainstream musicals: Katy! The Musical, 1988, with libretto by Jose Javier Reyes; Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1993, with libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera; Alikabok (Dust), 1995, with libretto by Noel Balmaceda; Ilustrado: Ang Buhay ni Rizal (The Educated: The Life of Rizal), 1996, with libretto by Paul Dumol; Magnificat, 1996, with libretto by Nestor Torre; Ang Larawan: The Musical, (The Portrait: The Musical), 1997, with libretto by Rolando Tinio; Mapaghimalang Kamay ng Birhen ng Caysasay (The Miraculous Hand of the Virgin of Caysasay), 2005, with libretto by Nestor Torre; Ageless Passion, 2011, with libretto by Kristian Jeff Agustin; and Lorenzo, 2013, with libretto by Paul Dumol and Christian Vallez.

It is interesting to note that a number of musicals during this period were inspired by events and persons in Philippine history, particularly from the time of the late 19th century Philippine revolution. The musical 1896, music by Lucien Letaba, arrangement by Chino Toledo, and libretto by Charley de la Paz, was on the life of Emilio Jacinto. It premiered in 1995. Rizal: Mga Huling Araw, written by Roberto Perlas-Gomez, premiered in Dec 1995 to mark the beginning of the centennial commemoration of Rizal’s execution. Another musical on Rizal is Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal? (Who are You, Jose Rizal?) staged in 1996. In 1998, Repertory Philippines staged its 1st Filipino musical, Miong, with libretto by Joy Virata and Freddie Santos, and music by Ian Monsod.

Elias at Salome (Elias and Salome), a modern sung-through musical, premiered in 1996. The libretto was written by Domingo Landicho, and the music was composed by Jesse Lucas, Meynard Peñalosa, and Liezel Travison. In 1997, Tanghalang Pilipino staged Sa Pugad ng Adarna (On the Nest of the Adarna) with libretto by Tony Perez and music by Manuel Maramba. Lean: A Filipino Musical was staged in 1997 to mark the 10th death anniversary of young nationalist, student leader, and activist Lean Alejandro, who fell before an assassin’s bullet in 1987. The libretto and music were both written by Gary Granada.

Rama at Sita: The Musical (Rama and Sita: The Musical) was staged in 1999. Its libretto was by Roy Iglesias and its music was composed by Danny Tan. Isang Buhay sa Tambakan (A Life in the Dumpster), a comedy musical by Rolando Tinio satirizing the experience of rich people who undergo immersion in the slum area, was staged in 2002. Its music was by Julius Socorro. Himala (Miracle) by Ricky Lee and Soxy Topacio with music by Vince de Jesus premiered in Nov 2003.

The musical, Hudhud: An Ifugao Romance, with music by Chino Toledo who arranged it in ethno-pop-rock music style, was staged in 2004. The libretto was written by Nicolas Pichay, and direction was by Fernando Josef. St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, with music by Antonio Africa, libretto by Floy Quintos, and direction by Alex Cortez, was staged in 2005. Gabriela: Isang Oratorio (Gabriela: An Oratorio), was staged in 2006, with libretto by Joi Barrios, music by Joy Marfil, and direction by Tony Mabesa.

 

Song of Joseph, 2009, is a musical with libretto written by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio and music by Raymond Roldan, which was premiered in 2009 under the direction of Noel Cabazor. In 2010, Tanghalang Pilipino opened its season with one of the classics of Philippine literature, Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat (Glimmer and Shine). Libretto was by Bienvenido Lumbera and music was by Lucien Letaba. Direction was by Jose Estrella. In May 2010, the CCP and Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP) collaborated to produce the movie musical, Emir. It tells the story of Amelia, an Ilocana from Paoay, who worked as nanny to a royal household in the Middle East. It was directed by Chito Roño, with libretto by Jerry Gracio, Gary Granada, and Rody Vera, and music by Gary Granada and Diwa de Leon.

The rock musical Sa Tabi ng Ilog Pasig (By the Pasig River), 2010, is a reworking of Jose Rizal’s zarzuela, Junto al Pasig. It was staged under the direction of Andrei Tiangco. The libretto was written by Jose Jeffrey Camanag and music was composed by Jesse Lucas. A musical that explored the age-old quest for academic and sports excellence between La Salle and Ateneo was Rivalry, staged in 2013, under the direction of Jaime del Mundo. Its libretto was by Noel Trinidad and music was by Ed Gatchalian. Sa Wakas (At Last), featuring the songs of the band Sugarfree, with libretto by Andrei Nikolai Pamintuan and Mariane Abuan, and musical arrangement by Ejay Yatco, was staged in 2014. PETA’s production of Rak of Aegis (Rock of Aegis) has been the longest running musical in the country to date. It features the music of the rock band, Aegis, and was premiered in 2014. In 2015, Tanghalang Pilipino and Actors Company staged Mabining Mandirigma: A Steampunk Musical (The Warrior Mabini), with libretto by Nicanor Tiongson and music by Joed Balsamo, under the direction of Chris Millado.

Music for Ballet and Modern Dance. Western romantic period music continues to dominate the music used for ballet productions of established groups such as Ballet Philippines and Philippine Ballet Theater. Tchaikovsky’s Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty, and The Nutcracker Suite, and Adam’s Giselle have been among the most commonly performed ballets since 1986.

An important addition to the music for dance in theater is Joey Ayala’s Encantada, featuring neo-ethnic compositions inspired by the sound colors and rhythms of music from Mindanao. Ayala combined Philippine indigenous instruments such as the kubing, luntang, kuratong, sarunai, and angklung, with electric guitars, cymbals, and banjo. The libretto was written by Al Santos, and choreography was by Agnes Locsin who used neo-ethnic dance movements. Another collaborative work of Locsin and Ayala is Sayaw LikhANG KIUKOK, Atbp., which premiered in Davao in 2003 and was restaged at the CCP in 2005.

Ryan Cayabyab’s Rama Hari was restaged by Ballet Philippines in 2012, choreographed by Alice Reyes. Other newly choreographed works include Alden Lugnasin’s 2004 full-length modern ballet Peter Pan’s Neverland and other short dance creations such as Aku, Swimming the Ilog Pasig, and Fire Water Woman. Joed Balsamo’s Crisostomo Ibarra, premiered in 2010 and recipient of the Philstage Gawad Buhay award for Outstanding Dance Production in the same year, and Simoun, premiered in 2016 were the results of collaborative work with Ballet Philippines, with choreography by Paul Alexander Morales.

Music for Brass Bands. Bands continued to thrive, performing in civic events in their respective communities, passing on the long tradition of music making in public that began in the Spanish colonial period. The Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas, Inc. (PASAMBAP, Inc.), remains to be the leading confederation of brass bands in the country that ensures the continuing development of the bands’ general disposition and the musical quality of their performances. Several places still hold a strong band tradition where most brass instrumentalists come from. These include Rizal, Malabon, Pandacan, Cavite, Pampanga, and Nueva Ecija. In Silang, Cavite, during the town fiesta every February, residents line up on the streets to listen to dozens of brass bands play and march, and the day culminates with the annual brass band competition. This has become the city’s tourist attraction.

The repertoire of the bands is mainly from the established literature of western composers such as Franz von Suppe, James Swearingen, Harold Waters, John Moss, Leroy Anderson, Alfred Reed, and John Philip Sousa. Only a few Filipino composers have written music for brass bands after 1986. This group includes Lucio San Pedro with his The President March, commissioned by Malacañan Palace for President Fidel V. Ramos in 1992, and Centennial March, commissioned by the National Centennial Commission in 1998; Antonino Buenaventura with his Parangal ni Santa Cecilia (Tribute to Saint Cecilia); and Chino Toledo with his Tanikala (Chain), 1990. The compositions of Lucio San Pedro have been among the staple repertoire of brass bands in Rizal, Pandacan, and Cavite, and these include Victory on Parade March, Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), Festival March, Binatang Bukid March (Young Man of the Farm March), Jubilate March Heroic, and Maharlika March (The Noble Man March).

Rondalla Music. Rondalla music underwent a revival in the Fifth Philippine Republic. Noteworthy in this movement was the inclusion of rondalla as a regular category in the NAMCYA competition since 1996 and the holding of the International Rondalla Festival, which has not only helped elevate appreciation for this traditional musical ensemble but has also generated new works for the medium as well. Celso Espejo, an advocate of rondalla music who founded the Pambansang Samahan ng Rondalla (PASARON) with Benjamin Lucas and Teodorico Cosejo in the 1980s, also organized rondalla festivals and competitions from 1986 to 1995. Unfortunately, the organization is now defunct, but Espejo continues to help educate the young about rondalla music and its historical and culture significance through workshops in the provinces, with the help of his son, Nelson Espejo, and daughter, Elaine Espejo-Cajucom.

The main repertoire for rondalla groups consists of arrangements of western symphonic compositions. In recent years, however, with the vigorous promotion done by Ramon Santos through the various festivals and competitions for rondalla, a contemporary rondalla repertoire has developed and has become standardized. Among the music used are Ramon Santos’s Katubo; Ma. Christine Muyco’s PagpiPiko (Playing Hopscotch); Chino Toledo’s Isahan sa Pagkakaisa (One in Unity); Christi-Anne Castro’s Gabi ng mga Aswang (Night of the Evil Spirits); Nelson Espejo’s Minsan sa Isang Taon (Once A Year) and Victory; and Dominic Salustiano’s Bagong Pasadoble No. 6 (New Paso Doble No. 6).

It is also during this period that the translocalization of rondalla music happened. Pockets of diasporic Filipino groups in Boston, Singapore, Japan, and Australia organized rondallas as a way of maintaining their connectedness with the homeland. Christi-Anne Castro’s Iskwelahang Pilipino Rondalla Group based in Boston is the best known example. It has participated in the Cuerdas nin Kagabsan, the 1st International Rondalla Festival held in Naga City in 2004, together with the other group from Australia, the Rondanihan, and the Fil-Am Veterans Rondalla from San Jose, California. As a Philippine musical tradition transplanted abroad, the translocal rondalla is—for the Filipino communities living away from the homeland—a means of reterritorializing in the new environment using the old cultural symbolic form.

This translocalization is similar to the time when the kulintang tradition was brought to the United States in the 1970s. The kulintang tradition primarily spread through the work of two cultural bearers—Danongan Kalanduyan from Maguindanao and Usupay Cadar from Maranao, who both left Mindanao to teach kulintang in American universities in the West Coast. By the 1990s, several kulintang ensembles were established in the United States, owing to the influence of these migrant musicians. Their Filipino-American audiences have obtained a sense of identity through this diasporic music. In 2000, Danongan Kalanduyan was honored by Hillary Clinton through the conferment of the National Heritage Fellow of the United States of America’s National Endowment for the Arts.

 

Popular Music

 

Popular music or “pop music,” specifically the commercial or mass-mediated variety, is the predominant musical genre in the Philippines. Its reach is wide because it is the music that is produced and disseminated by the industry. Pop music comes in a variety of forms: ballads, novelty songs, folk songs, rock, jazz fusion, rap, and alternative music.

 

The period after 1986 witnessed the strengthening of the pop music scene with the unquestionable dominance and influence of western pop music, particularly from the United States. Rock, hip hop, and rap music became prevalent. The distribution was primarily through television, radio, and film. As the technological revolution of the last years of the 20th century reached Philippine shores, the dissemination of pop music accelerated and intensified through satellite-enabled interactive communications technology, even telepresenced, i.e., in real time. Many of these developments were beneficial to local music industry, but they also posed challenges in the artists and producers’ intellectual property rights as well as revenues. Government and private institutions have joined forces to address the concerns of Filipino songwriters and musicians regarding the matter.

 

Ballads. The establishment of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mangaawit (OPM) in the late 1980s helped uplift the pop music industry, for it encouraged the creation of new songs. Linked to the music productions were the various competitions for singing and songwriting, and the shows that gave equal opportunities to veteran songwriters, established singers, and new talents to succeed. Many of the songs that became popular during the period debuted in contests such as the Metropop Festival and later on, the PhilPop Music Festival. Some of these songs were “Sometimes You Just Know” by Danny Tan, Makko Pals, and Edith Gallardo, “Shine” by Trina Belamide, “Can’t Stop Loving You” by Dodjie Simon, and “Malayo Man, Malapit Din” (So Far, Yet So Near) by Bayang Barrios. Competitions abroad also contributed to the popularity of Danny Tan’s “Easy to Love You,” 1991, and “You Lift Me Up,” 1997; Vehnee Saturno’s “Love is All We Need,” 1991, and “Huwag nang Ipagpabukas Pa” (Don’t Procrastinate), 1993; and Ryan Cayabyab’s “Tayo Na” (Let’s Go), “Paraiso” (Paradise), and “Kahit Habang Buhay” (Even Until Forever).

Among the composers of pop ballads, a few stand out because of their impressive output and their ability to create one hit song after another. Ryan Cayabyab has probably contributed the most to the list. His classic hits include “Tuwing Umuulan at Kapiling Ka” (When It’s Raining and You’re With Me), “Minsan ang Minahal ay Ako” (Once When I Was the One You Loved) from the musical Katy!, “Better World,” “Can This Be Love,” and “Iniibig Kita” (I Love You). Another songwriter who consistently produced hits is Jose Mari Chan, and his works include “Beautiful Girl,” “Christmas in Our Hearts,” “Tell Me Your Name,” and “Deep in My Heart.” The versatile songwriter and performer Gary Valenciano has also many hit songs, several of which emphasized Christian values. Among his songs are: “Take Me Out of the Dark,” “Natutulog ba ang Diyos?” (Is God Asleep?), “Shout for Joy,” “Could You Be Messiah,” “Hataw Na” (Dance On), “Sa Yahweh” (Dance for the Lord), and “Babalik Ka Rin” (You’ll Return Someday).

Novelty Songs. The novelty songs that were created in the past thirty years emphasized the humorous side of the Filipino, even containing irreverent lines and sexual innuendos. Among the famous novelty songs are “Spaghetti” by the Sex Bomb Girls, “Babae Po Ako” (I am a Woman, Please) by Tuesday Vargas, “Sasakyan Kita” (Will Lay on You) by Gladys and the Boxers with K, “Bulaklak” (Flower) by the Viva Hotbabes, “Papa Cologne” by Parokya ni Edgar, “Giling giling” (Gyrations) by Willie Revillame, “Pare, Pa Kiss!” (Kiss, Dude) by Guadings, and “Otso otso” (Move Like Number 8) by Bayani Agbayani.

Some novelty songs, though, highlight the uniqueness of Philippine natural resources such as Ryan Cayabyab’s “Da Coconut Nut” and the opening song for the 1994 Miss Universe Pageant held in Manila, “Mabuhay!” (Long Live), and Banda ni Kleggy’s “Only in the Philippines.”

Pinoy Folk. Filipino musicians who wrote songs using the folk style continued to express patriotic sentiments using the simple combination of voice and an accompanying instrument, commonly the guitar. After 1986, songs that emphasize the Filipino value pakikipagkapwa (concern for others) came out. Heber Bartolome’s “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy” (We are Filipinos) highlighted the characteristics of Filipinos. His songs always had social themes and in the late 1980s, carried anti-US sentiments and a critique against militarization.

Right after the revolution, Coritha recorded “Oras Na” (It’s Time) and revived “Ang Bayan Kong Pilipinas” (My Country, the Philippines). In 1996, Inang Laya launched their album titled “Alay sa Laya ng Bayan” (Homage to the Country’s Freedom) to celebrate the centennial of the Philippine revolution. It included songs like “Sulong Gerilyo” (Advance, Guerilla), “Babaing Walang Kibo” (Silent Woman), “First Quarter Storm Medley,” “Tear Gas,” “Boykot/Lakbayan Medley” (Boycott/Touring Medley) and “Japayuki” (Filipina Entertainer in Japan).

Freddie Aguilar is perhaps the most popular among the folk singers and in 2007, together with his Watawat Band, Aguilar came up with “Ipaglalaban Ko” (I Will Fight), “Estudyante Blues” (Student Blues), “Sa Kuko ng Aguila” (In the Claws of the Eagle), and “Kumusta Ka?” (How Are You?). In 2013, he released a new single entitled “Eleksiyon na Naman” (It’s Election Time Again), a timely critique about the social practice of electoral vote buying. Other singers who mirrored the social realities of contemporary Filipino societies through their songs include Joey Ayala, Noel Cabangon, Chin Chin Gutierrez, Gary Granada, Grace Nono, and Bayang Barrios.

Pinoy Rock. During the late 1980s, rock music in the Philippines experienced an unprecedented growth with the emergence of innumerable bands. Many young and talented musicians tried their luck at performing in rock circuits in order to be signed by a recording label that could bankroll their first single or album. Many new rock bands tested the waters with a live audience that did not require perfect intonation but were looking for originality in the performers. It was these types of bands that developed a loyal following.

 

The Dawn, at one time the most prolific band in the Philippines, started in the 1980s and released its first album, Enveloped Ideas, in 1987. After the band’s success, Pinoy rock of the 1990s and beyond witnessed the birth of others like Side A Band, Eraserheads, South Border, Rivermaya, True Faith, After Image, Color It Red, Parokya ni Edgar, Tropical Depression, Mike Hanopol, Alamid, Sugarfree, Aegis, Bamboo, Wolfgang, Sponge Cola, Urbandub, Orange and Lemons, Mojofly, Hale, and Slapshock. It is interesting to note, though, that despite the upsurge in the number of bands in the country, the forerunner of Pinoy rock, Joey “Pepe” Smith, who was in hiatus in the last decades of the 20th century, proved that he still had a huge following. He made a successful comeback at the beginning of the 21st century and even had a reality TV show titled The Smiths that included three of his daughters, Queenie, Sanya, and Beebop.

An important factor in Pinoy rock’s proliferation was the support given by the radio station NU 107, which played music from both established and unknown bands, and held the annual NU Rock Awards from 1995 until 2010. Many popular rock bands were legitimized by the honors given out such as the song, video, album, and artist of the year awards. A few of the hits that had been given recognition are Alamid’s “Your Love,” Eraserheads’ “Ang Huling El Bimbo” (The Last El Bimbo), Bamboo’s “Noypi,” Kamikazee’s “Narda,” Sandwich’s “Betamax,” Ebe Dencel’s “Taking Second Chances,” Aegis’s “Halik” (Kiss), and Bamboo’s “Halik ni Hudas” (Judas’s Kiss).

 

Many bands also join the annual Red Horse Beer Muziklaban Rock Challenge competition, which started in 1998 where hundreds of bands congregate to vie for the championship. The winning group is rewarded with instant fame, a contract with recording label, or gigs in prime venues.

Pinoy Jazz. Pinoy jazz of the late 1980s was characterized by the light style more commonly known as pop jazz or smooth jazz. It emulated the music of American jazz artists David Benoit, Dave Grusin, David Arkenstone, Jim Chapelle, and Kenny G. The foremost advocates of smooth jazz in the Philippines during that time were Eddie Katindig and his nephew Boy Katindig. In the 1990s, Lito Molina and the Jazz Friends brought back music popularized by legendary jazz artists like Glenn Miller, Count Bassie, Louie Armstrong, Duke Ellington, and Tommy Dorsey Jr. This paved the way for a revival of mainstream jazz. Other Filipino jazz musicians searched for new directions that allowed them to create a distinct brand of jazz music that was not a mere copy of its American counterpart. The pioneer in this endeavor was Bob Aves who incorporated musical ideas from the indigenous groups of the Cordilleras and Mindanao into the genre. Others followed suit, and this resulted in a vibrant jazz milieu up to the present. This was even evident in schools, as seen in the enduring presence of the UP Jazz Band and the emergence of new jazz groups like the UP Latin Jazz Ensemble. Landmark Pinoy jazz compositions of the period include Angel Peña’s Balikbayan and Johnny Alegre’s Stone of Intramuros.

The Jazz Society of the Philippines was founded in 2003 by jazz enthusiasts, one of whom was the jazz chronicler Richie Quirino. The group aimed to promote jazz music appreciation through events like the annual Manila Jazz Festival, the Candid International Jazz Festival, the Full Moon Jazz Festival, and the CCP International Jazz Festival. These occasions provided opportunities for artists such as Bobby Enriquez, Angel Peña, The Brass Munkeys, The Affinity, Saxoforo, Jewelmer Jazz Band, MAJAM, Tots Tolentino, Popoy Valmonte, Jun Cadiz, Johnny Alegre, Emi Munji, Toti Fuentes, Mike Guevarra, Isha and Mishka Adams, Cookie Chua, Judith Banal, and Mon David to perform and be commercially successful.

Pinoy Rap. Rap music in the Philippines surged in the 1990s with singers like Andrew E. and Francis Magalona aka Francis M. Andrew E.’s popularity grew with songs like “Humanap ka Ng Pangit” (Look for an Ugly One), “Makati Girl,” and “Huwag Kang Gamol” (Don’t Be An Ass). In the album Rap is Francis M, Magalona critiqued the ills of Philippine society such as colonial mentality, drug addiction, and corruption in the government. The messages of his songs like “Mga Praning” (The Paranoids), “Halalan” (Election), and “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy” (We are Filipinos) were easy to understand and resonated with his audience. Francis M. is best remembered for his signature rap “Mga Kababayan Ko” (My Countrymen).

An unexpected album on rap music was Willie Nepomuceno’s Snap Revolution released in 1991. It contained a collection of clean, relevant, and responsive rap that neutralized the negative raps that were produced during the same period. The album parodied the events that took place during the four-day EDSA uprising. In recent years, more rap artists have emerged, and the list includes Denmark, the rap group Death Threat, Dice & K9 aka Mobbstarr from Cebu, Thavawenyoz from Davao, Zambo Top Dogs from Zamboanga, Pikaso, Audible, and Krook, and J.O.L.O. Presently, Gloc-9 is the most popular rap artist in the country. His songs are social commentaries, following the trail blazed by Francis M., and these include “Sirena” (Mermaid), “Upuan” (Chair), and “Walang Natira” (Everybody’s Gone). He also carries the distinction of being the fastest rapper in the Philippines.

Alternative Music. Any music that contrasts itself from the mainstream style is called “alternative.” Singer-songwriter Joey Ayala saw the word “alternative” as the merging of “altered” and “native,” which captures in a nutshell the hybridity of a native subject born to a modern culture. For him, it is the “blending [of] the old and new, presenting artistic and cultural alternatives, encouraging a tribal attitude in modern man, an attitude of oneness with and respect for the world we live in” (Caruncho 1988). Thus, alternative music could be viewed as a type of music that is marked with Filipino elements and gives the bagong lumad (new native) a voice.

Filipino alternative music is global pop or the fusion of traditional ballad style with the modern rock style of the West. This hybridization speaks of the confluence of the tone color, modes, and rhythms of Mindanao music with Western pop. Aside from Joey Ayala, other Filipino musicians who have ventured into creating an alternative sound include Ryan Cayabyab, Grace Nono, Chin Chin Gutierrez, Edru Abraham and his Kontra-Gapi, Pinikpikan, Makiling Ensemble, the short-lived Musika Asya, and Tugma. In 1989, Ryan Cayabyab embarked on his brand of Bagong Tunog Experiment in which he combined the native singkil beat and instruments like the kulintang with modern devices like synthesizers. It was primarily to provide a fresh sound to a commercial jingle to captivate the market based on a new corporate strategy of a softdrink company. Cayabyab composed four songs in this experimentation: “Bagong Tunog” (New Sound) interpreted by Miguel Vera; “Bilib Sila sa Pinoy” (They Admire the Filipinos) sung by Pablo Clemente; “Angat sa Iba” (Ahead of Others) performed by The CompanY; and “Buhay Bulilit” (Small Life) interpreted by Paskevill Bernardo.

Grace Nono is also known in the local music scene as one of the movers of this ethnic-inspired global pop. Her songs promote respect for mother nature and an individual’s innate freedom, as seen in her albums Tao Music, Opo (Yes), Isang Buhay (One Life), Hulagpos (Breaking Free), and Diwa (Spirit). Actress Chin Chin Gutierrez’s involvement in the preservation of indigenous music has been documented in her album Uyayi (Lullaby), released in 2004. It is a collection of lullabies from various ethnolinguistic groups as originally recorded in the field, followed by an alternative arrangement for each, with Gutierrez singing and accompanied by various combinations of western and indigenous instruments.

Edru Abraham and his Kontra-Gapi adhere to the Asian musical philosophy that performance is participatory, and each person present during a rendition contributes to the experience of creation as in a ritual process. Founded in 1989, the group has since performed for different kinds of audiences, and they have embarked on several European cultural encounters.

Pinikpikan’s music is also classified as global pop or world music. It fuses the distinct sound colors of indigenous instruments from the Philippines and from other parts of the world, with the electronic sounds of modern electric guitar and percussions. Their album Atas (Duty) received a Katha award in 2000. In 2008, Pinikpikan changed its name to Kalayo. Following the tradition of Pinikpikan and Grace Nono, the Makiling ensemble also propagates a Filipino version of global pop. This ensemble is comprised of alumni of the Philippine High School for the Arts led by Diwa de Leon. The most current addition to this list of alternative music groups is the UP-based Tugma, a group comprised of Asian music and musicology majors who specialize in the performance of traditional Asian, African, and Latin American instrumental and vocal music, coupled with dance. Unlike global pop proponents, though, this group adheres to cultural authenticity.

 

Conclusion

 

Philippine music since 1986 has been invigorated by the twin processes of localization and globalization. Advances in media and technology and affordability of travel further enabled these developments. But these developments would not have been possible without the intervention of government agencies and the political will of the artists themselves. The atmosphere of liberality resulting from the change in government in 1986 encouraged cultural productions that shifted focus from a direction dominated by elite tastes into one that celebrated the vibrant and multifaceted Filipino culture that combines popular, folk, indigenous, and Western-inspired classical traditions, giving opportunities to a wider selection of artists from all over the Philippines. The muchneeded governmental support for the arts which was realized through the major state policies implemented by agencies such as the CCP and NCCA resulted to more artistic creations and scholarly researches on the arts, placing emphasis on works that express the Filipino spirit. The radical shift in the thrusts of CCP initiated the dawning and eventual proliferation of indigenous cultural performances that stirred dynamic exchanges between artists from the regions and Manila.

The growth of the popular music industry in the Fifth Republic may also be attributed to the supportive government regulations that promoted the circulation of Philippine music in radio, television, film, print media, and other modes of mass technological distribution. The current generation of Filipinos continues to take advantage of new technologies through storing recorded music into their electronic devices and bringing these into the privacy of their homes. The transformation of the traditional mode of distribution formerly enjoyed by the recording industry into a cheaper mode of acquisition through the Internet has caused the Philippine recording industry’s economic plunge. New regulations are being implemented to cater to this new form of recorded music distribution; the effects of these merit future studies. Nevertheless, these new technologies offer Filipino musicians’ enormous possibilities in terms of creative works and innovative performance practices.

The improved process of music creation in this period explains the increase in collaborative works, particularly theater and dance productions. The huge output of modern operas, musicals, ballets, sarsuwelas, and other collaborative productions attests to the vibrant spirit of cooperation amongst artists, mostly influenced by global trends that became easily accessible beginning in the late 1980s. Visiting international theater groups with their modern technological production techniques, as well as the exposure of Filipino artists abroad have helped transform the general attitude and disposition of local artists and musicians, specifically in sustaining the standards of their productions to be at par with international measures.

This globalization has ensured the high valuation of indigenous music and dances emphasizing their significant role in establishing a modern Filipino identity. The uniqueness of Philippine traditional music from the different ethnolinguistic groups determines the special position of Filipinos in the global arena, and this has been capitalized by the government through cultural tourism. Many international music festivals have been organized in the past 30 years which highlighted the special musical traditions of the various Filipino cultural groups, attracting local and international enthusiasts to appreciate, study and reproduce these performances elsewhere. On the other side of the exchange process, many Filipino musicians have presented distinct Philippine repertoire to international audiences in Europe, North America, South America, and Asia.

The music in the Fifth Philippine Republic illustrates the various Filipino groups of artists and musicians’ aspiration to establish a contemporary cultural identity that represent the modern Filipino. In their myriad ways, Filipino musicians continue to create new works, perform established musical traditions, and publish new researches that express their current stance, influenced by the complexities of the twin processes of localization and globalization.Written by Arwin Q. Tan
