text:
Section:

Indigenous Music
Rural Hispanicized/Christian Music
Urban Transnational Music

The variety of Philippine music and musical practices represents a cultural pluralism molded by history, environment, and outside cultural influences. Although Philippine music is generally categorized as Western (i.e., acculturated) and non-Western (i.e., aboriginal or indigenous), it may be specifically defined according to social context, history, geography, performance styles, repertoire, and instruments.

Philippine music may therefore be classified as Cordillera highland, central west highland, Mindanao highland, Aeta, Islamic, rural Christian, and urbanized. The sources and influences on these groups will be discussed under Indigenous Music, Rural Hispanicized/Christian Music, and Urban Transnational Music. The last is further subdivided into art music and popular music.

 

Indigenous Music

 

While little record exists, if at all, of specific sources and origins of ethnic, pre-Christian Philippine music, sufficient evidence points to its close kinship to the music of Asia-Pacific. Given the history of trade and migrations, influences from China, India, and the Middle East shaped Southeast Asian, including Philippine music.

Philippine gong-chimes not only indicate Southeast Asian influence but also hint at Chinese roots. The Cordillera flat gongs called gangsa, gangha, kalsa or pinsak are also found in the southwestern provinces of China where they are known as tuluo, gaobianluo, and shiziluo. The bossed gongs are called mang. The bianmang, a set of 17 hanging gongs of graduated sizes similar to the Manobo hanging kulintang, is found in southern China, together with the mangqing or 14 small bossed gongs laid in three parallel rows in the same manner as the single-row kulintang of Muslim communities. Other Philippine instruments with Chinese counterparts include the nose flute, mouth harp, Isneg bamboo or the parallel-stringed tube zither, the polychordal zither, Kalinga tongatong or stamping tubes, Tagakaolo udol or plank drum, Kalinga balingbing or bamboo buzzer, and the Kalinga patang-ug or quill-shapedtubes. Philippine instruments similar to other Southeast Asian instruments include the two-stringed boat-shaped lute of Palawan and Mindanao called kudyapi, kuglong, which looks like the Bornean lute sapeh (sape or sambe) or its distant cousin, the Thai zither kachapi chakay, and the bamboo xylophone gabbang, gambang, which looks like the Javanese gambang kayu and Thai ranad. The bossed gongs of Mindanao, Sulu, and Palawan called kulintang, babandir, agung, gandingan, belong to the family of bossed gongs of Borneo, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam.

Although Indian influence on Philippine culture is believed to have been acquired through other cultures, it had a significant impact on local religious beliefs, language, and literature, including the system of writing and, to some extent, music. Evidence of the last is cursory, but points at some interesting musical connections. Terminological derivations include kudyapi from kachapi (Thai zither), gangsa from the Sanskrit kansya (gong or plate of bell metal), huni (tune, echo) from dhvani. Other hints are the miniature bells on costumes of the Mindanao highland peoples; details of the Ramayana in some Mindanao epics; and the soloistic improvisational, organically developed melodic structures of the instrumental music of the highland and Islamic communities of Mindanao.

Elements of Middle Eastern music are especially evident in Muslim modes of vocal rendition, which are characterized by highly ornamented melodic configurations and high vocal register. The manner of realizing the basic melodic structures allude to the Persian dastgah or Arabic maqam traditions. Instrumental accompaniment to songs is also semi-improvised. Among the Tausug, the biyula is played in the Middle Eastern way, with the tail of the instrument propped against the chest and the scroll pointed downward.

Other aspects of pre-Christian music include the use of the pentatonic and hexatonic modes, vocal techniques of sliding tones, glottal stops, and high vocal register, integration of music and dance, community participation, unmetered time, and nonfixed tuning instruments. All these are related to the music of Pacific islanders, who are part of the greater Malayo-Polynesian culture area.

 

 

 

Rural Hispanicized/Christian Music

 

Folk music among rural Christian Filipinos shows varying degrees of syncretic blending of European and Southeast Asian elements. In general, the entire repertoire basically falls under either of two musical categories: imported Western genres adopted into local practice or what can be termed indigenized Spanish music (e.g., music in the Christian liturgy, sung narratives, dance music genres like fandango and danza), and indigenous practices modified to accommodate Western cultural elements or what can be called Hispanicized indigenous music, as seen in rituals, song debate. Both of these are hybrid-acculturated music. Often, it is difficult to state which is more Hispanic and which is more indigenous Filipino. The syncretism is a product of prolonged music intercultural contact and exchange between Spain via Mexico and the inhabitants of the Philippine archipelago. The majority of Filipino folk songs that are in Western harmonic tonality are clear examples of the first category.

Western influences in Philippine music include themes and ideas derived from Western Christian literature such as prayers, biblical stories, religious legends, and tales of princes and princesses; the elements of Western theater; and the use of Western instruments and structural elements such as melodies and chords. Asiatic influences include the functional role of music in social and religious occasions such as rituals and celebrations; musical structures based on modal melodies as seen in the tagulaylay and awit, rhythmic flexibility, and a combination of drone and melody; the styles of performance (i.e., improvisation, usage of indigenous vocal techniques, and integration of music and dance, with the audience playing an active role); and the oral transmission of musical practices.

Specific forms showing syncretic fusion of Eastern and Western elements include religious dramas and events like the sinakulo, santacruzan, pangangaluluwa, and panunuluyan; metricalromances called the awit and korido; musical-dance forms like the pandanggo and balitaw; folk theater forms such as the komedya or moro-moro and linambay; the rituals of the pabasa, sanghiyang, and subli; various song genres such as the composo and huluna (lullaby); folk instrumental ensembles such as the rondalla, musikongbumbong, banda boca (voiced imitation of band instruments), pangkatkawayan, and a host of other smaller ensembles with improvised groupings of instruments.

 

 

 

Urban Transnational Music

 

Philippine music in urban communities is directly inherited from European influences that passed through Spain in the second half of 19th century, then through Anglo-American music traditions via Hong Kong, Singapore, and Australia when the English language gained supremacy in the 20th century. Today, it is better to call urban Filipino music as transnational because the usual unidirectional influencing between the “First World” of affluent Northern countries and the “Third World” of the South no longer holds true. Today, urban Filipino music even comes from Singapore and Australia which are famous for productions of Broadway musicals that have travelled to the Philippines in recent years. There are two distinct types of urban transnational music: art music and popular music.

Art Music. The classical and art music tradition in the Philippines can be traced to the 16th century missionaries, some of whom had specialized in music training in Spain before they were allowed to travel to the islands via Mexico. With Spanish musician-priests in San Agustin church in mid-18th century Intramuros and composers like Antonio Calahorra and Remigio Calahorra teaching at the Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral in the second half of the 19th century, the idea of a music conservatory emerged. In the late 19th century, visiting Spanish zarzuela and Italian opera companies kept Filipinos abreast of the musical scene in Europe and the United States. In the meantime, local musicians performed Western art music not only in urban areas but also in provinces where brass bands entertained the folk. In the 20th century, Filipino musicians and composers further honed their skills by studying in Europe and the United States.

At the beginning of the Spanish colonial regime, the clergy taught Filipinos to sing the plainsong or canto llano to the accompaniment of the organ; to dance and sing; and to play the flute, harp, guitar, and other instruments. In these activities, Filipinos showed great adaptability, especially in Manila, where there were many fine choirs of chanters and musicians who were quite skilled.

Churches all over the Philippines developed musicians, choral directors, and composers whose works were patterned after liturgical musical style prevalent in the Hispanic world. By the late 19th century, church music compositions were further influenced by the classical operatic style with florid solo parts and dramatic choral sections. One of the most celebrated church music composers and performers of the 19th century was MarceloAdonay of Pakil, Laguna, whose unparalleled skills earned him the title “Palestrina of the Philippines.” During this period, secular music composed by Simplicio Solis, JulioNakpil, JulianFelipe, and Jose Estella consisted of hymns, waltzes (the tanda de valses being the most popular subtype), gavottes, and patriotic songs based on native airs or folk songs.

The 19th-century Spanish zarzuela was introduced in the country with the staging of F. Barbieri’s Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire) in 1879. Soon, the form was adapted all over the country. Local writers and dramatists wrote sarsuwela in Tagalog, Pampango, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Bicol, Cebuano, Ilongo, and Waray. The music generally followed the simple song form of the Spanish zarzuela, and the dances were light, usually using the waltz and the pasodoble. Composers also used native airs such as the kundiman, danza, and balitaw, asserting a Filipino identity and expressing subtle nationalistic sentiments, especially in the politically inspired plays.

The advent of the opera in the last half of 19th century also significantly influenced local music and showcased the vocal prowess of local talents. The florid aria “AngMaya“ (The Sparrow) by JoseEstella for Filipinas para los Filipinos (The Philippines for the Filipinos) required the vocal technique of an opera singer. The first Filipino opera, SangdugongPanaguinip (Dreamed Alliance) by LadislaoBonus, produced in 1902, contains some difficult vocal passages.

Operatic singing also influenced the native kundiman. The kundiman in early 19th century was a dance-song in simple binary form with parallel major-minor tonality. Its bipartite section was similar to most Filipino folk songs. In the latter part of 19th century, though, the kundiman became simply a song with a poetic text focusing on subtle and metaphorical expressions of love. By the early 20th century, in the hands of NicanorS.Abelardo, Bonifacio Abdon, and FranciscoSantiago, the kundiman became dramatic and in some cases had three sections, which could be attributed to the influence of the romantic operas being performed then by visiting French and Italian companies.

The establishment of formal music academies and conservatories at the turn of the 20th century brought in fresh repertoires of instrumental music, notably the piano literature of the romantic composers Frederick Chopin, Robert Schumann, Felix Mendelsohn, and Franz Liszt. The first Filipino composer to have used folk materials in his music was Diego C. Perez who wrote Recuerdos de Filipinas y sus Cantares (Memories of Philippines and Their Songs) in 1886. He was followed by Julio Nakpil, who used native forms like the dalit and Jose Estella who wrote the first multi-movement symphony titled Filipinas in 1928, based on folk materials. Bravura became the primary ingredient in the works of the later leading composers such as FranciscoBuencamino, Juan de Sahagun Hernandez, FranciscoSantiago, Rodolfo Cornejo, and Bernardino Custodio. Some of their nocturnes, waltzes, and concertos were based on Filipino folk melodies.

The early music of Abelardo shows great mastery of the harmonic-chromatic language of the romantic period, challenging the performer beyond the level of technical proficiency. In later years, Abelardo wrote in the expressionist style of post-Wagnerian composers such as Richard Strauss and Arnold Schoenberg and used ambiguous tonal language and disjunct melodic structures.

Contemporaries of Abelardo and Santiago were influenced by the romantic style, with traces of the impressionist and neoclassic techniques in their works. They used Philippine folk music materials in their tone painting, as well as descriptive and programmatic writing. They preferred tone poems and overtures since they were shorter than symphonies, had greater mass appeal, and could be scored for the more accessible brass band. One composer who wrote complex and stunning symphonic variations in the 1920s was Alexander Lippay, director of UP Conservatory from 1925 to 1930. Lippay was a student of Franz Schreker.

Antonio J. Molina’s works can be traced to the European zarzuela and opera, the religiousmusic of the Romantic period, and the impressionist and some post-expressionist music. The works of HilarionF.Rubio, who was also an opera and band conductor, display dramatic contrast and programmatic tone painting, influenced as he was by the program overtures of Beethoven and Mendelssohn. His later works for chamber ensemble such as Ang Manok at ang Bayawak (The Rooster and the Iguana) and The Strutting Peacock are also descriptive, and uses the harmonic idiom of the French neoclassicists. Antonino Buenaventura’s works, as exemplified by the well-known BytheHillside, combine the transparent, coloristic texture of the impressionist school and the orchestral sonority of the late romantic period.

Among the next generation of composers, it was LucioD.SanPedro who was greatly influenced by the instrumental works of Tchaikovsky and Wagner which focused on the organic and variational development of thematic ideas. On the other hand, the dramatic and programmatic character of Felipe Padilla de Leon’s compositions echoes the operas of Puccini. Padilla de Leon’s later works use some 20th-century techniques in descriptive fashion, as in Sayaw ng Igorot (Igorot Dance) for piano and Tatlong Tunog Larawan (Three Sound Portraits) for orchestra.

Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s descriptive eclectic style, ranging from romantic to neoclassic, stemmed from his association of specific idioms to specific emotions and other extramusical ideas. Jerry A. Dadap shared this concept of music creation, adopting a wider variety of writing styles, from the traditional kundiman vocal style of Abelardo and Santiago to the neoclassic structures, and even avant-garde devices.

Eliseo M. Pajaro and LucreciaR.Kasilag belong to the neoclassic school. Both were trained in the United States in the tradition of Paul Hindemith of the Eastman School of Music. Pajaro’s Western abstract works—symphony, sonata, concerto, oratorio, song cycle, and fugue—contain bitonally harmonized Filipino themes. While utilizing traditional melodies and chords, Kasilag also departs from the traditional Western neoclassic language not only by combining different tonalities from the same well-tempered chromatic scale, but by fusing scales, modes, and instrumental timbres from both Western and non-Western music. She has also written works using avant-garde elements such as improvisation, electronics, and physical movement. Later neoclassic composers were RosendoSantos, Fr Manuel Maramba, OSB, and AngelM.Peña.

Jose Maceda’s works are directly inspired by his contact with music making among indigenous Philippine and other Asian music traditions, and his study of their structural elements (i.e., drone and melody) and their social and philosophical significance. The community-oriented rituals engendered his ideas of musical performance involving large groups of people, rather than standard ensembles or solo playing. His compositional technique consists of forming mass structures and clouds of sounds, as well as fusing and diffusing different classes of timbres. The technique is directly influenced by the French musique concrete movement and its principal pioneers and exponents Edgar Varese, Pierre Schaeffer, Olivier Messiaen, and Iannis Xenakis.

Avant-garde literature of the 1950s and 1960s was introduced through the concerts organized by Maceda, as well as through international conferences and meetings, starting with the UNESCO-sponsored Musics of Asia in 1966. Avant-garde music had an impact on a younger generation of Filipino composers, especially on RamonP.Santos, BayaniM.deLeon, and FranciscoF.Feliciano. After studying abroad, they developed their individual styles which bore influences from the different New Music idioms prevailing in Europe and the United States. The early music of Santos used the serial technique and later the open-ended forms inspired by the aleatoric music of John Cage. De Leon was also influenced by Cage, although his works draw their significance from extramusical ideas—usually inspired by metaphysical concepts—rather than compositional techniques. Thus, De Leon freely used various idioms, even those based on conventional harmony or neoclassic language, in his later works. On the other hand, Feliciano’s mature works, developed while he studied with the European masters Isang Yun and Krystof Penderecki, reflected the structural clarity and organic principles of the German tradition. In spite of the new techniques of writing they acquired from abroad, Santos, De Leon, and Feliciano drew their basic musical ideas from Philippine traditional music and culture. Some elements are structural, as may be seen in Santos’s Abot-Tanaw (Horizons), De Leon’s Okir, Feliciano’s Siya-Kuno (They Say It’s Him); others are literary as in Santos’s Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau) and Tin-ig (Voices), De Leon’s Sugatang Perlas (Wounded Pearl), Feliciano’s LaLobaNegra (The Black She-wolf); and others are philosophical as in Santos’s Likas-An (Nature-ing) and De Leon’s Bahay Bata (Womb).

The music of the following generation of composers—ChinoToledo, Conrado del Rosario, Verne de la Peña, Ruben R. Federizon, Arlene Chongson, and Jonas Baes—was also influenced by modern Western idioms. Toledo’s sensitivity to color and texture shows the strong influence of French and electronic music. Although different in temperament, the music of De la Peña and Federizon are based on traditional Philippine rhythms, modes, and timbres. Del Rosario’s style, on the other hand, may be identified with the German New Music idiom, with more sensitivity to color and texture. The later works of American-trained Chongson combine neoclassic forms with non Western-music structures. Baes was influenced by Maceda’s large-scale works as well as his traditional music. Thus, he uses simple melodic materials and sounds in building different sound textures.

Beginning 1990s, a new batch of composers emerged. Among them are Christine Muyco, Jed Balsamo, Jocelyn Marfil, Feliz Macahis, and Robin Estrada. Indigenous music concepts continue to be an inspiration in their “new music” that is for the academy. However, these composers have also crossed borders by composing many multimedia works in the realm of popular culture such as music, theater, dance, and film.

Popular Music. Philippine popularmusic is principally characterized by its wide circulation as a consequence of its mediation in print and via audio mechanical reproduction. It may be traced to the folk music of the villages, which accompanied dances for public entertainment such as fiestas and secular celebrations. The dances such as minuet, fandango, polka, mazurka, and habanera were mostly European in origin. On the other hand, the folksongs of ordinary people about everyday life include ballads, work songs, lullabies, drinking songs, and humorous songs. Folk, which is normally passed on orally in small-scale face-to-face societies, becomes popular when it is written down and then printed or broadcast in mass media. The process is reversed, i.e., the popular becomes folk, when people from the rural areas learn a foreign song from the radio and then absorb it into their existing oral genres and repertories. The case of salidummay is a good example of this process. Many melodies in this genre were first heard in Christian evangelical church and public school unison songs.

The American regime brought in new institutions of social entertainment and mass culture, namely, the dance halls called cabaret (pronounced kabaret), the bodabil or variety show, the radio, and the cinema. It was also during this time that dance bands and dance orchestras, which served as the standard media of popularmusic, were introduced. Their repertoire consisted of prevailing American popularmusic—jazz and its dance varieties like the fox-trot, one-step, and swing; Latin American-influenced dances such as the tango, rhumba, cha-cha, and samba; the boogie-woogie and the rock ‘n’ roll of the 1940s and the 1950s; the love songs mostly culled from musicals and the radio; and since the late 1980s, American hip-hop music. Filipinos were quick to fuse the near-dance rhythms with folk material, as seen in “BahayKubo“ (Nipa Hut) and “SarungBanggi“ (One Night), substituting Filipino lyrics for the English or composing new songs in the same pattern. It is interesting to note that at the turn of the century, “Sarung Banggi” was a popular song with a known composer. Today, few remember the composer because it has already entered the folk repertory similar to what happened to the Igorot salidummay.

After World War II, an instrumental ensemble called cumbanchero proliferated as an offshoot of the popularity of the band leader Xavier Cugat, dubbed the “Rhumba King” in the 1950s. The ensemble consisted of imported and improvised instruments: harmonica, maracas, bongos, conga drum, guitar, guiro, jaw bone, and a one-string bass with remodeled World War II military vehicle gas containers serving as the resonator. This craze was followed by another ensemble called combos by the time rock ‘n’ roll was marketed via vinyl records and cassette tapes in the country starting in the 1960s. Combos are particularly identified with electric guitars and bass and the trap drum set.

The influence of American popularmusic culture was so strong in the 1960s that radio and TV programs such as the top-rated Student Canteen launched searches for Filipino counterparts of American music idols such as Perry Como, Elvis Presley, Johnny Mathis, and Neil Sedaka. In reaction, the search for a Filipino identity in popularmusic came to a head in the same decade as local composers and songwriters began to produce original works in the vernacular which expressed local themes and ideas. The Filipinization of popularmusic that time counts among its exponents rock and roller Bobby Gonzales, folk singers Florante, FreddieAguilar, and HeberBartolome, novelty singer YoyoyVillame, rock artists Mike Hanopol and Joey Smith, and rapper Francis Magalona. These musicians were superseded by groups like the Eraserheads, Parokya ni Edgar, Side A, The Dawn, and Gloc-9 in the 1990s. However, the musical idioms, whether ballad, folk, rock, or rap, remained faithful to their American models such as Elvis Presley, Joan Baez, Peter, Paul and Mary, Fats Domino, Frank Zappa, Vanilla Ice, and M.C. Hammer.

In the 1980s, popmusic artists such as JoeyAyala at ang Bagong Lumad, Edru Abraham’s Kontra Gapi, Heber Bartolome’s Banyuhay, Asin, Pen Pen, and Pinikpikan began to use materials from non-Western cultures. They called their music neo-ethnic, but actually they were not unique for their idioms were also influenced by the larger global pop called world music or world beat in which musicians from developing countries were appropriated by producers from developed countries such as Peter Gabriel and the Grateful Dead.

Philippine pop ballads have their roots in the early American cinema and musical stage shows. Early Philippine cinema drew principally on sarsuwela such as WalangSugat (No Wounds) and DalagangBukid (Country Maiden), as well as from bodabil. Sarsuwela arias in simple harmonic and melodic modes, early popular dance rhythms, and an emerging kundiman-style of writing were the ingredients of the Filipino love songs, most of which were born at the movies. The most popular love songs were Mike Velarde’s “DahilSaIyo“ (Because of You), a danza composed for the film BituingMarikit (Beautiful Star) and Constancio de Guzman’s “Halina’t Magsaya” (Come and Celebrate), a balitaw for the movie Lambingan (Tender Affection). The love ballads of later composers such as ErnaniCuenco, RestieUmali, and GeorgeCanseco trace their aesthetic origins to this musical lineage. On the other hand, middle-of-the-road English and Filipino love songs by WillyCruz, JoseMariChan, and Alice Doria Gamilla echo those of Cole Porter, Jerome Kern, and other early Broadway composers. Contemporary American ballads, modern jazz, and the rock-theater music of the 1960s and 1970s such as those from Hair and Jesus Christ Superstar are the basic sources of Ryan Cayabyab’s works, including his experiments with indigenous music and the everyday jargon of the young masses.

The plethora of sources and influences, and the relation of Philippine music to other types of music are only two aspects of Philippine music. Through the centuries, Filipino artists have reshaped outside influences to fulfill their aesthetic needs, making the music truly their own.Written by Ramon P. Santos, u pdated by Jose S.
